human: Representative Mike Johnson wasn’t the first — or second — choice for speaker of the House, but he was the only congressman to successfully secure a majority of votes. He now faces his first major test with a deadline looming for a government shutdown on Nov. 17.
llm: Representative Mike Johnson (R-LA) was elected by his peers to serve as the next House Republican Conference Chairman, a position that will make him one of the most powerful people in Washington. Johnson is an ardent supporter of President Trump and has been involved with conservative causes since his days at Louisiana State University. His commitment to our country is unquestioned, but his promotion is bad news for the future of this nation.

human: What small moments from your life do you think about often? Scenes from your childhood? An experience with your friends or family, or maybe a stranger? A memory that makes you laugh — or breaks your heart, or fills you with regret?
llm: What small moments from your life do you think about often?

human: Roni Abuharon, a detective in the southern Israeli city of Ofakim, grabbed his pistol and floppy police hat. “Don’t leave me alone,” his wife pleaded as sirens signaled incoming rockets from the Gaza Strip, less than 20 miles away.
llm: Roni Abuharon, a police spokesman who witnessed the shooting of Officer Zidan, said that the police were not prepared for the kind of violence they faced. “We weren’t ready,” he said. “We didn’t have the equipment.”

human: Naya Qeshta was born in Rafah on November 11. Her mother, Samah, was one of tens of thousands of pregnant women in Gaza relying on a health care system that has been crippled by Israel’s ongoing siege.
llm: Naya Qeshta was born in the Gaza Strip, where she grew up and studied. She is a writer and journalist for several newspapers and magazines in Palestine and abroad. She also works as an editor-in-chief of a monthly magazine in Gaza City. Her articles have been published by various newspapers and magazines such as: Al Hayat (London), Al Ahram Weekly (Cairo), Al Jazeera Magazine (Doha) and many others. Naya has worked as a researcher on women's issues at the Palestinian Center for Policy Research & Strategic Studies and as a program coordinator for the Arab Women Organization, Gaza. She has written three books and translated five books from English to Arabic.

human: The last time I went to the Peking Duck House on Mott Street, I drank a lot of good wine. This has nothing to do with the restaurant’s own list and everything to do with its longstanding policy of letting diners bring in wine, free of corkage fees.
llm: The last time we caught up with the folks at Wine Spectator, they were just getting ready to launch a new publication called Restaurants. Now that it's been out for more than a year, we wanted to know how it was going and what was next on the agenda.

human: A list of 10 “Working Rules” is taped to the concrete wall on the top floor of the Swiss architect Peter Zumthor’s studio, which overlooks a dramatic alpine landscape through floor-to-ceiling glass. Rule No. 1: “Have a clear idea of what you want.”
llm: A list of 10 things to do in Los Angeles, including “Hear It: Katy Perry,” at the Hollywood Bowl; “See It: ‘The Sense of an Ending,’” at the Cinefamily; and “Eat It: Chef’s Tasting Menu at Otium.”

human: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his wife, Nadine Menendez, were both charged last fall in a broad federal corruption case in which they were accused of accepting cash and gold bribes.
llm: Senator Robert Menendez's wife, the focus of a federal corruption investigation, asked Tuesday for her own trial separate from that of her husband and an eye doctor accused of bribing him with political contributions, trips to Paris and the Dominican Republic, and other gifts.

human: To borrow some terminology from professional wrestling, an art form much beloved by the traders and lawyers of “Billions” (to say nothing of the show’s writers), Mike Prince is a monster heel champion. He is a bad guy at the top of the heap, gold around his waist and his last defeat a distant memory. Seemingly impervious to attack, Prince steamrolls every babyface contender who comes his way. He is an effective villain because he has been booked to be unstoppable — all to better set up the moment when he is stopped.
llm: To borrow some more movie terminology, this is a great episode for the middle of the series. It is a well-written and acted outing that does a lot to set up the rest of the season, but also makes sure not to alienate viewers who have been watching all along. And I love how it gives us a look at Wendy (Maggie Siff), who has not gotten much screentime in this seventh season, and then gives her an episode that allows her to shine. This was one of those episodes where the only complaint I could muster was that it ended too soon.

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a major threat to his leadership on Tuesday, advancing his flagship immigration policy over the objections of hard-right factions in his Conservative Party. But the victory may prove fleeting as he faces several more hurdles to the plan, which would deport asylum seekers to Rwanda.
llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's Brexit deal was defeated in the House of Commons by 283 votes to 312. Credit: PA

human: Peter Crombie, an actor who was probably best known for his memorable portrayal of “Crazy” Joe Davola on five episodes of the hit sitcom “Seinfeld,” died on Wednesday in a health care facility in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 71.
llm: Peter Crombie, an actor who played the role of a menacing and vindictive cop in the “Soup Nazi” episode of “Seinfeld,” died on Tuesday in Dublin. He was 71. His death was announced by his wife, Annemarie McLoughlin. She did not give a cause. Mr. Crombie played Sgt. O’Rourke, a New York police officer obsessed with enforcing the city’s no-standing law.

human: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen, described her journey from Gaza to Egypt.
llm: Lena Beseiso, a U.S. citizen who was born in Jerusalem and raised in Texas, crossed into Gaza at the Rafah border crossing on Tuesday morning. She is the first American to cross from Egypt into the Gaza Strip since 2006.

human: On Tuesday, I made the wrenching but necessary decision to resign as Harvard’s president. For weeks, both I and the institution to which I’ve devoted my professional life have been under attack. My character and intelligence have been impugned. My commitment to fighting antisemitism has been questioned. My inbox has been flooded with invective, including death threats. I’ve been called the N-word more times than I care to count.
llm: On Tuesday, I was told that I would not be rehired as a professor of the practice for the coming academic year. It is not clear why this decision was made. As my colleagues know, this is not the first time that I have been fired by an employer because of my sexual orientation or gender identity and expression. While I am disappointed to lose my position teaching in Harvard's Graduate School of Education (GSE), I also feel a sense of relief. My hope is that my story will provide a broader understanding of what it means to live openly as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, and/or asexual (LGBTQIA+) person in America today—particularly in education and other professional fields.

human: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Thursday declared a two-week state of emergency in the capital, Port Moresby, and suspended the Pacific island nation’s chief of police after violent protests left the city shellshocked.
llm: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea, Peter O’Neill, has declared a state of emergency in the capital Port Moresby after violent rioting. The declaration comes as police attempt to regain control of the city following two days of rioting that have killed five people and left dozens injured.

human: Almost two years have passed since I began trying to draw people’s attention to the widening gap between economic perceptions and economic reality. At the time the economic picture was mixed, with rapid job growth yet also rising inflation; even given that mixed picture, consumer sentiment seemed abnormally low.
llm: Almost two years ago, I wrote a post that asked whether the "feel good economy" was in fact a "feel bad economy." In the intervening time, we have seen an extraordinary period of policy activism by central banks around the world. The Bank of Japan has embarked on its most aggressive monetary easing program since the 1930s and is now buying government bonds at negative yields (meaning they are paying interest to bondholders). The European Central Bank has also taken measures to reduce long-term interest rates through purchases of sovereign debt in what has been dubbed a "quantitative easing lite." The Federal Reserve's second round of quantitative easing--which began in late 20

human: You may be partly joking, Mary, but this is probably a minor reason Democrats do a bit better among older voters than people might guess!
llm: You may be asking, what is that? Well it's when I answer a few questions that readers have asked me in recent weeks. This is always a fun exercise because you get to see what my readers are thinking about and also get to learn something new about them! So here we go:

human: The video shows a projectile streaking through the darkened skies over Gaza and exploding in the air. Seconds later, another explosion is seen on the ground.
llm: The video shows the hospital being struck by a missile from an aircraft, and it is undisputed that the strike was carried out by Israeli forces. But the IDF has denied using air-dropped munitions in this attack, and has claimed instead to have used artillery shells fired from ground positions. The video of the aftermath shows a large crater in front of the hospital entrance, which is consistent with the use of an aerially delivered weapon such as a high explosive bomb or rocket. The strike also caused extensive damage to the roof, interior rooms, and exterior walls of the hospital compound. This suggests the use of a large weapon with significant blast effects. The IDF's only artillery weapons capable of delivering such destructive power are the G

human: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals. They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar. As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.
llm: Every spring, trillions of flowers bloom across the Northern Hemisphere. But as temperatures rise and seasons change, many plants are changing their sexual habits. A new study from the University of Leeds has found that flowering plants are evolving to have less sex in order to survive climate change.

human: Update: The mayor of London on Sunday announced that the planned Tube strike had been suspended.
llm: Update: The mayor of London has now ordered the shutdown to be delayed until Saturday.

human: Instead of the usual “each week we choose a theme, and bring you three or four stories on that theme” business, this episode of “This American Life” throws all that away and brings you 20 stories — yes, 20 — in 60 minutes.
llm: Instead of the usual one-act plays, the actors performed a series of scenes from various plays. It was an entertaining show with some very talented people. The director was Lori Bates.

human: Julia Kate Tiller and Eric Daniel Graves didn’t meet at her older brother’s graduation in 2019, although they both attended (Mr. Graves is Ms. Tiller’s brother’s friend). They didn’t fall in love at church in the summer of 2021, although that’s where they met.
llm: Julia Kate Tiller

human: President Biden told Israel’s leaders on Tuesday that they were losing international support for their war in Gaza, exposing a widening rift with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who rejected out of hand the American vision for a postwar resolution to the conflict.
llm: President Biden told reporters that “Israel has to understand, they are losing support. They are losing support in the world community.”

human: Joseph Lelyveld, who worked as a reporter and editor at The New York Times for 39 years, the last seven of them as executive editor, died on Jan. 5. He was 86. Below, Bill Keller, who served as a managing editor under Mr. Lelyveld, and later as The Times’s executive editor from 2003 to 2011, remembers Mr. Lelyveld as a journalist.
llm: Joseph Lelyveld, who died at 85 on Thursday after a long career as an editor and journalist, was the kind of person who earned his following.

human: Here’s a holiday recipe you probably haven’t made.
llm: Here’s a holiday tradition that just keeps getting stranger: every year, the number of “smart” dolls on wish lists rises. The most popular one this year is Cozmo, a robotic toy by Anki. But why would anyone want a smart toy for Christmas?

human: With great fanfare this week, CNN announced it would host the network’s first debate of the 2024 presidential campaign, gathering the Republican candidates for a marquee event on Jan. 21 at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire.
llm: With great fanfare, CNN announced it would be hosting two Democratic presidential debates in Des Moines this summer, one of them a prime-time event on July 30.

human: An inmate stabbed Derek Chauvin 22 times last week at a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona said on Friday in announcing attempted murder charges.
llm: An inmate stabbed the Minnesota police officer who was seen on video punching an unarmed motorist during a traffic stop, the Justice Department said Thursday, as federal prosecutors announced that they had completed their investigation into the beating and would not pursue charges against the officer.

human: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
llm: The future of OpenAI is now in doubt. A group of 10 researchers have threatened to leave the artificial intelligence startup over the company's direction and work environment.

human: Everything makes way for the Olympics. Even an event as important to the host nation as the Tour de France.
llm: Everything makes way for the Tour. I am sure that if the Tour was going to pass through London, there would have been a great deal of discussion about whether or not they should close off Trafalgar Square or Big Ben to allow the peloton to pass by. It's all a matter of perspective.

human: President Biden signed a short-term government funding bill on Thursday, narrowly averting a government shutdown but leaving a larger spending clash for Congress early next year.
llm: President Biden signed the 2015 spending bill into law Thursday night, averting another government shutdown. The deal to fund the federal government through September 2015 passed both houses of Congress earlier in the day by wide margins. It's an important achievement for President Biden and his administration, which has been plagued by high-profile failures such as ObamaCare and the VA scandal.

human: Hours after Hamas gunmen crossed the border into Israel, slaughtering and kidnapping soldiers and random civilians alike, Palestinians in Gaza knew what was coming next.
llm: Hours after Hamas's surprise win in the Palestinian legislative elections, Israel sealed off the Gaza Strip with a curfew. Palestinians had been warned that anyone found on the streets would be shot at sight. The curfew was lifted only a few days later. During this period, an Israeli sniper shot and killed two Palestinians who were sitting in a taxi near the Erez crossing. They were going to pick up a relative from an Israeli hospital.

human: For nearly a decade, the sensational killing of a prominent Florida law professor in 2014 centered on a single, sordid question: Did his ex-wife’s family, motivated by an ugly custody dispute, hire hit men to murder him?
llm: For nearly a year, dentist Robert A. Burt had been telling his girlfriend that he wanted to kill her husband, and she had gone along with the plan. But on June 27, when they met in a motel room to do it, Dr. Burt's girlfriend changed her mind, called police and turned him in. On July 14, after a three-week trial, a jury convicted him of solicitation to commit first degree murder. He was sentenced to 30 years in prison.

human: Ford Motor has recalled about 238,000 Explorers because of a defect that poses a risk of the sport utility vehicles rolling away if the parking brake is not engaged.
llm: Ford Motor has issued a recall of its Ford Explorer and Mercury Mountaineer SUVs due to a problem with the vehicle's cruise control switch. The recall affects about 196,000 Ford Explorer vehicles from model years 2002 through 2005, as well as an additional 42,000 Mercury Mountaineer SUVs built between 2002 and 2005.

human: WILMINGTON, Del. — Mitch Landrieu, the coordinator of President Biden’s ambitious infrastructure program, is stepping down from his post to help lead the president’s re-election campaign, the White House said in a statement on Monday.
llm: WILMINGTON, Del. — The Democratic presidential primary field is growing crowded, but not so much that Joe Biden didn’t have time on Tuesday night to take a few moments to congratulate one of his former employees for joining the race.

human: Artem Marchuk needed to escape Ukraine or die. He didn’t see any other options.
llm: Artem Marchuk needed to get out of Ukraine. His parents had died in a car accident and he was living with his grandfather on a pension of about $30 a month. He was 26 years old and felt like his future was slipping away.

human: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving. He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up. His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn. Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world. Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read. On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
llm: “The Core of the Onion: Why We Eat What We Eat” is a book that will make you rethink your dinner. . . . Kurlansky's book is an unforgettable, mouthwatering journey into our shared culinary past.” — The Washington Post

human: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly. After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing. So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured. There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.
llm: Grief moves slowly, and I think that is what is happening here. We are still processing our shock over the election results and all of the implications they have for us as Jews and as Americans. The question remains: How do we move forward? It will take some time, but I am hopeful that those of us who care about social justice, human rights, and economic fairness will find a way to stay engaged and continue to fight for these issues, even when it feels like nothing has changed.

human: In New York, where roughly 7.7 million people flowed through the southern half of Manhattan every weekday before the pandemic — almost a quarter of them by motor vehicle — finding a place to park is not exactly easy.
llm: In New York, there are 1.8 million parking spaces. That’s a lot of space to store cars that are sitting idle most of the time. But it’s not enough to satisfy demand in a city where people drive more than they walk. The result is a parking problem that costs the average driver about $500 per year and adds up to $2 billion in lost revenue for the city. In the latest episode of Freakonomics Radio, Stephen Dubner explores this paradox with reporter Linda Pollak, who wrote a series of articles on the subject called “The City’s Most Wasted Resource: Parking.”

human: There are two big questions right now about the U.S. economy. One is why it’s doing so well. The other is why so many Americans insist that it’s terrible.
llm: There are two kinds of people in the world: those who think that Joe Biden is the worst vice president since Dick Cheney, and those who think that Joe Biden is a political genius.

human: A bright red cape and headband. Creamy cable knit pants. Overcoats of all sorts: Single-breasted and double-breasted, in shades of camel and pink, some skimming knees and others falling closer to the floor.
llm: A bright red sweater and black tights make a pretty good first impression. But if you're wearing snow-white snow boots with them, well . . . let's just say that your footwear is not exactly making an elegant statement.

human: Thumbs up.Five stars.You’ll love it.It’s very easy to use.It will never break!
llm: Thumbs up.Five stars.You’ll never go wrong with this one. This restaurant is definitely the best in town. A must-try! I love everything about it: the ambiance, the service and of course, their food. It’s definitely worth every penny.

human: This week, I called Dr. Izzeldin Abuelaish, a physician from Gaza who now lives in Canada, to check in on him. During Israel’s 2008-9 war on Gaza, three of his daughters were killed when an Israeli tank struck their home. This time, I had to offer my condolences again, when he told me about the recent deaths of more than 25 members of his extended family in Gaza. Among them, he said, were five babies.
llm: This week, I'm joined by my good friend and co-host of the podcast, Jason. We talk about the difficult choice between revenge or forgiveness, as well as what it takes to make that decision. If you are in a place where you're struggling with this very thing, please listen to the episode and know that you are not alone. God is with you, and He will help you choose life over revenge!

human: Nearly 50 years to the day after the Yom Kippur War in 1973, Israel was again taken by surprise by a sudden attack.
llm: Nearly 50 years after the Six-Day War, a veteran Israeli general looks back and reflects.

human: The Russian pop star winced as the black kitten he was cuddling in Russian-occupied Ukraine licked the crook of his neck for about the 15th time.
llm: The Russian pop star is pictured wearing a see-through dress.

human: Barely a month after winning a landmark phone-hacking lawsuit against a British publisher, Prince Harry on Friday withdrew an unrelated libel suit against the publisher of another tabloid paper, The Mail on Sunday.
llm: Barely a month after launching his libel suit, Prince Harry has withdrawn the case against Associated Newspapers. The lawsuit was filed over photos published in the Mail on Sunday that showed him frolicking nude with friends at a Las Vegas hotel suite. It turns out that he and his mother are now considering their options for legal action against those responsible for leaking the images. [Telegraph]

human: Robert H. Precht, who for more than a decade produced “The Ed Sullivan Show,” the Sunday night variety extravaganza that for 23 years brought singers, comedians, rock bands, jugglers, animal acts and the Italian mouse puppet Topo Gigio into the living rooms of millions of viewers, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Missoula, Mont. He was 93.
llm: Robert H. Precht, who produced “The Ed Sullivan Show” from the late 1960s through its final broadcast in 1971 and was a longtime television executive, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

human: The Great Lawn, the 12-acre oval of green space that is one of the most popular gathering places in Central Park, will be closed to the public until April after it was damaged during a concert late last month, the Central Park Conservancy confirmed on Tuesday.
llm: The Great Lawn, the 55-acre swath of green in Central Park where New Yorkers picnic, sunbathe and watch free concerts, will be closed until at least early April after a rock concert damaged the grass so severely that it is unlikely to recover.

human: Why run? I ask myself this question as I lace up my shoes, as I confront an approaching hill, as I coax one more lap out of my aching calves. The obvious answer is that we run to be healthy, to improve our cardiovascular systems and our moods, to become fitter and stronger. But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running. I run so that I can run more.
llm: Why run? I’ve been asked that question many times. Why not drive or walk? Well, the truth is, I could have walked to school but I chose to run. I wanted to be the fastest runner in my class and I wanted a pair of Air Jordan sneakers just like Mike. It was a goal. I set it and I achieved it. Running became something I loved to do, even though I didn’t love running at first. I had to learn to love it. My body has changed since then, and so have my goals. But one thing hasn’t changed: I still run.

human: Another year, another amazing album from Igor Levit. Like all this pianist’s recording projects, “Fantasia” is daringly yet elegantly programmed: Eight works from across some 200 years, with four meaty masterpieces each set alongside a smaller companion.
llm: Another year, another 365 days of classical music. To help you sort through the good stuff and the bad, we’ve compiled a list of five albums released in 2019 that will make great additions to your collection. From a new take on old favorites to fresh interpretations of contemporary works, these are albums sure to keep you entertained all year long.

human: The Supreme Court reiterated on Monday what it had said just two months ago: that the Biden administration may continue to regulate “ghost guns” — kits that can be bought online and assembled into untraceable homemade firearms — while appeals move forward.
llm: The Supreme Court of the United States has denied a request to review a 2016 ruling that upheld an Obama-era ban on homemade firearms, also known as “ghost guns.”

human: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Thursday, a day after a federal appeals court temporarily reversed an earlier ban on their import and sale in the United States.
llm: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Friday as the company works to satisfy a court order to pay $145 million in damages to a company that accused it of stealing hologram technology.

human: In September, at Prada’s spring 2024 women’s show, models walked between translucent curtains of pink slime that dripped from the ceiling and pooled on the floor. The brand referred to them as “fluid interruptions,” a concept that was echoed in the collection’s flowing organza dresses and fringed skirts. Above all, though, it evoked the secretions of a snail, an animal that has recently been crawling into the realms of design and fashion.
llm: In September, at a conference of some 100 designers in Paris, a group called Slow Fashion was created to promote eco-friendly clothing. The organization is made up of French brands such as Gaspard Yurkievich (who makes his clothes from organic cotton), La Compagnie de Provence and Maison Martin Margiela (who uses recycled polyester). “There’s no reason why fashion should be made with polluting materials,” says Yvonne Bournonville, one of its founding members. “It’s time for us to change.”

human: The Supreme Court is considering whether to take up the question of presidential immunity — that is, the idea that a president, by virtue of the unique nature of the office, is entitled to exceedingly broad protections from legal consequences for statements made and actions taken while in office. If the court takes up that question in a case regarding Donald Trump, it will have profound consequences for both the 2024 election and the bigger question of presidential power.
llm: The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments this week in a case that could dramatically shift the balance of power between Congress and the White House, setting new limits on presidential authority.

human: It’s the latest hot TV genre: a woman in a frigid outpost, bundled in puffy outerwear, trying to uncover truths buried in ice.
llm: It’s the latest from HBO.

human: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas. He was in the city for its inaugural Formula 1 race, which had drawn 315,000 visitors including Rihanna and Kylie Minogue.
llm: Around noon on Monday, February 26th, a small group of people gathered in an auditorium at Facebook headquarters in Menlo Park. The event was a meeting for the board of OpenAI, a nonprofit artificial intelligence research institute that is backed by some of Silicon Valley's most powerful players: Peter Thiel and Reid Hoffman, who cofounded PayPal; Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX; Y Combinator president Sam Altman; and Amazon founder Jeff Bezos.

human: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train. What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back. Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me. I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs. I just wanted to not look at a screen. I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human. A woman wearing a spiky hat. Shoelaces, untied. Shoelaces, tied. An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad. “Do Not Lean on Door.” Snoring. The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.
llm: After a long time, I'm writing this blog post. A few days back, I had an argument with my mom on WhatsApp (my mother is so tech-savvy that she uses WhatsApp even at the age of 75). She said that I should write more often and share what I have learned from life. But how do you describe or express what you have learned from your own experience? What words can we use to describe the miracle called life?

human: The New York Police Department detained 34 demonstrators at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade who were protesting Israel’s killings of civilians in Gaza, the authorities said on Friday.
llm: The New York Police Department arrested about 34 pro-Palestinian protesters on Thursday, as they were marching in the Thanksgiving Day parade to call for a boycott of Israeli products and to show support for Palestinians.

human: Even as Israeli tanks and ground troops continued to battle Hamas militants in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday outlined a postwar vision for the territory, one that he said would not involve the Palestinian Authority in its current form.
llm: Even as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has declared victory over Hamas, he is not ready to accept the idea of handing Gaza back to its Palestinian Authority leaders. ...

human: House Republicans on Friday demanded that Hunter Biden, the president’s son, sit for a closed-door deposition in their impeachment inquiry into his father, rejecting his request to testify only in public and suggesting he could face punishment if he did not agree to their terms.
llm: House Republicans on the Intelligence Committee said Thursday that they will move ahead with their planned deposition of Hunter Biden in coming days, even as Democrats said they were prepared to issue a subpoena for him if he did not appear voluntarily.

human: Several months ago, as a federal judge worked through a docket of smuggling cases in the bustling border city of Laredo, Texas, three people were escorted into the courtroom.
llm: Several months ago, I was approached by a friend who had just been released from prison. He is a member of a Muslim Sufi order (tariqah) that has been in conflict with the Saudi government for many years. The tariqah, led by Sheikh Hasan al-Banna, has been repeatedly banned by the government and its members jailed on charges ranging from apostasy to terrorism. My friend was among them, spending 40 days in jail before he was released without charge.

human: Inflation eased in October and price increases showed encouraging signs of slowing under the surface, according to fresh data released on Tuesday. The report provided the Federal Reserve with renewed evidence that its battle against rapid inflation is working — and likely reduced the need for further rate increases.
llm: Inflation eased in July, according to this morning's release from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The headline CPI came in at 0.2 percent, down from 0.3 percent in June and below market expectations of 0.3 percent. Excluding food and energy, core inflation rose by a tamer-than-expected 0.1 percent, compared with 0.2 percent in June. This was the slowest rate of growth since April 2015.

human: Responses from a survey of 603 voters in Arizona conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from Oct. 22 to Nov. 2, 2023.
llm: Responses from a random sample of Arizona voters. For results based on this sample of registered voters, the maximum margin of sampling error is ±3 percentage points at the 95 percent confidence level. The margin of sampling error for results based on the total sample of registered voters in each state may be higher and would vary depending on the state.

human: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7. In response to another lecturer’s message, she wrote that “the massacre,” referring to the actions of Hamas, reminded her of something the French philosopher and playwright Jean-Paul Sartre once wrote about race relations, adding a paraphrased quote: “‘After so many years that the neck of the occupied has been suffocating under your iron foot and suddenly was given a chance to raise his eyes, what kind of gaze did you expect you would see there?’ We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.
llm: On Oct. 25, The New York Times published an op-ed by Israeli academic Zeev Sternhell titled “Israel Is Silencing Internal Critics.” A former professor of political science at Hebrew University, Sternhell is a critic of Israel’s treatment of Palestinians and its settlement policy in the West Bank. He has also been a vocal supporter of boycotting Israel as a means to pressure it to end its occupation of the territories.

human: The Republican chairman of the bipartisan House Ethics Committee introduced a resolution on Friday to expel Representative George Santos of New York from Congress, citing the committee’s damning new report documenting violations of House rules and evidence of pervasive campaign fraud.
llm: The Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee is now saying that there was a “political agenda” behind former FBI Director James Comey’s decision to publicly announce his reopening of the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails.

human: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings. In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.
llm: Heavy rain and high winds lashed parts of New York, Pennsylvania and Maryland on Wednesday as a storm system swept across the eastern United States. The National Weather Service said more than 6 inches (15 cm) of rain had fallen in some areas of New York State, causing flash flooding that stranded motorists. In northern Baltimore County, Maryland, an 8-year-old boy was killed by lightning while he was standing in his family's front yard, according to the county sheriff's office. "We are not going to get out of this without any loss of life," Baltimore County Sheriff Jim Johnson told reporters at a news conference. He said there were also reports of trees falling on houses, cars stuck in water, and power

human: The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports by Amnesty International and The Washington Post that Israel used white phosphorus supplied by the United States in violation of international law.
llm: The Biden administration is concerned about the possible use by Israeli forces of American-supplied white phosphorous artillery shells in the Gaza Strip, a senior administration official said on Wednesday.

human: Can magic illuminate a life that was far from magical?
llm: Can magic illuminate the world? That’s the question at the heart of “The Vanishing Elephant,” a new show by the theatrical troupe Punchdrunk. As in its previous productions, the company has created an elaborate set on which it places a play that is meant to evoke the experience of theatergoing as it was in the late 19th century. But this time around, the play itself is about magic and magicians, and the show also incorporates a live performance from one of New York City’s most famous street performers. Together, these elements create an experience that feels like nothing so much as a fairy tale come true.

human: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall. Opportunities to acquire are everywhere, waiting either around the corner or at the end of a subway ride: exotic foods, knickknacks, records, books, medicine, tents, computers, sunglasses and everything else. It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.
llm: Walking through New York's Fifth Avenue at Christmas, one has to admit that it is a wonderfully festive experience. The stores are decorated beautifully and the windows are an artistic delight. But why would you want to be surrounded by people when you can shop from home? And if you prefer the human contact of shopping in person, then why not take advantage of the sales tax exemption for clothing and footwear purchases under $100. You can go to another state, buy some great clothes and come back with no tax liability.

human: Ivo Dimchev, a queer performance artist from Bulgaria whose brash charm has been known to compel people to take their clothes off and join him onstage — it happened at Joe’s Pub last month — has questions. And more questions.
llm: Ivo Dimchev, a Bulgarian born in Sofia and now based in Berlin, is an artist who defies easy categorization. He's a dancer (he studied at the P.A.R.T.S. dance school in Brussels), but he also sings, writes plays, directs, acts and more. His work has been described as everything from cabaret to theater, performance art to burlesque, and it's hard to disagree with any of that. But what makes Dimchev's work so distinctive, and what makes his appearance here at On The Boards so exciting, is its raw intensity. In works like "Bulgarian Folk Songs," Dimchev uses his voice in ways that are deeply expressive, almost operatic

human: As Israeli troops moved toward the border with Gaza before a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas, a U.N. official warned of a humanitarian “disaster” in the blockaded territory.
llm: As Israeli troops continue to bombard the Gaza Strip, killing at least 105 Palestinians since the start of their ground offensive on Saturday, the United Nations warned today that a full-scale humanitarian crisis is unfolding and urged Israel to allow more humanitarian aid into the area. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon called for an immediate ceasefire, warning that “without it, an already dire situation will only get worse.” Meanwhile, the Palestinian Authority is threatening to dismantle itself unless peace talks resume. For more on this, we’re joined by Amjad Atallah, senior fellow at the New America Foundation and editorial director of its Middle East Task Force. [includes rush trans

human: Neanderthals were morning people, a new study suggests. And some humans today who like getting up early might credit genes they inherited from their Neanderthal ancestors.
llm: Neanderthals were morning people, too.

human: A gritty crime thriller with a dreamlike tone and dense postmodern flourishes, the survival horror video game Alan Wake 2 is often weird and always unpredictable, veering off from its small-town murder-mystery setting to follow surreal and mind-bending digressions. It has few, if any, video game precedents.
llm: A gritty crime drama in the vein of The Killing?

human: Jeff Landry, the hard-line conservative leading the race for governor of Louisiana, surveyed the crowd packed into a small restaurant in Monroe, where his staff had covered the tables and a lone Halloween skeleton in his blue-and-yellow campaign merchandise.
llm: Jeff Landry, the state attorney general and a favorite of conservative activists, has emerged as the leader in the race to succeed Gov. Bobby Jindal, a Republican whose popularity is in free fall because of his relentless pursuit of tax cuts for businesses that have left the state with billions of dollars less than it needs to operate. Read more...

human: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse. He was a scurrier. As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted. His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor. Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
llm: When Michael Stipe was 23, he moved to Athens, Ga., from his hometown of Decatur, Ill., to join a band called R.E.M. He became an iconic musician, singer and songwriter for the band that is now in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. In April, R.E.M. played its final concert in New Orleans. Now, as Stipe approaches 50, he has released an album with a group called Dead Weather (featuring Jack White). The project is called "Treat Me Like Your Mother" and it's a departure from anything he's done before. On this week's podcast, we talk about how he wrote the lyrics to one of the songs, why he prefers

human: The prosecution of Brett Hankison, the former police detective who fired 10 bullets through Breonna Taylor’s apartment during a fatal 2020 raid in Louisville, Ky., ended in a mistrial on Thursday after the jury said it could not reach a unanimous verdict on federal civil rights charges.
llm: The prosecution of a white Cincinnati police officer accused in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black woman ended in a mistrial Wednesday after jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked.

human: If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog, Harry S. Truman supposedly once said. But what if the dog is not all that friendly?
llm: If you want to know the truth about Joe Biden's dog, just watch this video.

human: President Biden is trailing Donald J. Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 election, suffering from enormous doubts about his age and deep dissatisfaction over his handling of the economy and a host of other issues, new polls by The New York Times and Siena College have found.
llm: President Biden is a horrible idea.

human: Sidney K. Powell, who spun some of the wildest conspiracy theories about ballot fraud as a member of Donald J. Trump’s legal team after he lost the 2020 election, pleaded guilty on Thursday morning to six misdemeanor counts. She is one of 19 people, including Mr. Trump, who were indicted in August for trying to subvert the election results in Georgia, and she has agreed to testify against any of the remaining defendants.
llm: Sidney K. Powell, a well known conservative attorney and the author of Licensed to Lie: Exposing Corruption in the Department of Justice , has pled guilty to two misdemeanor charges for violating a protective order in a criminal case against President Donald J. Trump. The plea was entered today before Judge Steve C. Jones in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. She was immediately sentenced to 30 days of house arrest and will be on probation for one year.

human: The 2020 presidential campaign was underway, and Anthony Pratt was doubling down on Donald J. Trump.
llm: The 2020 presidential race is off to an early start. In the past week, former Vice President Joe Biden announced that he would not be running for office this year and Senator Bernie Sanders (I-VT) made his campaign official by announcing his intentions to run again in the upcoming Democratic primary election. With these announcements, candidates have begun to roll out their platforms as they vie for the Democratic nomination.

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.” In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.” And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, a young artist named Donald Judd moved to Marfa, Texas. He bought an old army base and turned it into his studio. Later he bought a neighboring lot and built a house on it. A few years later, when the house was completed, Judd found that it wasn't quite what he wanted. It had too many windows, not enough room for the artwork he wanted to display, and no dining table. So he started building one. He made it from a slab of concrete, poured in place, with recesses cut out for the legs. When finished, it stood two feet high, ten feet long, and sixteen feet wide. And it was perfect.

human: Former President Donald J. Trump’s rivals in the Republican race for president again lined up in his defense on Thursday after Maine barred him from its primary election ballot, the second state to do so.
llm: Former President Donald Trump's defense team said Friday that it is ready for his Senate impeachment trial, which is set to begin next week.

human: At the Taipei train station, a Chinese human rights activist named Cuicui watched with envy as six young Taiwanese politicians campaigned for the city’s legislative seats. A decade ago, they had been involved in parallel democratic protest movements — she in China, and the politicians on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait.
llm: At the Taipei Times, "China warns against Taiwan referendum on independence."

human: Residents as young as 16 have been granted the right to vote in school board elections in Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, beginning in April, after the City Council unanimously approved an ordinance Wednesday lowering the voting age.
llm: Residents as young as 16 can vote for school board candidates in Newark. (The New York Times)

human: Last week, a group of federal employees organized a protest of the Biden administration’s support of Israel in its war with Hamas. Although a snowstorm in Washington complicated their plans, some federal employees from a range of agencies declined to work for a day. Meanwhile at the Capitol, Republican members of the House of Representatives were once again threatening to throw their institution into chaos to prevent their leader from negotiating a spending package with Democrats.
llm: Last week, a new poll from The Washington Post and ABC News showed that the percentage of Americans who trust the federal government to do what is right all or most of the time has dropped from 74 percent in 2008 to just 19 percent today. As CBS News notes, this is the lowest level of faith in the government since Richard Nixon was president.

human: My first attempt at crunchy rice was not entirely on purpose. I was a young, multitasking cook with a pot of rice left on low heat until … wait, was something about to burn?
llm: My first attempt was to use a combination of the two recipes, but it didn't quite work. I used the rice recipe from the article as my starting point (adding in the chili powder and oregano) and then substituted the ingredients from the soup recipe. The problem with this approach is that the cooking times are very different: 35 minutes for the rice and 20 minutes for the soup. If you try to combine them, the rice will be overdone by the time the soup is done.

human: The first warning was a blip, a small anomaly picked up by radar scanning the skies over Ukraine. Within seconds, it became clear that the blip was a Russian ballistic missile streaking in Kyiv’s direction at several times the speed of sound.
llm: The first warning sign came from a civilian witness who saw a “huge explosion” in the sky above the Donetsk Airport. The next came from a Russian-backed separatist commander, who claimed that the blast was caused by an anti-aircraft missile fired by Ukrainian forces. Then the Russian news agency TASS reported that Ukrainian troops had launched an artillery attack on the airport. Finally, the separatists said they were forced to shut down their main base outside Luhansk because of heavy shelling from Ukrainian positions.

human: The White House on Wednesday condemned Representative Rashida Tlaib for embracing a phrase used by some pro-Palestinian groups, a day after the House censured her for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: The White House statement came in response to a comment made by Rep. Tlaib at an event over the weekend. She said, “There's always kind of a calming feeling I tell folks when I think of the Holocaust and the tragedy of the Holocaust and the fact that it was my ancestors — Palestinians — who lost their land and some lost their lives, their livelihood, their human dignity, their existence in many ways, have been wiped out.”

human: Taylor Swift holds the top of the Billboard 200 album chart with her latest remake, while Jung Kook of BTS opens at No. 2 and a posthumous release by Jimmy Buffett lands in the Top 10.
llm: Taylor Swift holds on to the top spot on the Billboard Artist 100 for a second week, as her re-recorded album “Lover” returns to No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart in its 46th week on the tally.

human: One of the strangest episodes in the history of the tech industry ended as start-up events often do: with a party in San Francisco’s eclectic Mission District.
llm: One of the most difficult things for a startup founder is to let go. And, when you're a founder with a high profile like Sam Altman, it can be even more difficult. But, he did it.

human: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.” Under stained-glass windows, they formed a circle, introducing themselves to a crowd of visitors as composers, rappers, painters and poets. Then they began to sing.
llm: One by one, the men filed out of their cells in the maximum-security wing of New York State's Sing Sing prison and walked into a cavernous room where 300 prisoners are housed.

human: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life. The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked. Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.
llm: I first heard Sleater-Kinney in 2005, when I was a teenager. It wasn’t a time of my life that was particularly easy for me. I had to move schools after the 9th grade and I struggled with depression. For the most part, I felt alienated from everything around me – people, places and ideas. The world seemed like a cold, bleak place. But then Carrie Brownstein appeared on my TV screen, and I saw her perform “Jumpers” live at an MTV awards show. She looked like she was having so much fun on stage, it made me want to be there too. And in that moment, something changed inside of me. I was no longer alone. This is the power of music

human: Isabella de la Houssaye, a lawyer and prolific endurance athlete who continued to go on daunting adventures around the world with her five children after being diagnosed with Stage 4 non-small-cell lung cancer, died on Saturday in Hermosa Beach, Calif. She was 59.
llm: Isabella de la Houssaye, Athlete Who Endured Against the Odds, Dies at 59

human: Over 50 actors, artists and other celebrities in France have issued a letter ardently defending Gérard Depardieu, the actor accused of sexual harassment and assault, calling him the victim of a “lynching” and arguing that he should be able to continue working despite a storm of criticism.
llm: Over 50 actors, directors and producers have defended Gerard Depardieu following allegations that he sexually assaulted a young actress.

human: Buying things in bulk at wholesale retailers can be an all-day affair. Sam’s Club, the store chain owned by Walmart, is trying to make that time shorter: by using artificial intelligence to scan shoppers’ carts so they no longer have to show a receipt at the exit upon checking out.
llm: Buying things in bulk is not always as cheap as it sounds. Often times it can actually be more expensive! This is why I do most of my shopping on Amazon. It's cheaper than Wal-Mart and Sam's Club and they deliver it to your door!

human: Despite the chockablock ballroom full of Hollywood’s best and brightest, a jovial emcee in the comedian John Mulaney and honorees the audience seemed thrilled to celebrate, a pall of sadness was cast over the Governors Awards — an event created 14 years ago by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to shorten the Oscar telecast by relegating the honorary Oscars to its own untelevised confab.
llm: Despite the chockablock schedule of the film-fest season, I’m happy to report that the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences held its annual Governors Awards ceremony on Saturday night at the Ray Dolby Ballroom in Hollywood. The event is always a warm, collegial affair, but this year it was particularly emotional for everyone involved—and that includes yours truly.

human: The political potency of abortion rights proved more powerful than the drag of President Biden’s approval ratings in Tuesday’s off-year elections, as Ohioans enshrined a right to abortion in their state’s constitution, and Democrats took control of both chambers of the Virginia General Assembly while holding on to Kentucky’s governorship.
llm: The political potency of the abortion issue has been a constant theme in this year's elections. The abortion-rights movement was hoping that support for reproductive rights would help lift vulnerable Democratic incumbents across the country. But, as the New York Times reports, "the issue proved to be more powerful than many expected." In races from Virginia to Maine, it seems like voters had little patience for politicians who didn't want to talk about their stance on abortion:

human: Three people, including a girl, were killed and three others were missing after a landslide struck homes in southeast Alaska this week, the authorities said.
llm: Three people, including a 9-year-old boy and his father, were killed Saturday after a landslide hit the town of Talkeetna in southern Alaska. The boy’s mother was hospitalized with injuries that are not life-threatening.

human: There are many reasons to be horrified about recent events in the Middle East, and the prospect that attacks on shipping might undermine progress against inflation is way, way down the list. Nonetheless, if you are trying to forecast inflation, disruption of a major choke point for global commerce — the Red Sea is how ships get to and from the Suez Canal — isn’t what you want to see. But how big a deal is it?
llm: There are many things in nature that do not seem to make sense. If you believe in evolution, then you would think that everything that exists is here by accident and is only here because it can survive long enough to reproduce itself. There is no real purpose or design involved. But if you take a step back and look at nature as a whole, there really does appear to be order and purpose. Take for example the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia. It was once thought to be millions of years old but now scientists have discovered that it could have been formed in less than 3000 years. Now how did this reef form? Well, after the flood the waters began to recede and sediment fell out of solution. These sediments were deposited on

human: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists. The account, @theAIDSmemorial, is an evolving testament, told in photographs, videos and user stories, to lives lost to a devastating and, it can occasionally seem, forgotten epidemic.
llm: Shining out from the darkness of the night, a pair of headlights shined on the highway in front of me. I watched as they moved up the road and slowly came to my car, illuminating me. In the dim glow, I could see my reflection in the window, which looked like it was covered with dirt.

human: Punctuating a year of major gains for organized labor, Microsoft has announced that it will stay neutral if any group of U.S.-based workers seeks to unionize.
llm: Punctuating a year of organizing at Microsoft, workers from the tech giant’s offices around the world voted overwhelmingly this week to unionize. The vote was 93 percent in favor of joining with Unite Here Local 11, which represents hospitality and service industry workers in Seattle.

human: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease. Almost two thirds of them are women — a discrepancy that researchers have long attributed to genetics and women’s longer life spans, among other reasons. But there is growing consensus that menopause may also be an important risk factor for the development of dementia later in life.
llm: Across the U.S., 6,000 women turn 51 every day. By age 70, three out of four women will have gone through menopause. During this phase of a woman’s life, her hormones shift and her body changes. But how do these hormonal shifts affect the brain? For one thing, they make it harder for older women to remember things – and not just because of their advancing years.

human: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out. But other times I begin looking into a topic and find a problem so massive that I can’t believe I’ve ever written about anything else. This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life. It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society. They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.
llm: Sometimes in this life we are blessed to have people who believe in us when we don’t even know how to believe in ourselves. I think about that all the time and it is such an honor to be able to do so.

human: Dave Chappelle waded briefly into the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week, drawing cheers from some audience members and causing others to walk out as he decried the humanitarian crisis unfolding at the Gaza Strip, according to news reports and a spokeswoman for the comedian.
llm: Dave Chappelle waded into the Middle East conflict by telling a crowd at a Boston comedy club that he supports Palestinians, drawing cheers from some audience members but prompting others to walk out. The comedian made his comments Thursday during an appearance at the Laugh Factory in Copley Square. “I’m going to go way out on a limb here,” he told the crowd, according to the Boston Herald. “I think Israel is run by crazy people.”

human: Once upon a time, there was a princess in Denmark who aspired to become an artist.
llm: Once upon a time, there was this really cute girl who had the best job in the world: working at a horror movie streaming service. She worked her butt off and loved every minute of it. But one day, she woke up to discover that her bosses were evil and wanted to make her do things she didn't want to do. So she quit her job, got a new one at an awesome company, and everything was great again. Until she discovered that all of her coworkers were actually ghosts! And they didn't just work for a horror movie streaming service...they were also ghostly spirits of people who died on their jobs! It's like the ultimate horror movie, but she doesn't know how to escape from it. Will she ever

human: Nikki Haley on Saturday blasted Donald J. Trump’s dishonesty and his relationships with “dictators,” questioned his mental acuity and dismissed his mounting stack of endorsements, sharpening her attacks on him as she headed into the final two days of New Hampshire campaigning.
llm: Follow for live updates from NBC News' campaign embeds in New Hampshire: @mkraju and @david_lauter.

human: When Meg Bellamy got the call that would change her life — the one telling her that after months of auditions, it was she, among thousands of hopefuls, who would play Kate Middleton in the final season of “The Crown” — she was already standing in the shadow of Windsor Castle. But she wasn’t looking the part of a royal just yet.
llm: When Meg Bellamy, who plays Princess Margaret on Netflix's The Crown, was asked to audition for the role of a young Queen Elizabeth II, she had no idea what she was getting into.

human: Ukraine scored a major success on Tuesday when it struck a Russian warship at port in Crimea, one of the most significant attacks against Moscow’s Black Sea Fleet in months. But in another setback for their ground campaign, Ukrainian officials acknowledged that they had all but retreated from the eastern city of Marinka after a monthslong battle to defend it.
llm: Ukraine scored a major victory on Tuesday by downing one of Russia’s prized warships and killing 14 sailors. But it has failed to stem the advance of pro-Russian separatists into the east, losing ground around several key towns that are vital for controlling its industrial heartland, including Donetsk. The two sides also traded blame over the attack on the Ukrainian military vessel, with each side accusing the other of lying about what happened. On Wednesday, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he had ordered his country’s military to begin exercises in the Black Sea region, in an apparent show of force in response to the Ukrainian naval attack. Ukraine's acting president, Oleksandr V. T

human: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level. She has been anti-abortion my entire life. We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year. When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral. She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret). I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially. Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren. I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her. But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices. What do I owe her?— Name Withheld
llm: My mother and I have always been close. We talk on the phone every day, and when she comes to visit me in New York City, we spend hours just walking around town. I’m her only child, and I’ve always felt that my mom has a unique perspective about being a parent because of it.

human: Taiwan’s defense ministry issued an urgent alert Tuesday about a Chinese satellite launched on a rocket flying over the island, an alarming message that interrupted the final days of campaigning before a major election and spurred accusations of a political ploy.
llm: Taiwan’s defense ministry said it was notified of the rocket launch at 10:35 p.m. Wednesday and that the military had dispatched fighter jets to track its flight path.

human: Almost everyone on the stage outside San Francisco’s City Hall on Thursday afternoon was a woman: the vice president, the former speaker of the House, the city’s mayor and more.
llm: Almost everyone on both sides of the political spectrum, left and right, are praising Sen. Dianne Feinstein for her years of public service as she prepares to retire from the U.S. Senate after more than 25 years in office.

human: New York Times journalists have received many honors. But recognition by way of U.S. postage stamps has proved elusive. It seems that only two people closely associated with The Times have been the subjects of commemorative stamps.
llm: New York Times, March 27, 1906.

human: One of the art world’s top magazine editors was fired Thursday night after the publishers of Artforum said that the staff’s decision to post an open letter about the Israel-Hamas war failed to meet the organization’s standards.
llm: One of the most disgusting things about this is that he was not fired for his own views, but because other people disagree with him. This is so completely opposite from what a magazine should be, and it's a sad commentary on our culture today that the publisher thought it necessary to fire someone over their political views.

human: By striking Houthi rebel targets in Yemen with Britain on Thursday, Washington sent a searing message to both the Houthis and its Iranian backers that the United States has ended its longstanding defense-only posture in the Red Sea and is determined to stop the group’s attacks against commercial ships in regional waters.
llm: By striking Houthi rebels in Yemen, the United States is sending a strong signal that it will not tolerate attacks on commercial vessels. But there are also potential pitfalls to the American action.

human: Bob Iger, the chief executive of Disney, said the company is constantly evaluating its assets and their value.

human: “Everyone likes an underdog, and we had underdogs in spades.”
llm: “Everyone likes an underdog, and it doesn't get much more underdog than the British post office. In 2011, with a new prime minister in power, the government announced plans to sell off most of its 500-year-old postal monopoly. It was the latest of many such schemes by successive governments since the late 1980s.”

human: Workers can be barred from wearing religious garb, such as head scarves, in the offices of public administrations, a European Union court ruled on Tuesday, tapping into a charged debate in Europe about expressions of faith in public institutions.
llm: Workers can be banned from wearing religious symbols at work under European Union rules, the European Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday. The ruling upholds a Belgian court’s decision to dismiss an employee who insisted that she could wear her crucifix necklace while working as a receptionist for the Belgian justice department.

human: Matthew Perry’s fellow “Friends” cast members expressed their grief and sadness about his death in a joint statement to People magazine on Monday.
llm: Matthew Perry’s fellow “Friends” cast members have reacted to the news of his hospitalization. The actor, 49, was admitted for three months of treatment on August 30. His rep told People magazine he is being treated for a condition related to alcohol addiction. Perry, who has been open about his struggles with sobriety, was reportedly released from the hospital last week but is still receiving outpatient care. He will be staying at a sober-living facility in Los Angeles for an undisclosed amount of time.

human: Over the two weeks that dozens of Indian construction workers have been trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the authorities have reported meter-by-meter progress toward reaching them and offered hopeful timelines for their rescue. Each time a breakthrough has appeared imminent, politicians have rushed to the scene.
llm: Over the two weeks that followed, Mr. O'Neill, 26, and the others survived on rainwater and whatever food they could find — fruit, berries, insects, mice.

human: It was a relief to learn of the arrest last week of a 21-year-old Cornell University student for threatening to rape and murder Jews on campus in reaction to the Israel-Hamas war. It was also an easy case: Violent threats against specific people are illegal, and they are dealt with by the justice system, not school administrators.
llm: It was a very interesting discussion. I am still digesting it, but wanted to share the link with you here:

human: David Gail, who played Dr. Joe Scanlon on the ABC soap opera “Port Charles” and appeared on “Beverly Hills, 90210,”  died on Tuesday. He was 58.

human: Material from a binder with highly classified information connected to the investigation into Russian efforts to meddle in the 2016 election disappeared in the final days of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, two people familiar with the matter said.
llm: Material from a top-secret investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election disappeared from the White House hours after Donald Trump left office, according to officials familiar with the incident.

human: Hamas released 10 Israeli hostages and two Thai nationals on Tuesday as the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas continued into a fifth day, raising the total number of captives released to 85. Roughly 240 hostages were captured on Oct. 7, when Hamas led devastating raids into Israel and killed about 1,200 people, according to the Israeli authorities.
llm: Hamas released 102 prisoners in exchange for Shalit, the Israeli soldier kidnapped by Hamas operatives from inside Israel in June 2006 and held ever since. Palestinian terrorists captured Gilad Shalit when they raided an IDF post along the border with Gaza and killed two soldiers. A third was badly wounded but survived.

human: Danuta Klimas, an office cleaner, went back to work in Lower Manhattan days after the Sept. 11 attacks, as toxic dust from ground zero hung in the air. She was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer years later.
llm: Danuta Klimas, an organizer with the union's campaign to win higher wages for private-sector janitors, said the workers were on strike to secure a $25-an-hour minimum wage and affordable health care.

human: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Dr. Monica M. Bertagnolli, a cancer surgeon who currently leads the National Cancer Institute, as the next director of the National Institutes of Health, overriding the objections of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, the chairman of the Senate health committee.
llm: The Senate on Thursday confirmed Dr. Francis S. Collins, a physician-geneticist and the director of the National Human Genome Research Institute at the National Institutes of Health, as the agency’s new leader over the objection of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. The vote was 79 to 18.

human: In the year since OpenAI sparked an artificial intelligence boom with its popular ChatGPT chatbot, start-ups and tech giants have been scrambling to develop semiconductors to power the buzzy technology, hoping to muscle in on Nvidia’s market dominance.
llm: In the year since we launched the NVIDIA DGX-1, the world’s first deep learning supercomputer, it has become an industry standard for training and inference in artificial intelligence (A.I.).

human: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history. The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.
llm: “Inspector Sun,” a 1968 film directed by Yang Beibei, has been digitally restored and is now available on DVD. (The film was released in the United States under the title “A Chinese Tragedy.”) It is a must-see for anyone interested in cinema history — or just in good movies....

llm: Chris Christie had some tough words for state Assemblyman Raj Mukherji, D-Hudson, who criticized the governor's handling of Hurricane Sandy.
