human: This is Day 3 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.
llm: This is Day 3 of a 10-day series on how to eat for better energy. Yesterday, I talked about the importance of protein and today's post focuses on carbohydrates. Carbs are your body's primary source of fuel so it's important that you get enough every day. Here are some quick tips on how to get them into your diet without overdoing it.

human: On Oct. 26, the Department of Commerce announced that gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter. This growth rate ran well above even optimistic forecasts, leading to what can only be called triumphalism from a White House dead set on making Bidenomics a key to its 2024 presidential campaign. President Biden issued a self-congratulatory statement, and the White House echoed it over and over — and Donald Trump’s relative popularity increased.
llm: On Oct. 26, 1983, President Ronald Reagan was shot in an assassination attempt by John Hinckley Jr. The wound was serious enough to require surgery, but the president survived. His press secretary at the time, Larry Speakes, said: “The doctors feel that the president should recover fully.” But he did not.

human: A Minnesota doctor who the authorities said had worked as a poison specialist was arrested on Friday and charged in the death of his wife, Betty Bowman, who died in August from poisoning.
llm: A Minnesota doctor who specialized in treating poisoning has been accused of murdering his wife. The complaint says Dr. Terrance Lee was arrested on Thursday after he allegedly admitted to killing his wife with a drug overdose.

human: David Chang is “pausing operations” at Momofuku Ko next week, according to a post on his company’s Instagram account. It goes on: “we won’t call this a goodbye, but ko will no longer operate in the way it has.”
llm: David Chang is opening a new restaurant in New York City.

human: Which activities do you look forward to during the holiday season? Putting up decorations? Watching movies? Building gingerbread houses?
llm: Which activities do you engage in to get into the holiday spirit?

human: President Emmanuel Macron of France this week condemned what he called a “manhunt” targeting Gérard Depardieu, the embattled French actor whose worldwide fame has been tarnished in recent years by allegations of sexual harassment and assault.
llm: President Emmanuel Macron has condemned a “manhunt” against the French actor Gérard Depardieu, after the former Hollywood star was accused of tax evasion.

human: Tens of thousands of women who are not pregnant are ordering abortion pills just in case they might need them someday, especially in states where access is threatened, according to a study published on Tuesday.
llm: Tens of thousands of women are ordering abortion pills online without a prescription — and many aren’t even pregnant, a new study suggests.

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food. As a child, he relished a good Big Mac, a box of chicken nuggets and a cold, refreshing Sprite. But after moving to the East Coast for college, Rivera’s socioeconomic circles began shifting, as well as his worldview around food. In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
llm: Growing up in the 1970s, we had no idea that our parents' love of KFC could be considered anything but normal. In fact, it was a rite of passage to have your first bite of fried chicken at the tender age of two (or three or four). We would watch Mom and Dad gleefully tear into their buckets of greasy goodness, and beg them for a taste. "Chicken is bad for you," they would warn us, while shoveling it into their mouths with reckless abandon. And yet they still bought more, and more, and more. It became clear that this food was not only addictive, but also necessary to the well-being of our entire family.

human: LONDON — The British Government will continue to make protests to Washington in all cases of seizures of suspected rum-runners outside of the three-mile limit until the reciprocal rum treaty is ratified by the two countries, the correspondent of The New York Herald was informed today at the Foreign Office.
llm: LONDON — The government's action in seizing the two American rum ships, the Biscayne and the Delaware, was discussed by the House of Commons. Mr. Lloyd George spoke against the action as being a blow at the British Empire. He said that if the United States should take similar measures, Great Britain would be obliged to follow suit.

human: Metro Bank, an upstart British lender, said on Sunday that it has raised 325 million pounds, or $395 million, in new capital to help ease regulators’ worries about its financial health.
llm: Metro Bank, an upstart British lender that has struggled with mounting losses and regulatory scrutiny over its finances, announced on Monday that it had raised $403 million from investors as part of a rescue plan intended to shore up its capital.

human: An off-duty pilot who was in a jump seat in the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines flight on Sunday was charged with more than 80 counts of attempted murder after he tried to cut fuel to the engines, prompting the plane to divert to Portland, Ore., the authorities said.
llm: An off-duty pilot was arrested Monday after he allegedly tried to cut the engines on an Alaska Airlines plane that was taxiing at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, according to a news release from the Port of Seattle.

human: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween. The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon. Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be. It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
llm: A couple of days ago, I was talking to a friend who has been in the business world for many years. He said that he used to be an expert on China but now he is no longer up-to-date and not confident enough to talk about it anymore. His experience reminded me of my own: I had studied Chinese history at university and spent six years as a journalist covering Beijing and China. But now I am also not confident enough to speak on behalf of China.

human: Krayzie Bone, a member of Bone Thugs-N-Harmony, one of the most influential rap groups in history, has been fighting for his life for several days, he said in a post on social media on Monday that included a photo of him in a hospital.
llm: Krayzie Bone, a member of the iconic group Bone Thugs-n-Harmony, posted on social media about his health scare.

human: It was one of New York City’s most enduring crises: For decades, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had warned that it was teetering on the brink of financial ruin.
llm: It was one of many stories about the MTA's budget that I wrote in 2014 and 2015, as the agency faced a $1.2 billion deficit, service cuts, fare hikes and more. The problem was this: the MTA kept spending money on projects like East Side Access, which would deliver service to Grand Central Terminal from Long Island, and Second Avenue Subway, a line that had been discussed for decades.

human: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, who, behind the geopolitical scenes, played a leading role in coordinating U.S.-Soviet relations during the last decade of the Cold War, and who later oversaw the destruction of hundreds of nuclear weapons belonging to the former Soviet republics, died on Oct. 28 in Manchester, N.H. He was 87.
llm: Maj. Gen. Roland G. LaJoie was a great American, and an extraordinary soldier and leader. He will be missed by all who knew him. May he rest in peace.

human: Downstairs at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, about 20 miles north of Copenhagen, a woman is urinating on President Vladimir V. Putin. Balanced on a table above a black-and-white portrait of the Russian leader, her blonde hair and face shrouded in a bright-red balaclava, she hitches up her loose dress and answers nature’s call, drenching the photograph before kicking it to the ground.
llm: Downstairs at the Royal Court Theatre on Friday 18 October, join the RSC for a night of activism, solidarity and song. The evening will be hosted by Samira Ahmed (BBC Newsnight) with live music from Eska and DJs including Gilles Peterson, Hattie Collins, Shanti Celeste and more. Plus an introduction to Pussy Riot from Nadya Tolokonnikova herself!

human: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.
llm: In the era of Trump, many Americans are looking back with nostalgia to a time when we were not divided. They’re remembering an America that existed in their youth—and never was.

human: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling. My imagination was captivated by this town nestled in the foothills of the Himalayas in the Indian state of West Bengal. Surrounded by lush, terraced tea gardens that extend across rolling hills, with the majestic snow-capped mountains behind them, Darjeeling is one of India’s most stunning hill stations, known as the Queen of the Mountains.
llm: Ever since I’ve been to India (and even before), there are many things that have intrigued me about this country. One such thing is the way they enjoy their tea. In every part of the world, you will find people with their favourite beverage but in India, it goes beyond just the taste and into the ritual as well. A cup of tea is prepared in different ways across the regions of India and each time, it has its own unique flavour. But what makes it more special than anywhere else is the fact that it is always accompanied by a small snack or something sweet. And the most common accompaniment to tea is the samosa, which can be either fried or baked.

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in. The Horn has been much in the news this fall, as it survived a threat of demolition.
llm: On May 20, 1937, the New York Times ran a story that would change the art world forever.

human: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.
llm: “Everything needed for the war is being produced in Russia.” That was the conclusion of Sergei Zhuravlev, a former deputy minister of defense and current president of the Russian Academy of Geopolitical Problems. And that means that Russia’s economy has become dependent on the continuation of its war with Ukraine.

human: She flirted with Brando and even Prince Charles. She has been romantically linked with a succession of Hollywood hunks — think Warren Beatty and Ryan O’Neal.
llm: She flirted with the idea of being a fashion designer.

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut. Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes. Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert. It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized. In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner. A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project. “I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said. The flavor and filling combinations are endless. For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt. He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving. He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks away from Dominique Ansel's bakery is The Meatball Shop, where you can order "meatballs and beer," "meatballs and wine" or even "a meatball sandwich." (It does not serve pastries.)

human: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today. Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously. Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it. No one can confidently say who knew what when.
llm: It will be interesting to see what happens when the “war” is over and those who fought it have become “normalized.” Will they return home and blend back into society? Or will their experiences continue to shape them in ways that make them stand out from other members of the generation, or even from others within their own families? And will the rest of us be able to recognize these differences or simply assume that everyone has gone through this experience?

human: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood. “Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register. Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.” Wait, what? The staff whoops. Someone says, “No way!” He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries. Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!” The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea. For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide. Then I say, “Good night.” — Zoe Marie Bel
llm: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood, CA, US

human: For this landmark biography, Tick, a music historian, leans on a rich trove of archival research — in particular, articles from recently digitized Black newspapers — as well as new material from Fitzgerald’s family, including a scrapbook the jazz legend kept when she was 18.
llm: For this landmark work, a Pulitzer Prize–winning journalist has drawn on a trove of newly released FBI files to present the most authoritative account yet of the bureau’s secret involvement in the civil rights struggle. Read more...

human: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34). He’s speaking on a bleak afternoonomg in one of the bleakest places in Poland, the Warsaw ghetto in December 1940. Those he will secretly assemble in the upstairs room of a library are intent on preserving the biographies of at least some of the hundreds of thousands of Jews imprisoned by the Nazis in three square kilometers of the city.
llm: “It is up to you to read between the lines and figure out what you are going to do. The story does not tell you.” —Nobuko Takagi, in conversation with J-Lit Book Club

human: Qatar is engaged in high-level discussions with Hamas to deliver vital prescription medicines to Israeli hostages in the Gaza Strip at the same time it is making progress with Israel about allowing more medicine into the enclave for Gazan civilians, officials said.
llm: Qatar is engaged in a delicate negotiation with the militant group Hamas, brokering an exchange of Israeli soldiers for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel. Qatari officials are working with representatives from Egypt and Turkey as well as Hamas, trying to secure the release of 19-year-old Gilad Shalit, who was captured by Hamas gunmen on June 25. In return, they hope to win the release of hundreds of Palestinians being held in Israeli jails. One major sticking point is the fate of two high-profile prisoners, Ahmad Sa'adat and Abdel Rahim Malouh, both leaders of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), a Marxist faction

human: Young women from across genres — along with the Recording Academy’s favorite polymath spoiler Jon Batiste — reigned atop the nominations on Friday for the 66th annual Grammy Awards, to be held Feb. 4 in Los Angeles.
llm: Young women from the US and Canada united as a trio in 2018. They are Lucy Dacus (from Virginia), Phoebe Bridgers (California) and Julien Baker (Tennessee). This is their first album. It has been nominated for Best Alternative Music Album at this year’s Grammys. The three singers have all won acclaim for their solo albums – Ms Bridgers was nominated for a Grammy last year.

human: The final game of the playoff series between the Houston Astros and the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday lasted only two hours and 38 minutes. It was a crisply played game — which the Astros won, 3-2 — that highlighted Major League Baseball’s biggest accomplishment this season. Thanks to a 15-second clock that prevents players from dawdling between pitches, the average game lasted just two hours and 40 minutes this season, down a remarkable 24 minutes from last season.
llm: The final game of the series in New York is this afternoon. The Yankees and the Mets are playing at 1:05 p.m. ET, and you can watch it on Fox Sports 1 (FS1).

human: We ask that no spoilers be posted in the comments. If you would like to discuss the Super Mega and reach out for help, please join our Super Mega Support Group. Spoilers and strategies are appreciated there!
llm: We ask that you bring your own pencils, erasers and snacks. If you have a crossword dictionary or app, please feel free to bring it along. You can also buy them on the day of the event.

human: There’s big news this week for tiny warriors.
llm: There’s big news today for Warhammer fans. The tabletop and video game franchise is getting a TV adaptation from Legendary Entertainment, who has also signed on Henry Cavill as one of its executive producers.

human: A highly lethal form of bird flu that has been spreading across the world has now been detected in a dead polar bear in Alaska. It is the first known case in the Arctic animals, which are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.
llm: A highly lethal bird flu strain has been detected for the first time in wild polar bears, scientists say.

human: Thousands of readers reacted to the articles in the Dying Broke series about the financial burden of long-term care in the United States. They offered their assessments for the government and market failures that have drained the lifetime savings of so many American families. And some offered possible solutions.
llm: Thousands of readers have shared their stories about caring for aging parents or paying for long-term care. Here are some of those stories.

human: Filoli, a grand house and garden on 654 acres of rolling green grounds near the California coast, has been a supporting character in the 1980s television drama “Dynasty” and the 2001 romantic comedy “The Wedding Planner.” It has been the venue for top-dollar nuptials of Facebook executives, and the public can tour the gardens.
llm: Filoli, a grand country estate in Woodside, California, was the setting last weekend for two weddings: one by an American tech billionaire to his Chinese bride, the other by the son of a vice president of the United States.

human: Last week, I asked you to submit a song that feels like fall. So many of you responded with such evocatively autumnal suggestions that it became quite a daunting task to whittle them down to a relatively compact and cohesive listening experience — but I somehow managed, and I have that playlist for you today.
llm: Last week, I asked you to vote on the best songs of fall. This is not my list; it's your list! And that means it's a pretty awesome list.

human: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together. What a good antidote to despair that was. Much of it was rereading, but I’d missed some stories and novels, and I’d never read them sequentially or with a clear sense of Cather’s life. That spring I also delved into several of the biographies, which taught me something about how such books can vary.
llm: During the difficult early years of her writing career, Willa Cather wrote a number of articles for The Home Monthly. A series of articles published in 1903 were later compiled into a book titled “Willa Cather on Writing.” It was not until many years later that I became familiar with this work.

human: Jeff Landry, the Louisiana attorney general and a hard-line conservative, trounced a crowded field of candidates on Saturday to become the state’s next governor, cementing Republican control of Louisiana after eight years of divided government.
llm: Jeff Landry, the hard-line conservative who has served as attorney general for the past four years, won election Tuesday night to become Louisiana's next governor. He will replace Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat who was re-elected last year but is prohibited by term limits from seeking a third term in 2019. Mr. Landry, 57, defeated two other Republicans in an open primary, including the state treasurer, John Schroder, and a former lawmaker, Scott Angelle. The vote was close: Mr. Landry received about 46 percent of the vote, while Mr. Schroder received 39 percent and Mr. Angelle received 15 percent. In his victory speech at a hotel ball

human: You didn’t have to be a financial wizard to get a safe return of more than 7 percent on your money for decades to come. All you had to do was buy a 30-year U.S. Treasury bond in the last nine months of 1994.
llm: You didn’t have to be a market expert to understand that last week’s 30-year bond auction was going to be ugly. The U.S. had just sold $25 billion of debt at record low yields, and there were still buyers out there willing to take it off their hands.

human: Pee-wee Herman’s toys, Robert Gottlieb’s plastic handbags and other unexpected treasures.
llm: Pee-wee Herman’s toys, John Lennon's handwritten lyrics and a letter from Frida Kahlo to Diego Rivera are just some of the items in the collections that will be up for auction.

human: After winning major gains in wages and benefits from two of the three Detroit automakers, the United Automobile Workers union is looking beyond the Motor City to car companies operating nonunion factories across the South.
llm: After winning major contracts with the Big Three, the United Automobile Workers is expanding its organizing efforts beyond unionized auto plants. The UAW has set a goal of unionizing nonunion auto manufacturers by 2015, according to The New York Times.

human: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family. But when she tore open the wrapping on his gift for her, she was disheartened to discover what lay inside: a car-window scraper. Sure, she lived in a frosty place, but she didn’t own a car. Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.
llm: On Christmas Eve, when I was a child, my parents would read to us from Luke's account of Jesus' birth. We would sit on the floor in our living room with all the lights off and listen as they told us how Mary and Joseph traveled to Bethlehem so that their firstborn son could be registered for taxation. How an innkeeper let them stay because there were no other rooms available. How shepherds, who were tending their flocks outside Bethlehem, were visited by angels announcing the birth of a Savior. And we would hear about wise men who saw a star and followed it to Jerusalem where they were told the King of Kings had been born.

human: Celebrities streamed onto the lush red carpet to pose in front of the floral backdrop for the Golden Globes on Sunday night as the awards ceremony made a return to television (it wasn’t broadcast in 2022, and was moved to a Tuesday evening last year).
llm: Celebrities streamed onto the red carpet for the 76th annual Golden Globe Awards at the Beverly Hilton in Los Angeles on Sunday, January 5. See photos from the 2020 ceremony here.

human: Is there something you have read, watched, listened to, eaten, visited, played or otherwise experienced this year that you think is so bad that you want to discourage others from experiencing it? If so, what and why?
llm: Is there something you'd like to see us cover? Let us know!

human: By Canadian standards, the 10.4 billion Canadian dollar military purchase announced this week moved at light speed, possibly within as little as nine months.
llm: By Canadian standards, it's a very large number indeed. So large that some observers are questioning whether Canada can afford to buy the equipment it has in mind for its military forces over the next few years. This past weekend, the Canadian government announced it was looking at buying new fighter jets and other military hardware worth more than $10 billion dollars, including:

human: Less than 24 hours after condemning terrorism in the Middle East in one of the most powerful speeches of his tenure on Tuesday, President Biden was back before television cameras for another statement.
llm: Less than 24 hours after a powerful bomb killed 16 people in Baghdad and sent the Iraqi capital into chaos, Vice President Joe Biden said the U.S. will not abandon its efforts to bring stability to the country.

human: My wife became pregnant soon after we met, when our relationship was “fluid” and non-monogamous. We agreed to raise the child together and, at my urging, to have an open relationship. However, our relationship since has been monogamous. My wife was injured during the birth of our second child and now finds sex painful and avoids it. (We had a terrific sex life before the injury.) When I broached the topic of having other partners and reminded her of our agreement to have an open relationship, she became irritated and said that having kids changed things. Subsequent discussions resulted in a stalemate.
llm: My wife became very upset when I told her about my past infidelity. She said she can't forgive me and wants a divorce. However, she said we could have an open relationship if that would help ease the pain. Now I'm starting to wonder how serious she was about it, especially after reading your column on "How Do I Get My Girlfriend Into BDSM?", in which you mentioned that one of the rules of such relationships is "no cheating." Shouldn't the same rule apply to open marriages as well? Or are they different? What should I do? —Wondering If I Can Trust Her

human: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead. The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
llm: The ruins of Monte Alban, in Mexico's Oaxaca state. (Photo: Wikimedia Commons)

human: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet someone who can laugh at Dracula because he’s like family. We’ll also find out why grade inflation has become an issue at Yale University.
llm: Good morning. It’s always interesting to learn about the creative process behind a film, and I enjoyed your interview with writer/director Gary Sherman about his upcoming “Dracula” project.

human: For the two days after a gunman killed 18 people and injured 13 in Lewiston, Maine, Patrick Hynes and other residents in the area sat in their own homes, under a shelter-in-place order, facing their grief, their rage, in isolation.
llm: For the two weeks of the lockdown in November 2018, there were no school buses on the roads. There was no one on Main Street after dark. It felt like the world had been turned upside down. And then, as suddenly as it started, the state-mandated lockdown was over. A year later, the community is still struggling with its impacts and grappling with how to move forward. On this episode, we speak with Katie Greenleaf, a professor at Bates College who wrote an essay for the Sun Journal about what happened in Lewiston during the lockdown. She joins us in our studio to talk about the experience, along with Lewiston High School Principal Ben Ashby.

human: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning. The Israelis spoke in whispers as they pleaded desperately for help.
llm: Israeli citizens, barricaded in shelters or fleeing their homes en masse as the rocket fire continued to rain down on Tuesday, had only begun to digest the details of an attack that appeared to come out of nowhere. No one seemed to know where it would end. The deaths were mounting fast. “This is insane,” said Avigdor Liberman, a former defense minister who is the leader of the opposition Yisrael Beiteinu party. “There’s no other word for it.”

human: “Put on your masks!”
llm: “Put on your thinking caps and join us for a discussion of the challenges faced by public health as we move into the 21st century. What do we need to be doing differently? How can we make sure that our work is relevant, impactful, and sustainable in the future?”

human: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip have grown so dire that the U.N. agency that has helped feed, school and shelter Palestinians there for decades said Wednesday that it might have to start shutting down operations.
llm: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip are affecting food supplies and the work of aid groups there, according to a report in The New York Times on Thursday.

human: The Safdie brothers, the filmmaking duo behind “Uncut Gems” (2019) and “Good Time” (2017), are splitting up.
llm: The Safdie brothers, Josh and Benny, are a duo that have been making some noise in the independent film scene. Their films Uncut Gems and Good Time have been praised by critics and audiences alike. But now it seems their partnership is over. According to The Hollywood Reporter, they are done working together as directors. They say: “Josh and Benny Safdie have decided to go their separate ways creatively, and will not be continuing to make movies together.” It’s unclear what this means for them professionally going forward, but we do know that they’ve split before.

human: Maine’s top election official said on Friday she intended to appeal the ruling by a state Superior Court judge this week that placed on hold her decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s Republican primary ballot.
llm: Maine’s top election official will appeal a ruling by the state supreme court that ordered her to let President Donald Trump appear on the ballot for next month’s presidential primary.

human: The fate of the sons of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of being the mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, has long been a source of mystery and controversy.
llm: The fate of the sons of one of the suspects in the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks is shrouded in mystery.

human: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her calls this week for the U.S. government to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, after some users, weighing in on the war between Israel and Hamas, promoted “Letter to America,” a text written by Osama bin Laden after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

human: When a jury of military officers is assembled this week at Guantánamo Bay, it will be asked to choose a sentence in the 20- to 25-year range for two Malaysian prisoners who admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.
llm: When a jury finds the defendant guilty of the crime charged, and the court imposes a sentence within the range set by statute, the defendant has no right to appeal. This is true even if the judge has erred in instructing the jury on the law.

human: A prominent cancer center affiliated with Harvard said it will ask medical journals to retract six research papers and correct dozens of others after a British scientist and blogger found that work by some of its top executives was rife with duplicated or manipulated data.
llm: A prominent cancer research center has asked the journals that published its studies to retract them, citing problems with some of the data. The request by Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, one of the nation’s top medical institutions, is unprecedented among major research centers. In a statement, it said that 47 of its studies had been compromised by data errors, and that it was working with the journals involved to correct the papers or have them retracted. The move came as the National Institutes of Health announced an investigation into how the institution handled research grants and funding. Dr. Thomas J. Lynch Jr., director of the cancer center, acknowledged that the errors were serious. But he said that none of

human: “I was delighted to learn from this charming song all about the qualities, habits and foibles of the unicorn, or ‘monoceron,’” a character says near the start of “The Hunt,” Kate Soper’s latest work of music theater.
llm: “I was delighted to see this production. It was a very good idea for The Hunt to be performed in the middle of the woods, with only natural lighting. This was a perfect setting and I was able to relax in my seat as if I were at home watching a movie on Netflix.” – Kyle Smith, Audience Member

human: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter yesterday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
llm: The future of OpenAI, the artificial intelligence research group created by Elon Musk and Sam Altman, is uncertain. In a statement posted on its website yesterday, OpenAI said it will “pause” some of its efforts while it focuses on AI safety and working with the US government to make sure that its technology doesn’t fall into the wrong hands. The non-profit had planned to launch an online videogame platform later this year. Read more on Wired.

human: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who is currently serving a 19-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, missed another court date on Monday as his allies expressed concern at not having heard from him for more than five days.
llm: Aleksei A. Navalny, the anticorruption activist and opposition leader who has been under house arrest for more than a month, failed to show up in court on Wednesday morning, raising alarm among his supporters and renewing speculation about whether he would be jailed or released before the trial of another prominent activist begins this week. Mr. Navalny’s lawyers said that they had not heard from him since Tuesday night, when he called them to say that he was ready to appear in court. But on Wednesday morning, as his lawyers and other supporters were waiting outside the courthouse in Moscow, he did not emerge.

human: We’re living through an era of collapsing paradigms. The conceptual frames that many people use to organize their understanding of the world are crashing and burning upon contact with Middle Eastern reality.
llm: We’re living through a moment when, as Michael Hudson says, “the United States is trying to impose its will on the world and, if that doesn’t work, it’s going to blow up the planet.” To understand how we got here, I interviewed Hudson, an economist and financial analyst, about his new book, J Is For Junk Economics. Hudson has spent more than forty years analyzing the global economy. He’s written fifteen books on finance, war and politics, including the classic Super Imperialism: The Origin and Fundamentals of U.S. World Dominance. In this conversation, Hudson discusses the economic roots of American imperialism; why the U.S. has such a huge military budget; how the Trump administration is trying to enrich the richest

human: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out strikes against what it said were terrorist hide-outs in Iran. A day earlier, Iran hit what it called militant camps in Pakistan. The military exchange is the latest example of an expanding set of hostilities connected to the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: Pakistan announced yesterday that it carried out strikes against militants who had killed 14 of its soldiers and were preparing to attack a military base. The strikes, which hit the Jandola area of South Waziristan on the border with Afghanistan, were launched after Pakistani troops came under fire from the militants while conducting a routine patrol. It was not clear if any militants were wounded or killed in the attacks, but the army said it would continue the strikes as necessary.

human: “It all began with writing,” goes the first line of Adam Thirlwell’s latest novel, in which a young socialite named Celine is slandered in pornographic, anonymously authored pamphlets circulating in prerevolutionary Paris. Four pages later, Thirlwell clears his throat — actually, Celine’s publicity troubles go back to the Big Bang: “The universe disintegrates into a cloud of heat, it falls inevitably into a vortex of entropy, but within this irreversible process there may be areas of order, portions of existence that tend toward a form, in which it might be possible to discern a design — and one of these was this story of Celine and her friends.” This could have gone without saying, but Thirlwell can’t help himself. In “The Future Future,” the English writer compulsively gestures to the biggest picture and decides it’s the gesture that’s profound.
llm: “It all began with a simple plan: I would write a novel about a woman who was possessed by a demon. Then it turned into a story about the devil and his minions, as well as the angels who oppose them. But my research led me to think that the devil wasn’t so bad, just misunderstood. So now it’s a book about faith and how it is tested, but also about the power of love, which can bring even the worst person back from the brink.” —Jonathan Janz

human: Heather Sellers wrote her Modern Love essay in 2013, about reconnecting with her elderly, estranged father. Although their relationship was painful, Heather made sure that her last words to her father were “I love you.” And at the time, that felt like closure.
llm: Heather Sellers wrote this essay in 2013 and then changed her mind about it. It was originally published in the journal Brevity (http://brevitymag.org/nonfiction/the-art-of-change/). She has changed it again for this book.

human: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

human: The linen closet did not hold nearly enough sheets to blunt the vengeance of a late-May freeze that turned umbrella-like Astilboides leaves into alien life-forms.
llm: The linen closet is full, and we still have to put away the Christmas decorations. I'm not sure why we bother with the tree, but we do it anyway. Maybe that's what makes the holidays special.

human: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the conviction of Sam Bankman-Fried, the reassertion of union power and the turmoil at OpenAI were just some of the big business stories in a year that was full of them.
llm: The collapse of the world's second largest automobile manufacturer, Toyota, caused a worldwide recession and economic crisis. The company went bankrupt after its vehicles were found to have faulty gas pedals that could lead to uncontrolled acceleration and loss of control of the vehicle. Toyota was one of the most profitable companies in the world prior to the recall scandal.

human: The president of Harvard, Claudine Gay, will remain in her job, the university announced on Tuesday, despite demands for her resignation because of her testimony in a congressional hearing on campus antisemitism.
llm: The president of Harvard University is stepping down from her position in the wake of a series of controversies over the past year.

human: Talk to any friends of the writer Hisham Matar, and he has many, and soon they’ll bring up one of his more notorious pastimes: Have you ever seen how he looks at art?
llm: Talk to any writer, and they will tell you that the most difficult part of writing is the first sentence. What do I put down? How can I encapsulate my whole life in one sentence? And how do I know whether this sentence is right or wrong?

human: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side. There is a rent-stabilized apartment on my floor occupied by an older couple who have lived here for 50 years and have serious health issues. This morning, one of the occupants, who has advanced dementia, opened my apartment door, which was briefly unlocked, and was standing in my living room! I was able to gently escort her back to her apartment. Building management said that they have spoken to the city’s adult protective services, which has investigated and declined to act. This is a terrible situation — there are no interested family members, and the couple is often unbathed and walking the halls. What can we do?
llm: Q: I live in a gated community. The people next door are elderly and not in the best of health. They need help, and my wife and I have done what we can for them, but there's only so much we can do. What else can we do? -- C.F., Houston

human: In late 2016, when the private equity mogul Leon Black was trying to sell one expensive piece of art to buy another without incurring a hefty tax bill, he turned to the one man he knew who could help pull it off: his friend Jeffrey Epstein.
llm: In late 2016, Mr. Epstein, the financier, contacted the art dealer Larry Gagosian and asked him to broker an unusual sale: He wanted to buy a painting by Paul Cézanne, “Card Players,” one of the most celebrated works in modern art, and he needed help finding a buyer who would pay more than $150 million.

human: After the brass band packed up its instruments, Sergio Solano and two other food delivery workers walked a white bicycle to an overpass within view of the United Nations headquarters.
llm: After the brass band had finished playing, a man stood and read from his notes: “As we mourn our brother, let us also celebrate his life.”

human: What happened in the wake of those arrests would expose a juvenile justice system that was playing by its own rules. For over a decade, this county had arrested and illegally jailed hundreds, maybe thousands, of children. It would take years, but eventually one lawyer, a former juvenile delinquent himself, asked: Why? The answer would lead back to a powerful judge, the jailer she appointed and a county that treated this astronomical number of arrests as normal.
llm: What happened in 2017? A lot. We can tell you that much. So, we put together a little recap video with some of our favorite photos from the year! We hope you enjoy it!

human: A New York City carriage driver was charged with animal cruelty on Wednesday in a case arising from a feeble horse’s collapse on a busy Hell’s Kitchen street in August 2022.
llm: A New York City carriage driver was charged with animal cruelty on Tuesday after a horse he was driving collapsed and had to be euthanized. The horse, a 13-year-old Belgian draft named Prince, was pulling an open carriage around Central Park on Saturday when the incident occurred. A witness told WABC that the horse was "sweating like crazy," and a passerby who tried to help him said that the horse "couldn't breathe."

human: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Wednesday proposed a rule that would sharply limit overdraft charges at the largest banks and credit unions in the United States, a change that the agency estimated could save households up to $3.5 billion a year in fees.
llm: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has proposed a rule that would cap overdraft fees at $10 per item and place limits on the number of times banks can charge those fees. The CFPB estimates that the rule could save consumers up to $4.5 billion annually. The proposal would apply to banks with more than 2 million deposit accounts and is intended to address concerns about bank account practices that have led some consumers into debt. A large percentage of these fees are charged to low-income customers, who also tend to be less likely to opt out of overdraft protection services. Under the proposed rules, banks would no longer be allowed to assess an overdraft fee unless the consumer opts in to the service. Additionally, consumers

human: At the top of Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, Calif., Lick Observatory looks out over the dense sprawl of the San Francisco Bay Area. On a clear day from the 4,200-foot summit, you can see San Francisco to the north, as well as the entrance to Yosemite Valley, 120 miles east, as the crow flies. At night you can see even farther — millions of light-years into space.
llm: At the top of the summit of Mount Wilson in the San Gabriel Mountains, we’re standing near a 60-inch telescope that was built by George Ellery Hale. It was used to discover the rings of Saturn, measure the speed of light, and many other things. The telescopes are still in use today, but they have been joined by new instruments like the Michelson interferometer which has the world’s largest mirrors. At the nearby Palomar Observatory, there is another 200-inch telescope and it will be featured on the show.

human: “Two things are true: Israel must do something, and what it’s doing now is indefensible.” So writes Zack Beauchamp, a senior correspondent at Vox.
llm: “Two things are needed for the success of a military operation: The right people and the right tools.”

human: It was just after noon on an early September Saturday when the first call came.
llm: It was just a few days after his 20th birthday in November when George Santos, an undocumented immigrant, found himself on a Greyhound bus bound for Phoenix with little more than $100 and a backpack full of clothes. His parents had sent him away from their home in Mexico City when he was 15 because they could no longer afford to feed him, but now that he was older, they were asking him to come back and help support them.

human: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree. The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.” That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.
llm: Apparently, some time after 1973, the author of this article read that serial killer Edmund Kemper's last words were: "I'm going to go out and find me a nice girl."

human: Donald J. Trump is showing surprising resilience on the abortion issue, appearing less vulnerable than fellow Republicans despite his key role in shaping the Supreme Court that overturned Roe v. Wade.

Wade, the 1973 ruling that established a constitutional right to an abortion, and even suggested that women should be punished if they have illegal procedures.

human: As the Kremlin reveled in the failure of Congress to approve new military assistance for Ukraine and President Biden railed against Republican lawmakers for “kneecapping” an ally in their hour of need, Ukrainian soldiers, political leaders and Kyiv’s allies were all left asking the same question on Thursday: What happens if the United States stops providing military assistance?
llm: As the Kremlin has continued to ramp up its support for separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine, the United States has been trying to figure out how much aid it can afford to give Kiev as it fights a war that is costing lives and billions of dollars.

human: The math performance of U.S. teenagers has sharply declined since 2018, with scores lower than 20 years ago, and with American students continuing to trail global competitors, according to the results of a key international exam released on Tuesday.
llm: The math performance of 15-year-olds around the world has declined slightly since the last international assessment in 2003, according to results released today on the PISA exam. However, while the United States still ranks lower than many other countries, it showed a slight improvement in math scores this year, though the change was not statistically significant.

human: Since fleeing Syria a decade ago, Wafa Mustafa has spoken out for political prisoners at the United Nations, held vigils outside war crimes trials and chanted in solidarity with Iranians protesting their authoritarian government.
llm: Since fleeing Syria, Ahmad has been on the run. First to Turkey and then to Germany, where he arrived in 2015, he has moved from one shelter to another, unable to find a home. human: A plane crash that killed dozens of people in Nepal in January was caused by a pilot who pulled the incorrect levers while trying to land, the country’s investigators said Thursday.
llm: A plane crashed into a hillside in Nepal on March 12. All 67 passengers and five crew members were killed. The cause of the accident is not yet known.

human: Darryl George, the Texas high school student who earlier this year was removed from school because his hairstyle violated a dress code, was suspended again on Tuesday, the latest flashpoint in a monthslong dispute over a school policy that has spilled into the courts.
llm: Darryl George, the student’s father, said his son was given a 10-day suspension because his dreadlocks were longer than 2 inches. The suspension would have started Monday, and Mr. George said he had to take off work to pick up his son.

human: So the federal government wasn’t shut down over the weekend, although we may have to go through this whole drama again in six weeks. Kevin McCarthy, the speaker of the House, ended up doing the obvious: bringing a funding bill to the floor that could pass only with Democratic votes, because the hard-liners in his own party wouldn’t agree to anything feasible. And the bill didn’t include any of the spending cuts Republicans have been demanding, except for one big, bad thing: a cutoff of aid to Ukraine.
llm: So the federal government is now officially a criminal enterprise. I would be interested in hearing what the conservative talking heads have to say about this, since it's their party that has done all of this.

human: Former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina has tried to carve a more moderate path on the contentious issue of abortion than many of her rivals for the Republican nomination for president.
llm: Former Gov. Nikki Haley (R-SC) said she would have signed the six-week abortion ban that is making its way through South Carolina's legislature, despite her past criticism of similar bills in other states.

human: New Haveners and Yale graduates alike size one another up with a handshake and a single question: What’s your favorite pizza place?
llm: New Haveners and visitors alike have been seeking out the perfect slice of pizza for decades. It is a mission that has been documented in books, movies, and even songs. Now, one company has stepped forward with an ambitious plan to take it to the next level. The New Haven Register has more on how the quest to unlock New Haven's Pizza Moment could be the start of something big.

human: In Britain, Armistice Day is usually an understated affair, marked only by two minutes of silence at 11 a.m. This year was considerably more eventful, as two very different protests descended on London.
llm: In Britain, Armistice Day is Remembrance Sunday, and the ceremonies are quite different from those in France. On November 10th, in Paris, a two-minute silence was observed at midday by all traffic; in London it was only after the service that motorists stopped for the sounding of the last post. human: American shoppers, burned by more than two years of rapid inflation, are getting some welcome relief this holiday season: Prices on many products are falling.
llm: American shoppers, burned by the recession and cautious about spending in these uncertain times, are finally getting a break. For the first time in decades, prices for clothing and other consumer goods are falling.

human: The South African police have arrested a man who confessed to having caused a fire that killed 77 people in a derelict building in downtown Johannesburg last year after a drug dispute led him to strangle a man and set the body alight, a police spokeswoman and a victims’ advocate said on Wednesday.

human: As the Israel-Hamas conflict intensifies, raising the prospect of a wider war, China has stepped up efforts to pitch itself as a neutral broker for Mideast peace.
llm: As the Israel-Hamas conflict rages on in the Gaza Strip, Chinese social media users have turned their attention away from the battlefield and toward another front in the war: antisemitic attacks against Jews.

human: The Connecticut River faces a crisis: An aggressive invasive plant that grows in thick underwater mats is spreading swiftly.
llm: The Connecticut River, which flows through six states and serves as a water source for millions of people, is facing multiple environmental threats. The river has suffered from pollution for decades and now faces an even more serious threat: climate change. Climate change is likely to result in less rainfall and more extreme weather events in the Northeast U.S., which could pose additional challenges for the river's health. In 2016, the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) partnered with the New Hampshire Department of Environmental Services to investigate whether dye tracer experiments can be used to help predict how changes in precipitation might affect the river system and its ability to provide clean drinking water to residents.

human: A man was arrested early Tuesday after breaching the Colorado Supreme Court building, holding a guard at gunpoint and opening fire inside, the local authorities said. No injuries were reported, although the judicial center suffered extensive damage.
llm: A man was shot by police at the Colorado Supreme Court building Tuesday night after he pulled a gun on security officers, according to Denver police.

human: Investigators looking into the cause of a deadly fire at a wedding hall in northern Iraq called on Sunday for the firing of a half-dozen provincial and local officials for their failure to enforce compliance with even minimal safety standards in the hall’s construction and operation.
llm: Investigators looking into the causes of a fire that destroyed an Iraqi wedding hall in which 59 women and children died, are calling on Baghdad's governor to be dismissed. The investigators say the governor failed to take action after receiving warnings about the safety of the building.

human: “Kevin Hart & Chris Rock: Headliners Only,” a slick, self-mythologizing piece of Netflix content that follows the two comedians on the recent arena shows they teamed up on, is aimed at comedy fans — even if much of it will be familiar to them. The story of how Eddie Murphy spotted Rock at The Comic Strip (now Comic Strip Live) and offered him a job on the sequel to “Beverly Hills Cop” has been told many times. And any stand-up fan on social media knows that Hart presented a goat to Rock at the end of their recent show at Madison Square Garden (as well as whether or not Dave Chappelle would show up). That doesn’t mean there aren’t reasons to watch.
llm: “Kevin Hart & Chris Rock: Headliners Only” is the latest Netflix comedy special, and it’s a bit of an odd duck. The show was recorded at the 2018 Just For Laughs festival in Montreal, and Hart and Rock are both billed as headlining performers, but they don’t do sets together or even appear on stage simultaneously. Instead, each does his own set, with Rock opening the show and Hart closing it out.

human: House Republicans this week formalized their impeachment inquiry into President Biden with a party-line vote, as leaders of the investigation argued they needed to take the step to ward off potential legal challenges to their work.
llm: House Republicans this week authorized their own impeachment inquiry into the 2016 dealings of former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter. The move, which passed along party lines in a vote on Tuesday night, is an attempt by Republicans to counter the Democrats' investigation into whether President Trump abused his power when he pressured Ukraine's president to investigate the Bidens for corruption.

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Lydia Polgreen, with Masha Gessen. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

human: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve will announce their latest decision on interest rates on Wednesday, and although they are expected to keep rates steady, their assessment of the economy often moves markets, with implications for borrowers and savers.
llm: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve voted to raise short-term interest rates on Wednesday. The increase marks a milestone in the economic recovery, as it is only the second time since 2006 that the central bank has raised rates. While this decision affects many financial products, such as credit cards and mortgage loans, its impact will be felt most strongly by savers, who have seen their accounts’ yields fall in recent years as the Fed kept rates low to help stimulate the economy. The following is a look at how savers are likely to be affected by the rate hike:

human: It took Judge Tanya S. Chutkan three rounds of written filings over the last six weeks and more than two hours of courtroom arguments this week to sort through the issues surrounding the gag order she imposed on former President Donald J. Trump.
llm: It took Judge Richard Leon less than 14 hours to decide that the president’s tweet about “spying” was not evidence of obstruction. The judge, who was appointed by George W. Bush, rejected claims made by the plaintiffs that President Donald Trump’s May 2017 tweets were evidence of an attempt to obstruct special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

human: Javier Milei was first introduced to the Argentine public as a combative television personality with an unruly hairdo and a tendency to insult his critics. So when he entered Argentina’s presidential race last year, he was viewed by many as a sideshow.
llm: Javier Milei was a student of mine in the early 90s, and I'm very proud that he is now running for president. He's an honest man with a clear mind, who will work hard to make Argentina great again. He deserves your support.

human: When Scotty Scott was about 8 years old, his aunt Yvonne made him stem pounds and pounds of green beans for a big holiday dinner. Young Scotty figured that if he intentionally left on some of the ends and kept most of the pods long and floppy — in other words, did a bad job — he’d never again be tasked with such an arduous responsibility. But Aunt Yvonne caught on quickly. “What are you doing, man?” she asked when she saw his pile of odds and ends. “No, no, no, no — get back in there! You know how to snap beans.”
llm: When Scotty Scott first met with his mentor, the late Joe “Pops” Wilson, he was immediately drawn to the sound of a banjo. The 16-year-old had no idea what a banjo was and how it would impact him. But that encounter sparked a lifelong passion for music. Today, at age 74, the veteran blues artist is one of the best banjo players in America.

human: A former C.I.A. officer who worked at the American Embassy in Mexico City pleaded guilty on Tuesday to drugging and sexually assaulting more than two dozen women over a period of 14 years, the Justice Department said.
llm: A former C.I.A. officer was sentenced on Monday to 30 months in prison for sexually abusing a female colleague while they were both stationed at the American Embassy in Singapore, federal prosecutors announced.

human: It was the type of tough question a Republican presidential candidate might get on a Sunday morning talk show, only the person asking it was 15: Quinn Mitchell wanted to know if Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida believed that former President Donald J. Trump had violated the peaceful transfer of power on Jan. 6, 2021.
llm: It was the kind of question that is likely to leave even the most seasoned political veterans speechless: “Do you have any plans to run for office?”

human: The house, a traditional 1940s white stucco ranch, felt just right to Nina Weinman. It was in central Los Angeles, where she and her husband wanted to live, and it was in their price range.
llm: The house, a 1920s Mediterranean villa with ocean views and a white stucco facade, had been on the market for nearly a year. The owner, a former television executive who spent millions to renovate it, had even reduced the asking price to $13 million from $18 million.

human: A New York City police officer who responded to a call reporting a distraught teenager repeatedly punched the boyfriend of the boy’s mother, a prosecutor from the Manhattan district attorney’s office said at the officer’s arraignment on Wednesday.

The video shows Sgt. Kizzy Adonis, 42, repeatedly punching and kicking Abel Montero as he lay on the ground with his hands behind his back, according to the district attorney's office. Mr. Montero was taken into custody after an altercation at a nightclub on West 30th Street in Manhattan. He was not charged in the incident. In a statement, the district attorney’s office said that the “victim suffered bruises, swelling and abrasions from

human: When they look at Hunter Biden, many Americans don’t like what they see — and not just because of the images of the president’s 53-year-old son in the midst of wild-eyed benders, which were leaked from his laptop and published online, first piecemeal and then in a massive batch in June.
llm: When they look back at the Obama presidency years from now, the only thing people will remember is that Hunter Biden was his son.

human: Hoosen Coovadia, a pediatrician who used science to fight for racial justice in apartheid South Africa and later transformed the approach to H.I.V. treatment for pregnant women in Africa and beyond, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Durban. He was 83.
llm: Hoosen Coovadia, a South African doctor who fought against the spread of AIDS and became an international advocate for children with H.I.V., died on July 15 in Durban. He was 83. The cause was complications of lung cancer, said his wife, Gail, to whom he had been married for more than 40 years. Dr. Coovadia, as he was widely known, was born in Durban on March 23, 1936. His father worked as a clerk at the city’s main post office, while his mother tended bar at a nearby pub. “We were quite poor,” Dr. Coovadia told The New York Times in 2017. “I remember when

human: Since Lionel Messi, considered by many to be the greatest soccer player ever, signed with Inter Miami this July, he has made a big splash for his new team — on and off the field.
llm: Since Lionel Messi, the world's most famous soccer player, is currently in jail in his native Argentina for tax evasion, it seems appropriate to note that, on Sunday, he was once again awarded the "pink jersey," an award given to the top scorer in the Italian Serie A league.

human: If you loathe cockroaches, you’re going to love the emerald jewel wasp.
llm: If you loathe cockroaches, these wasps might be your new best friend. They're tiny—no bigger than a grain of rice—and they use their stings to paralyze and then eat their prey alive. And when I say alive, I mean that literally: A female paralyzes her prey by injecting venom into its body, then proceeds to chew through its exoskeleton with her mandibles while it's still conscious. The process can take up to 24 hours, during which time the roach will likely suffer some serious emotional trauma.

human: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 11 questions you can get right.

human: Do abortion and democracy matter to voters?

These are questions that I address in a paper coauthored with Sébastien Dessus, “Abortion Rights, Democratic Reforms, and Voter Preferences: A Comparative Analysis,” which was published recently as part of the American Journal of Political Science‘s special issue on “Democracy, Authoritarianism, and the Study of Politics.” Here is the abstract:

human: Children, according to the old disciplinarian maxim, should be seen and not heard. The title characters of “The Witches,” Roald Dahl’s 1983 fantasy novel, would like to go one step further: They plan to exterminate every child in England by disseminating candy laced with a magic potion that will turn them into mice.
llm: Children, according to Roald Dahl, are “cruel little beasts” who should be fed to wolves. But in his 1983 children’s novel The Witches, a boy named Luke is kidnapped by witches and must endure a terrifying ordeal before he can escape. He eventually does so with the help of a giant talking mouse, but only after being subjected to some of the most grotesque images ever published for young readers. Now this grisly tale has been turned into a musical, which opened on Broadway at the Lyceum Theatre last night. And it’s not just kids who will find themselves gasping in horror as they watch the story unfold.

human: Good morning. Chili season gets underway in my house after the first day I am well and truly chilled on my daily bike ride north along the harbor, wind whistling out of the west as if to knock me over. That sure wasn’t yesterday, not in New York!
llm: Good morning. Chili today, huh? What a coincidence! I have chili on my blog today too. It's all about comfort foods for fall. :)

human: After the FTX cryptocurrency exchange filed for bankruptcy last year, Thomas Braziel, an investor who specializes in collapsed businesses, started brokering an unusual kind of transaction: a market to profit from FTX’s downfall.
llm: After the FTX/USD exchange rate spiked up to $0.13, it has been trading at around $0.125 as of press time. The current market capitalization of FTX is just under $8 million, with a circulating supply of 67,499,999 FTX tokens and a total supply of 100 million FTX.

human: The stretch of time that unfurls in the sublime Japanese drama “Monster” begins with a fire and ends during a monsoon. These elemental disasters, and a fragile cluster of events that fall between them, are viewed from the perspectives of three characters entwined in a messy struggle for understanding: a boy, a mother and a teacher.
llm: The stretch of the 20th century when we thought we could put a man on the moon and cure all diseases also had its dark side. The late 1960s and early ’70s were an era of social upheaval. In 1969, the Manson family murders shook Southern California; the following year, Charles Whitman climbed to the top of the University of Texas tower with a rifle and began shooting students below.

human: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian who, beginning in the 1960s, reshaped his field by setting aside dry chronologies of styles and movements for an interdisciplinary approach borrowing from psychoanalysis, French literary theory and cultural studies, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.
llm: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian and critic whose books and articles helped reshape the field of his discipline by reimagining it as a critical discourse in which theory and history were essential partners, died on Jan. 19 in Manhattan. He was 82.

llm: Al-Shifa, Gaza’s main hospital, was the target of Israeli airstrikes on Wednesday morning. A total of 18 people were injured and four ambulances damaged in the attack that hit the emergency room. The bombardment came two days after the start of Israel’s ground offensive against Palestinians in the besieged enclave.

human: They are some of the most determined voters in the world.
llm: They are some of the most influential members of America's fastest growing immigrant group. Yet they can't vote for president in November -- and many won't bother to cast ballots at all in their homeland. For more than 20 million Americans of Asian descent who were born abroad or have an overseas relative, voting back home is not as simple as mailing in a ballot. In fact, it requires a lot of time, patience and money -- even if you happen to be one of the richest people on Earth. That's the case with Mark Tsai, the founder of G-Tech Enterprises, which makes the popular G-Drive external hard drive. The 51-year-old from Taiwan, whose company has annual reven

human: The history of Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh was ended in the old manner of conflict resolution: siege, conquest, expulsion. After a 10-month blockade, Azerbaijan launched an attack on Sept. 19, claiming the enclave in a day and causing nearly the entire ethnic Armenian population to flee. Give war a chance, as the saying goes.
llm: The history of this world is a record of its gradual disenchantment. Each age has tended to disbelieve that which went before it, and mankind gets fixed in its turn, only to be displaced by the next. In every age, humanity has tried to throw off the trammels of the previous one, failed, and accepted them as permanent.

human: For many years, Rebecca Chamberlain designed clothes for famous brands, mostly to make ends meet. During the coronavirus pandemic, she started doing it for herself — by turning old garments into modern, sophisticated pieces.
llm: For many years, I have been working with recycled materials and vintage fabrics to create new fashion. Now that my children are grown up, it's time for me to spend more time creating things that I love. That's why I started my Etsy shop, which is now my main source of income. I design all my clothing in the studio that I built next to our home here in northern France. It’s quite isolated from everything, but I like this peaceful place where I can focus on what I do best: creating!

human: It’s 2023. Using only your smartphone you can study dance moves in Berlin, shout along with protests in Iran, watch opera in Finland or witness catastrophe in the Middle East, if not live then close to it. In other words, it’s easier than it’s ever been to believe you’re everywhere when you’re actually nowhere, to feel as if you’re acting when you’re only reacting, to think you’re making connections when you’re totally alone.
llm: It’s 2023. Using a combination of machine learning, artificial intelligence and big data, an algorithm has been created that can accurately predict what kind of content will go viral online before it even happens. A company is born to capitalize on this technology by creating a platform where people can post their own “viral” video content for free, in exchange for sharing their personal data with the corporation. As a result, the platform becomes so popular that it quickly replaces traditional social media as the primary method of communication between users. The company makes billions, and all the other social media platforms slowly die out or are acquired by the new giant.

human: It was Nov. 17, 2022, and Kenneth Smith was lying on a gurney inside Alabama’s execution chamber, his arms and legs strapped down as he waited to be put to death. Mr. Smith, who had been on death row for more than a quarter-century after being convicted of murdering a woman, recalled thanking God for his final week alive and thinking of his family.
llm: It was Nov. 8, and the state of Alabama had just tried to execute a prisoner for the first time in nearly 20 years. But it went terribly wrong. Read more at NYT > nytimes.com

human: An article on Sunday about the rise of net migration to Britain since its exit from the European Union incorrectly described the role of the Conservative Party in the Brexit campaign. It was the party’s Brexit-supporting lawmakers, including the current prime minister, who played on fears of a foreign influx, not the entire Conservative Party.
llm: An article on Friday about the state of the nation's public pensions misstated the name of a group that tracks the health of such plans and how much money they have. It is the National Conference on Public Employee Retirement Systems, not the National Conference on Public Pension Systems. (The conference changed its name in September.) The article also referred imprecisely to the amount of money that the Illinois pension system has. It has less than $45 billion in assets — not $45 billion in unfunded liabilities.

human: When Mayor Mike Duggan talks about his accomplishments in Detroit, the list is both impressive and sad. He had the streetlights turned back on, and reopened closed parks. In the decade since he took office, the city has demolished some 25,000 blighted homes whose rusty debris and incubation of crime drag down neighborhoods.
llm: When Mayor Mike Duggan announced a new program in Detroit to use eminent domain to take over abandoned properties, some people called it “Kelo on steroids,” referring to the Supreme Court decision that allowed cities to seize private property for economic development.

human: Peter Coy: Paul, I think the economy is going to be a huge problem for President Biden in 2024. Voters are unhappy about the state of the economy, even though by most measures it’s doing great. Imagine how much unhappier they’ll be if things get worse heading into the election — which I, for one, think is quite likely to be the case.
llm: Peter Coy: Paul, we’re talking about the economy. But I think there is a little bit of politics in here as well because it’s an election year. You have to ask yourself, what is President Trump going to run on?

human: Jasmine, one of two protagonists in Jean Kwok’s intriguing fourth novel, “The Leftover Woman,” reveals little to the reader at first. Seeing her on the streets of Manhattan’s Chinatown, we quickly understand that she’s a woman with a complicated past. But like the frumpy clothes she wears to disguise her appearance, her thoughts and words are meant to throw us off the track. As Jasmine trudges from one job interview to the next, searching for work that will help pay off the “snakeheads” who helped her emigrate from China, she remains as invisible to readers as she is to her pursuers.
llm: Jasmine, one of the protagonists in my novel, is a single mother who lives with her two children in an inner-city neighborhood in New York City. Her life has been upended by the death of her husband from AIDS and she has become estranged from her family because they refuse to accept her son, who is HIV positive. She is an atheist who sees no value in religion, and she is cynical about the possibility of love.

human: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.” Make that pleasures: carnal, material, romantic, sonic, competitive and, if necessary, vengeful, all with a girlish nonchalance. The album begins with loops of laughter and ethereal oohs and ahs; it ends with Uchis thanking listeners with a “mwah” kiss. It’s an album of breezy confidence and sly ingenuity, easily moving among futuristic electronics, 1990s nostalgia and Latin roots.
llm: Kali Uchis basks in the glow of her own brilliance on “Orquídeas.” The song is one of two new tracks the Colombian singer-songwriter released as part of a new EP, Isolation, which came out today (Oct. 25) via Interscope Records.

human: A judge decided on Thursday that rap lyrics by the Atlanta artist Young Thug and his collaborators will be allowed as evidence in the racketeering trial of YSL, a chart-topping hip-hop label and collective that prosecutors say is also a criminal street gang responsible for violent crimes.
llm: A judge decided that Young Thug's lyrics will be allowed as evidence during his upcoming trial. The rapper was originally facing charges of extortion, kidnapping and aggravated assault for an incident involving a stylist who claims he stole her car after she failed to return the designer dresses he lent her. Now, however, prosecutors have added an additional charge against him: racketeering.

human: Detailed tables and scenarios explain every team’s paths to the playoffs.
llm: Detailed tables and charts are provided for each team, including records, common opponents, strength of schedule, average margin of victory in wins and losses, points scored and allowed, and more. The author has also compiled a list of the remaining games, which includes dates, times, television channels, and point spreads. This is a useful resource for sports fans who want to learn more about their favorite teams.

human: I’m near-term slightly more optimistic but long-term pessimistic about the ability of the United States to deal with its budget problems. My uptick in optimism comes from a deal in Washington, while the pessimism comes from what I heard at an economics conference in San Antonio that I attended last weekend.
llm: I’m near-term slightly bullish on the US stock market. But I do not believe the 10 year Treasury bond is a safe investment today. Why? Because the yield curve (the difference between long and short term interest rates) has inverted, which means that the shortest maturity Treasury notes are now paying more than the longest.

human: Four days after it was seized by Israeli troops, the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital has become a “death zone,” the World Health Organization said, as 31 premature babies in extremely precarious health there were evacuated on Sunday.
llm: Four days after Israel said it had discovered a “death zone” in one of the Gaza City hospitals it had struck, killing 10 people and injuring 28, the surviving patients have been moved to another hospital.

llm: The House of Representatives is broken. That much we know. But the question is why? And it turns out that one member has some answers: Rep. Mo Brooks (R-AL), who recently wrote a memo explaining his theory about what went wrong in the lower chamber. It's quite an insightful document. Here are the highlights:

human: Last fall, as The Learning Network celebrated 25 years of helping people teach and learn with the news, it seemed to us that education issues were making more headlines than ever.

human: Barring a political miracle or an act of God, it is overwhelmingly likely that Donald Trump will again be the Republican Party’s nominee for president.
