llm: Barring a political miracle, Donald Trump will win the Republican nomination. But as it turns out, I don't want him to become president. That doesn't make me a hypocrite—it makes me an American.

human: The soaring number of people crossing into the United States from Mexico has been a political vulnerability for President Biden for the past three years, chipping away at his approval rating and opening him up to political attacks.
llm: The soaring number of Central American migrants apprehended at the southwest border has put a spotlight on the Trump administration's efforts to send them back. But that effort is not without its critics, including former Vice President Joe Biden and other Democrats who have blasted the Trump team for what they describe as cruel and inhumane treatment of children and families seeking refuge from violence and poverty.

human: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1907, Jean Schlumberger was constantly sketching as a child. He dreamed of becoming an artist one day, but his parents, who hoped he’d take over the family textile business, sent him to Berlin to practice banking instead. In his early 20s, he defiantly moved to Paris and opened a jewelry workshop on Rue La Boétie, where he handcrafted delicate floral brooches out of Meissen porcelain, antique cameos and decorative Victorian objects he found at the Marché aux Puces. His fantastical creations soon captured the attention of the fashion world. After spotting Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark in a pair of his earrings in 1937, the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli commissioned him to design buttons shaped like fruits and insects.
llm: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1968, Mathieu Lehanneur studied at the École Nationale Supérieure de Création Industrielle (ENSCI) and at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. His work has been shown in galleries worldwide, including in Paris, Brussels, Berlin, New York, and Tokyo, and he has designed for brands such as Ligne Roset, Zanotta, and Seletti. In 2013, Lehanneur was awarded an Honorable Mention at the A’ Design Awards in Italy, where his Bubble Washing Machine won the Red Dot Award and the Iconic Awards. In 2014, he received the Architizer A+Award

human: Hundreds of people gathered in Columbus Circle in Manhattan on Thursday evening, the first night of Hanukkah, to light candles for the holiday and to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.
llm: Hundreds of people gathered at a rally outside the Israeli Consulate in Manhattan on Wednesday night to show their support for Israel amid the continuing violence between Hamas and Israel. They prayed, lit candles and called for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza.

human: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, on Thursday expressed little urgency to make another interest rate increase imminently — but he reiterated that officials would adjust policy further if doing so proved necessary to cool the economy and fully restrain inflation.
llm: Jerome H. Powell, Federal Reserve chairman, said on Thursday that the Fed was still in the early stages of its monetary policy normalization campaign and pledged to do more if necessary to reach its goals for full employment and stable prices.

human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat. Not especially beautiful, intelligent, affectionate or agile, she lived a long, happy, uneventful life. When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard. That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged. For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October. Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat. — Judith Karp
llm: Caboodle was a wonderful story, thanks for sharing.

human: An article on Monday about the Ukrainian Orthodox Church’s decision to move Christmas to Dec. 25 referred incorrectly to the Eastern Orthodox Church in Finland. The church there does not use the Julian calendar.
llm: An article on Friday about a new book by the novelist Joyce Carol Oates misstated the number of books she has written or edited. It is more than 50, not “more than 60.” The article also referred incorrectly to her having won two National Book Awards. She won the award twice; it was not for the same book. (The first was for “them,” in 1970, and the second was for “Blonde,” in 2000.)

human: The demise of Mint, the beloved budgeting app, has caused its millions of users to consider alternatives. That makes it as good a time as any for everyone to consider a money management tool.
llm: The demise of Mint is a big deal for personal finance nerds who have come to rely on it over the years. The app's clean design and easy-to-use features made it an attractive option for anyone looking for an intuitive way to manage their money, but now that it's going away, users will need to find new options. If you're one of them, there are plenty of other apps out there that can do the same job as Mint. They might not be as feature-rich or as popular, but they still work.

The other three debates are scheduled for October 7 (Oberlin College), October 15 (University of Michigan) and October 22 (Belmont University). All the debates will take place between 9:00 pm and 10:30 pm Eastern Time.

human: In recent months, abortion opponents in Texas have succeeded in passing a growing number of local ordinances to prevent people from helping women travel to have abortions in nearby states that still allow the procedure.
llm: In recent months, state legislatures across the country have introduced bills that would make it more difficult or impossible for women to access abortion care. In response, advocates in states including Georgia and Mississippi are working with local leaders to enact measures designed to protect access to reproductive health services, especially in areas where state lawmakers have sought to restrict abortion rights.

human: “Just meet the coach.”
llm: “Just meet the parents,” she said, “and you’ll see.”

human: Two lovers belting “Open Your Heart.” A misunderstood woman exhorting a roaring audience to “Express Yourself.” A gay wedding extravaganza set to “Like A Prayer.”
llm: Two lovers belting out the opening notes to “Like A Virgin” in an underground car park is not something you see every day. But that’s what happened on Wednesday night at the launch of “I Love Madonna,” a new musical in Paris which has been created by French fans for fellow fans. The show, presented in a rough-and-ready format, opened to 200 people with standing room only in the small venue, and tickets for future performances are selling fast.

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies. “Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women. Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire. She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago, Erica Jong published her groundbreaking novel “Fear of Flying,” which sold millions of copies and made its author a household name. But what happened next?

human: Amid terrible events abroad and the takeover of the Republican Party by agents of chaos, the U.S. economy has been delivering lots of good news. All indications are that real G.D.P. is still growing fast; we’re adding jobs at an extraordinary pace, even as inflation continues to fall.
llm: Amid terrible events around the world, it is easy to ignore a domestic problem that does not seem so pressing. But our government’s budget deficits are a serious problem, and they could easily become an emergency. As a practical matter, our economy will be more productive and grow faster if we address these deficits sooner rather than later. In fact, some economists believe that today’s high unemployment rate would not exist were it not for our large budget deficits. This is because investors have become reluctant to lend money in the United States as long as the federal government is running huge annual budget deficits. If we do not reduce the deficits soon, this situation will persist and hinder economic growth. So why don’t we? The

human: Follow our latest updates on the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: Follow our latest coverage of the conflict in Gaza.

human: June Jackson Christmas, a psychiatrist who broke barriers as a Black woman by heading New York City’s Department of Mental Health and Retardation Services under three mayors, died on Sunday in the Bronx. She was 99.
llm: June Jackson Christmas, a psychiatrist who founded the first racially integrated hospital in New York City and later became an influential educator of mental health professionals, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.

human: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory? It refers to a story or a painting that comes with a moral or a lesson, perhaps a social or political one. And, in an era when figurative art has returned to prominence, the New York galleries are filled with a profusion of both allegorical paintings and their very opposite — which is to say, paintings that reject third-person narration in favor of first-person self-exposure. I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
llm: At the risk of sounding like an old fart, I think it’s time we stopped talking about “controversial art” and just call it what it is: bad art. The work in question at this year’s Whitney Biennial (the latest, which opened last weekend) has been so heavily criticized that it’s a wonder it’s still there. But then again, the show is called “The 2017 Whitney Biennial,” not “The 2017 Whitney Biennial Except for One Work That Some People Think Is Bad.”

human: Last week, I wrote about the benefits of small rituals, those everyday acts, repeated regularly in a specific way, that add richness and meaning to our lives.
llm: Last week, I asked readers to share their offbeat rituals for Halloween. Here are some of the stories they sent in, which were edited for length and clarity.

human: The question of how Britain will respond to President Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act, the $369 billion landmark legislation offering deep subsidies for green investment, has followed Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s finance minister, for most of the past year.
llm: The question of how the UK will fund its green policies is now a big issue in British politics. The country has pledged to cut carbon emissions by 60% from 1990 levels by 2050, but there are concerns that the cost of meeting this target could be prohibitive. In the face of an economic downturn, the government is being forced to reassess its plans.

human: Gavin Newsom has a scant history of tough debates over his two decades as governor and lieutenant governor of California and mayor of San Francisco.
llm: Gavin Newsom has a problem with Fox News.

human: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said Sunday that criminal proceedings had been initiated over an episode in which Russian missiles struck a group of Ukrainian soldiers at an award ceremony in the south of the country, killing some and leaving others wounded.
llm: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has said that the killing of six Ukrainian soldiers by a Russian missile strike in September was an act of terrorism.

human: Humans are a remarkably ambitious species. We came to the edge of lands we could safely chart and built ships that would carry us to the unknown. When travel by water and land no longer suited us, we took to the skies. After journeying among the clouds could not sate our spirit, we turned our hearts to the stars.
llm: Humans are a plague on the planet, says Derrick Jensen in his new book. He's right, but what can we do about it?

human: It was the depths of the Cold War in the 1960s, and Caracas was on edge.
llm: It was the British who decided on the boundary in 1897. There's no reason for it to be changed now. If Venezuela wants the disputed land, they should buy it from Exxon or whomever is holding it.

human: Nasreen Parveen decided to run for her life at the same moment she decided not to end it.
llm: Nasreen Parveen decided she would have to leave her home in Bangladesh. As a young woman in her country, she was not allowed to speak out or take part in politics. But Nasreen wanted to change the world—and she knew that if she stayed, she’d never be able to do so. In this excerpt from the book “Born to Lead,” Nasreen tells her story of overcoming obstacles and finding success as an entrepreneur and advocate for women’s rights.

human: I’ve written several times about the case for disqualifying Donald Trump via the 14th Amendment, arguing that it fails tests of political prudence and constitutional plausibility alike. But the debate keeps going, and the proponents of disqualification have dug into the position that whatever the prudential concerns about the amendment’s application, the events of Jan. 6, 2021, obviously amounted to an insurrection in the sense intended by the Constitution, and saying otherwise is just evasion or denial.
llm: I’ve written several times about the events of January 6, 2019, when hundreds of thousands of Yemenis demonstrated in Sanaa against the Saudi-led war and blockade on their country. As I argued earlier this month, the U.S. media coverage of those protests was “an example of how Western media coverage of Yemen is often highly selective and misleading.” But while the protests themselves were unprecedented, the fact that a large number of Yemenis took to the streets to express their opposition to the war and blockade wasn’t exactly surprising: such protests have been occurring regularly for years. What was surprising was that the media focused so much attention on them—and that this focus led to the demonization of the protesters as violent

human: The reimagined home in Australia is ‘just joyful and really easy to live in.’
llm: The reimagined home features a bold palette of black and white, with splashes of blue.

human: Some candidates sound promising on paper but fall short when put to the test.
llm: Some candidates sound great on the campaign trail, but fail to deliver when elected to office. A look at how some of our presidents and senators lived up to their promises once in Washington.

human: A demonstration last week involving butchering half an heirloom pig, and showing how to use various parts, kicked off a series in the basement workshop and bakery at Leland Eating and Drinking House in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. It was followed by a five-course tasting dinner in the wine cellar, starring pork. The restaurant, which does its own butchering as a matter of course, has scheduled subsequent classes monthly throughout the year, with the next one on Feb. 21, followed by March 13, both pork-centric. Later in the year there will be sessions about duck and fish. The classes and dinners, starting at 6 p.m., are $100 plus tax, tip and beverages.
llm: A demonstration lasting about 10 minutes.

human: Microsoft, the technology giant that ranks as one of the world’s most valuable companies, was shaken by the upheaval at OpenAI, the small but influential artificial intelligence start-up that developed the ChatGPT chatbot, before it found a way out of the turmoil that propelled its shares to a new high.
llm: Microsoft, the technology giant and creator of Windows and Office, has hired two former employees from AI firm OpenAI as part of an effort to make its own artificial intelligence system. The company announced that it was creating a new team dedicated to applying AI technologies across its businesses, and the hires are the first for this group.

human: Shortly after Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, friends and relatives of Gali Shlezinger Idan, who lived in a kibbutz near the Gaza border, received frantic messages to check her Facebook page.
llm: Shortly after Hamas launched a campaign of terror against Israelis by firing rockets from the Gaza Strip, the organization hijacked the social media accounts of several Israeli victims. The Twitter account of Noam Alon, an IDF soldier killed in 2014, was taken over and used as a tool for incitement.

human: The new report in The New York Times that Russia is quietly signaling a readiness to freeze the war in Ukraine is both suspicious and tantalizing.
llm: The new report says Russia has been secretly arming the separatists since August, when Ukraine started its military campaign in eastern regions. The separatists have recently intensified their attacks on Ukrainian positions and captured some towns and villages in Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

human: The Chargers now have a 39% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Chargers now have a two game lead over the Chiefs for first place in the AFC West. They will be looking to keep that lead going when they host the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday, October 29th at StubHub Center. The game will start at 1:05 PM PST and will be televised by CBS.

human: In more than 1,500 animal species, from crickets and sea urchins to bottlenose dolphins and bonobos, scientists have observed sexual encounters between members of the same sex.
llm: In more than 100 species of mammal, both male and female animals have been observed engaging in sexual behavior with members of their own sex. Researchers have theorized that same-sex activity is a result of abnormal development, or that it may be an adaptation for reducing conflict within social groups. A new study suggests that same-sex sexual interactions may instead be an evolutionary strategy for reducing aggression between males.

human: In our age of scorched-earth ground offensives and bombed-out hospitals, the prospect of punishing atrocities perpetrated by governments seems particularly distant. But you could be forgiven for thinking otherwise based on the recent bounty of acclaimed books that glorify the potential of international treaties and tribunals to make lasting peace. Suspicious of diplomatic horse-trading, a prominent segment of Western liberals champion international law as the most promising means to enact their ideal of a just world.
llm: In our age of international tribunals, how can we understand the ways in which states have historically dealt with war crimes? In this lecture, Professor Diane Marie Amann will discuss how war crimes were handled by courts and other institutions of states in the past. She'll also examine how the 1946 Nuremberg trials changed the way we think about such prosecutions today. This talk is part of a series to commemorate the centennial of the end of WWI.

human: Her grandfather founded the outfitting giant L.L. Bean, whose gear has become synonymous with a woodsy lifestyle. She became a force in lobstering and tourism with companies of her own, and a lightning rod for critics who object to her outspoken conservative views.
llm: Her grandfather founded it, her father built it up, and she is rebuilding it. For more than 100 years, Jelliff’s Store was an island landmark. But in the 1960s, the store was torn down by a developer who bought out its owners. Now, with help from the Wyeth family, this summer camp on Vinalhaven Island is being restored.

human: There is one particular pulsar, a type of quick-spinning dead star, that holds the current record for the fastest rotation of any celestial body in the known universe — 716 times per second. By contrast, the blade of a Vitamix can turn around 333 times every second, but a blender is small enough to sit on a countertop, and a pulsar is a city-size ball of neutrons that floats in space and contains the mass of half a million Earths.
llm: There is one thing that I like about this episode.

human: New Zealand’s new right-wing government has said it will repeal a law that would have gradually banned all cigarette sales in the country over the course of several decades.
llm: New Zealand’s new government says it will scrap a ban on smoking in bars and restaurants when it takes office this week, Reuters reported.

human: The catchy, folk-tinged numbers from “Treason the Musical” have been streamed online over a million times, in 96 countries. Its fans — known as “Plotters” — have been listening to an EP, an acoustic record and a live album of the songs, as well as sharing their own performances on TikTok. But until this fall, there hadn’t even been a full-scale production of the show.
llm: The catchy, folk-tinged tune has been viewed more than 250,000 times on YouTube and is getting airplay in several cities. The singer, a 34-year-old mother of two from California named Lauren Mayberry, said she had not expected such an intense response when she posted it online this month.

human: For Jeanette Winterson, ghost stories are not old-fashioned or anachronistic in the modern world, but both cutting-edge and primal. In the introduction to her new collection, NIGHT SIDE OF THE RIVER: Ghost Stories (Grove, 306 pp., $27), she recalls some of her own inexplicable experiences with the uncanny, from the ghost of a writer friend materializing on her computer screen to her childhood premonition of her grandmother’s passing. Religion, and specifically faith in an afterlife, “can be considered as humankind’s first disruptive start-up,” she writes. “What’s being disrupted is death.”
llm: For Jeanette Winterson, a writer’s life is full of ghosts. Her own mother died when she was fourteen, but in her memoir Why Be Happy When You Could Be Normal? (2011) she imagined her back to life with the words: “I saw my mother as a young woman, not as I knew her.” She also conjured up the ghosts of Virginia Woolf and Mary Shelley in her novel The Passion (1987). “Both were writers who chose to live outside conventional marriage,” says Winterson.

human: Do you know what a Zynbabwe is? Or an upper-decky lip pillow? OK, here’s an easier one — how about just Zyn?
llm: Do you know how much time your children spend online? This is one of the most important questions for parents today. In this article, we talk about the most recent research on Internet use by young people and offer practical advice to help parents understand their kids' digital worlds. We also address the issue of when to worry if your child spends too much time online. Read more...

human: A man who had been denied probation attacked a judge during his sentencing in a Nevada courtroom on Wednesday in a violent episode that was captured on video.
llm: A man who was denied probation after he was convicted of a misdemeanor DUI charge attacked the judge who sentenced him, according to police.

human: Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, President Biden has presented himself as a statesman humbled and enlightened by his own country’s missteps after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. “While you feel that rage,” he advised Israelis, “don’t be consumed by it.”
llm: Since Hamas attacked Israel on May 14, the United States has issued a series of condemnations. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice called for an immediate halt to Palestinian rocket fire and urged both sides to stop fighting. President Bush said that "the Palestinians must not miss this opportunity." In Washington, D.C., at a rally in support of Israel, Senator John McCain said, "Israel has every right to defend itself against terrorism." He added: "The terrorists of Hamas, like all terrorists, are enemies of peace and we should do everything possible to help our Israeli allies defeat them."

human: Spirit Airlines, once a fast-growing low-cost carrier, is struggling to convince investors that it has a clear path forward after an antitrust ruling blocked the sale of the company to JetBlue Airways.
llm: Spirit Airlines, once the high-flying darling of Wall Street and the industry, has been battered in recent months. And now a judge has ruled that it's not allowed to buy JetBlue Airways' Latin American routes. The decision could set back Spirit’s growth plans for years, say some aviation analysts.

human: One Friday earlier this month, just as Dr. Daouda Diallo stepped out of the passport office in the capital of the West African nation of Burkina Faso, four men grabbed him off the street, pushed him into a vehicle and drove off.
llm: One Friday earlier this month, the government of Burundi sent a message to all its citizens over 18 years old: report to one of six military recruiting centers in Bujumbura. For many people, that meant missing work on Monday and Tuesday because they were forced to stand in line for hours in the heat before finally reaching the front of the queue. Others had to take time off from their studies or even quit their jobs altogether. The army needed an estimated 60,000 new soldiers.

human: The vote on Tuesday to remove Representative Kevin McCarthy as speaker of the House of Representatives has left the chamber mired in chaos.
llm: The vote on the floor was 124 to 251. This is the second time this year that McCarthy has failed in his bid for House leadership, as he also dropped out of the running for majority leader earlier this month after it became clear he did not have enough support from the Republican caucus. (more...)

human: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday in an appearance near the southern border, echoing Mr. Trump’s talk about an existential crisis of illegal immigration.
llm: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed Donald J. Trump on Wednesday, hailing the Republican presidential candidate’s immigration policies and saying he would help secure the border with Mexico if elected.

human: The Israeli military sought on Wednesday to bolster its assertions that Hamas uses tunnels beneath Gaza’s largest hospital, releasing a series of videos that it said showed “dozens of meters of a tunnel system” beneath the complex of Al-Shifa Hospital.
llm: The Israeli military has released footage of tunnels it says were built by the Palestinian militant group, Hamas. The video was published on Monday, showing tunnels in Gaza City's main hospital, and beneath a mosque.

human: President Biden pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday to agree to the creation of a Palestinian state after the war in Gaza is over and raised options that would limit Palestinian sovereignty to make the prospect more palatable to Israel.
llm: President Biden pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to take steps toward the creation of an independent Palestinian state, American officials said Friday. The White House was not ready to describe the conversation as a public confrontation between Mr. Obama’s two closest allies in the Middle East, but it appeared that Mr. Biden had made clear to Mr. Netanyahu that he wanted to see more action from the Israeli leader.

human: On a Cape Cod beach last January, I braced for my daily cold water plunge. “Can I join you?” asked a stranger. I hesitated. But her red hair and wide smile reminded me of my younger self. “Sure,” I said. Ashley is 29. I’m 47. For seven minutes in frigid water, we shared our stories: her chronic illness and career change; my failed marriage and struggles raising a child with cancer. Every day since our first encounter, we’ve met to immerse ourselves in the ocean. We bond in a daily baptism. I now can’t imagine braving water, or life, without her. — Amy McHugh
llm: On a Cape Cod beach, two friends share their love of the ocean.

human: On a recent trip to the Caribbean island of Antigua, Melissa Middlestadt, a writer from the Toronto area, was charged a $12-a-night resort fee by the all-inclusive Jolly Beach. She was told it covered the use of nonmotorized water-sports equipment and Wi-Fi.
llm: On a recent trip to New Orleans, I was charged a $29 per night “resort fee” by the Sheraton Hotel. This is in addition to the room rate of about $180 per night.

human: Dexter Scott King, who as one of four children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. worked closely with — but also frequently fought against — his siblings and the civil rights community over his father’s legacy, died on Monday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 62.
llm: Dexter Scott King, the son of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who was a civil rights activist in his own right and who worked to preserve his father's legacy, died on Thursday in Atlanta. He was 62.

human: We could talk, I suppose, about all Taylor Swift’s done for the economy, friendship bracelets, seismology and Travis Kelce. But her greatest nonmusical achievement is the innocuous art she’s made of the gape. On a 50-foot screen, the various apertures of her mouth constitute a spectacle. There’s the “Who? Me?,” the “yeah I said it,” the “ouch,” the “ooooo,” the “gosh golly” and the “Sally Field wins another Oscar.” Hers is the story of “oh.”
llm: We could talk, we could laugh about it now.

human: What makes a house a home? And what constitutes an American home? Planted dead center on the stage in “This House Is Not a Home,” a slippery, ever-shifting work by Nile Harris, is a house — a bounce house. But it’s more than an inflatable plaything.
llm: What makes a good father? It’s a question that has been asked by countless children and adults alike. But what does it mean to be a good mother in this modern age? That is one of many questions posed in “In a Land of Primary Colors,” an ambitious and complex new play from the Theatre for Young Audiences series at Actors Express Theatre Company.

human: Paul Giamatti would just like to put it out there that maybe he doesn’t always have to play such a motormouth.
llm: Paul Giamatti would be a great choice for a lot of things, but I don't think he has enough gravitas to pull off the role of Superman. I'm thinking more in terms of a guy like Jude Law or Matthew McConaughey. They have that ruggedness and sex appeal that could work for Supes.

human: Hi, all! Genevieve here, filling in for Emily Weinstein and realizing that almost exactly a year ago, I wrote about how pasta was all I wanted for dinner. Maybe it’s the season — a little chill in the air, a lot of too much going on — that calls for tender noodles.
llm: Hi, all! Genevieve here. I'm the newest contributor to Tasty Kitchen. I'm excited to be joining such an awesome community of food bloggers and can't wait to share my recipes with you.

human: On the Friday before Labor Day, Joseph Lanni and Vincent Minsquero stopped into Roxy’s Bar and Grille in Toms River, N.J. At around 8:15 p.m., federal prosecutors say, they began to argue with another patron. Restaurant employees asked them to leave, and the men became belligerent as they were escorted out.
llm: On the Friday before Thanksgiving, four men were indicted on charges of conspiring to control New York City's garbage hauling industry through extortion, bribery, and the use of violence and threats of violence. The charges include RICO (Racketeering Influenced Corruption Organizations) violations, as well as aiding and abetting mail fraud, wire fraud, and the collection of unlawful debts. Two other men were charged with related crimes that included obstruction of justice, witness tampering, and making false statements to federal agents. A further six people were arrested on charges of participating in a similar scheme involving the demolition industry.

human: House Republicans, divided and demoralized after the ouster of their speaker this week, are now quietly feuding over how to elect a successor.
llm: House Republicans, divided over their choice of leadership and facing an uphill battle in the midterm elections, have been fighting among themselves as they struggle to find a way out of the political morass.

human: A foreign visitor walking through Praça Brasil, a leafy square in the Amazonian port city of Belém, might think that the whirring blenders at a dozen nearby food carts were creating the most authentic açaí bowls on earth.
llm: A foreign visitor to Brazil has a lot of things to do in order to make the most of his trip. The list is long and varied, and includes everything from the obvious – visiting Rio de Janeiro's Christ the Redeemer statue – to the more obscure, like hiking through the Amazon rainforest. It doesn't matter if you are going for business or pleasure, you can always find something interesting to do.

human: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.
llm: “Transforming Spaces” is an art project in which we explore the ways that people and places are transformed through creative interventions. This series of photographs was inspired by a conversation between Nina Ruggiero, Director of AIRS, and her brother, David Ruggiero, about how he and his partner had transformed their home into a beautiful space to live and work in. This sparked a discussion about the ways that we all transform spaces around us to make them more livable and productive for ourselves.

human: Louis Vuitton’s takeover of the sporting world continues apace: Next August, shortly after the LVMH-sponsored Summer Olympic Games end in Paris, the Louis Vuitton-sponsored America’s Cup will begin in Barcelona.
llm: Louis Vuitton’s takeover of the LVMH Watch & Jewellery division is part of a long-term strategy to grow its watch business. The fashion house already owns Swiss watch brand TAG Heuer, which it bought in 1999. Since then, it has been expanding the brand and opening new stores around the world. Now it has its sights set on Hublot as well.

human: This feature is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.

human: “If you make it to the U.S., then you’re more likely than not to be able to stay. So it’s absolutely worth the chance of taking that risk.”
llm: “If you make $5,000 in China and $20,000 in America, why wouldn’t you go to America?” - A Chinese migrant to the United States, quoted by The Wall Street Journal.

human: A gospel singer was threatened with being removed from a Delta Air Lines flight after she refused to stop singing on the plane because, she said, she was “doing what the Lord” told her to do.
llm: A gospel singer who was nominated for a Grammy Award was nearly kicked off an airplane because of his singing.

human: A Secret Service agent guarding one of President Biden’s granddaughters fired at three people seen breaking into an unoccupied government vehicle in Washington late Sunday but did not appear to have hit them, according to a senior law enforcement official.
llm: A Secret Service agent assigned to protect Vice President Joe Biden's wife fired his gun during a car break-in in Washington, D.C., on Monday night, according to the agency.

human: About half of New York City students showed proficiency on math and reading exams this year, according to data released on Wednesday — scores that, on paper, represented a rise over last year.
llm: About half of the city's third-graders passed math and English tests this year, a slight improvement over last year but still far short of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's goal that all children be proficient by 2010.

human: Israel’s Supreme Court narrowly struck down a law proposed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that was meant to limit the court’s own powers. The momentous ruling, which was decided by a majority of eight judges to seven, could ignite a constitutional crisis.
llm: Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a government bid to impose restrictions on its own power, ruling that the legislature had no authority to curb the court’s ability to strike down laws. The decision was hailed by opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has been engaged in a long-running feud with the judiciary. In 2015, the right-wing leader proposed an amendment to the Basic Law, which is Israel’s de facto constitution, that would have limited the scope of review by the High Court of Justice. Under the proposal, a law would be considered “basic” and thus immune from challenge if it was passed by a simple majority of parliament, rather than the supermajority needed now. The bill spark

human: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.
llm: The first large-scale offshore wind farm in the United States is up and running. It’s a 600MW installation, called Vineyard Wind, located 14 miles south of Martha's Vineyard. The farm, which will generate enough electricity to power around 400,000 homes, took nearly two years to build.

human: Michael D. Cohen, the onetime fixer for former President Donald J. Trump who went to prison after pleading guilty to campaign finance violations in 2018, was trying to persuade a judge to end court supervision of his case now that he has been released.
llm: Michael D. Cohen, the president’s personal lawyer who is under scrutiny by federal prosecutors in Manhattan, cited cases in a legal filing that may not exist, a judge said on Monday.

human: The Italian Alps are renowned for their stunning scenery, fine wine and good food. But many travelers are unaware that the region also hosts exquisite Renaissance and Baroque art. Nestled in the mountains and hills of northwestern Italy, just an hour’s drive from Milan, a cluster of Catholic sanctuaries brim with sculptures and frescoes by artists like Gaudenzio Ferrari, Tanzio da Varallo and Pier Francesco Mazzucchelli.
llm: The Italian Alps are home to some of the most stunning scenery in all of Europe. The Alta Via 1, a high-altitude hiking route that runs between St. Moritz and Trieste is one of the most beautiful ways to experience this incredible landscape. On this trip we'll walk over 200km through this remote wilderness, staying in mountain refuges along the way. From the Matterhorn to Lake Garda, we'll hike over high passes, explore glaciated valleys, and follow the footsteps of Hannibal himself!

human: The Israeli military’s seizure of Al-Shifa Hospital, Gaza’s largest medical complex, is central to the military strategy at the heart of the ground invasion: Eradicate Hamas and free roughly 240 hostages taken during the Oct. 7 surprise attack.
llm: The Israeli military’s goal is to eradicate the Hamas organization in Gaza. The question I pose in this post is whether it will succeed and what the implications of a successful campaign are for Israel, Hamas, and the Palestinians more broadly.

human: Hollywood’s movie factories run on conventional wisdom — entrenched notions, based on experience, about what types of films are likely to pop at the global box office.
llm: Hollywood’s movie factories continued to crank out films at a dizzying pace in 2019. And yet the box office was down overall from 2018. Why? Because audiences have become more selective about what they watch and how much they pay for it. This is one of several lessons we can take away from this year’s box-office performance.

human: Bret Stephens: Gail, my attention these past few weeks has been devoted almost entirely to outrages and tragedies in the Middle East. But I couldn’t help smiling for a second when Nikki Haley called Vivek Ramaswamy “scum” at last week’s G.O.P. debate, after he raised the subject of her daughter’s use of TikTok.
llm: Bret Stephens: Gail, you’ve been covering politics for a long time. You’re the author of a new book called “The Party Decides.” What do you think are some of the lessons that we can draw from your book?

human: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy. Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice. After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër. Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago. (In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.) The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood. “For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett. “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
llm: Michael Bennett, the former Seahawks defensive end who now plays for the Eagles, is making furniture from scrap wood at his new studio in Philadelphia.

human: Phyllis Coates, who played the reporter Lois Lane, one of the most enduring characters in popular culture, in a theatrical film and the first season of the popular “Adventures of Superman” television series, died on Wednesday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 96.

human: We know — 2023 isn’t over yet. There are still many holiday parties and cookie swaps and family dinners to barrel through. For the cookie swap, you’ll want to refer to our 2023 Cookie Week recipes, but any sweet treat would be perfect paired with a bubbly tinto de verano. (Yes, summer is in the drink’s name, but this refreshing mix of red wine and citrus soda is delightful year-round.) And you have several options for that family dinner: white chicken chili (above), shrimp tacos or this perfect eggplant Parmesan that’s already dressed in red and green.
llm: We know — it's weird to think about what we'll be eating in 10 years. But according to a new study, that's exactly when this recipe will be all the rage: Kale and quinoa salad with roasted red pepper dressing. (Yep, you read that right.)

human: The lights are going to stay on in federal government offices, and also in the suite of the House speaker, Mike Johnson, at least for a few more weeks. Up to now, it hadn’t been clear that both could happen at the same time.

It exists only to serve its billionaire benefactors. The fact that it hasn't been shut down or dissolved is due to two factors: 1) the Democratic Party is as dysfunctional as the GOP; and 2) the corporate media gives the GOP a free pass. But eventually, even the most blindly partisan of Republicans will have to wake up and realize they've been hoodwinked by people who don't give a damn about them. I can hardly wait for that day.

And in several states, voters are also attempting to get candidates removed from the ballot because they did not file required paperwork or failed to meet residency requirements. human: As 2024 dawns, Americans’ credit card debt and late payments are rising, and card interest rates remain high, but many people lack a plan to pay down their debt. If your balances are ballooning, a New Year’s resolution to tackle them would be timely.

human: Walk into any government office, courtroom or classroom in Jamaica, and you’ll be expected to speak the official language, English.
llm: Walk into any supermarket in the capital, Kingston, and you will hear a variety of accents. In fact, this is true for most of Jamaica’s cities and towns. The country is linguistically diverse, with people speaking a mix of English, Spanish, French and even German. But only one language has an official status — patois, or Jamaican Creole. It is taught in schools across the island, though it is rarely spoken at home. In recent years, however, there have been attempts to make it more commonplace.

human: Prince Harry and other celebrities can proceed with their case against The Daily Mail’s publisher, a British judge ruled on Friday, paving the way for a lengthy court battle over phone hacking and other alleged violations of privacy.
llm: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's lawsuit against the publishers of The Mail on Sunday over their publication of photos from the couple's private wedding has been allowed to proceed in court. According to CNN, Justice Nicola Davies ruled that the case should be tried by a judge instead of a jury because it was an issue of media law and not privacy law. She also dismissed one of the five claims made by the couple—that the newspaper had misused private information—and said that another claim regarding harassment could still go ahead. (Britain's tabloids have long been accused of intruding into celebrities' lives.)

human: After years of heady spending, the budget cuts announced by Mayor Eric Adams last week hit New York City like a punch to the gut: Most libraries would be closed on Sundays. The expansion of the city’s signature prekindergarten program would be delayed. So would efforts to improve New York’s notoriously dirty streets and keep rats at bay. The city’s police force would be pared down in coming years.
llm: After years of overspending, New York is finally facing the economic music. Last week, Mayor Michael Bloomberg proposed a budget that will cut spending by $1 billion and raise taxes for the first time in more than 20 years. The city's financial picture has deteriorated significantly since Mr. Bloomberg took office in 2002. Back then, he was able to balance the books with a surplus and boast about the state of the city's finances. Now, as New York prepares for what promises to be an austere fiscal year beginning July 1, he is left explaining how his administration got into such dire straits.

human: At the restaurant ILIS in Brooklyn, your smoked tomato and clam dashi arrives in a giant clamshell, sealed with beeswax and roped shut. At Naks in the East Village, bites of beef tartare on crisped beef fat are ferried to your table on a cow horn.

At the top of the column is an elaborate base, usually with some sort of design element, like a starfish or a flower. These are called "pedestal" tables. They're designed to be both decorative and functional.

llm: The Israeli military has until Friday to withdraw from the Gaza Strip or face a broad international campaign against it and its leaders, senior American officials said today. human: A digital-age dirty-trickster who used Twitter posts that looked like Hillary Clinton ads to spread false information before the 2016 presidential election was sentenced on Tuesday to seven months in prison.
llm: A digital-age dirty-trickster was sentenced Thursday to seven months in prison for spreading false information about former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Sen. Robert Menendez (D., N.J.), according to the Justice Department.

human: The word exhortation has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 20 in “One More Chorus of ‘Humm Baby’ for a Baseball Lifer” by Scott Miller:
llm: The word exhortation has been used 1 time in all our systems.

human: The White House accused North Korea on Thursday of providing Russia with ballistic missiles that Moscow has begun to fire on targets in Ukraine, and said that in return the North was seeking a range of Russian military technologies.
llm: The White House said Monday that it is concerned about reports that North Korea may be providing Russia with ballistic missile technology.

human: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her. She had lost so much weight that she looked like a stick figure I might have drawn when we were kids. As her body had wasted, her tumors had grown — now several of them bigger than baseballs. Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
llm: On the day she died, my sister made me promise that I would write about her choice. I was reluctant. I thought that writing a piece about her death would be self-serving and exploitative. But she insisted that it wasn’t for me to judge or second guess what she did, but instead to honor her by telling the truth of how she lived and died in the most authentic way I could.

human: More Americans are buying heat pumps, an environmentally friendly alternative to furnaces and air-conditioners that can significantly lower monthly energy bills. But the pace of installations has slowed in the past year, posing an obstacle to the Biden administration’s climate plans.
llm: More Americans are turning to heat pumps as their primary source of home heating and cooling. But the technology is still in its infancy in the U.S., with just 14% of American homes having a central air conditioner or heat pump in 2018.

human: “Brown — the more ‘off,’ the better. It’s subtle and confrontational: Not a lot of colors have that versatility.” — Thebe Magugu, 30, fashion designer
llm: “Brown — the founder of The Future Today Institute, which predicts trends for companies like Intel and Microsoft — says that in the coming years, we'll be seeing more of a focus on what she calls “T,” or tech that is designed to help humans achieve their potential. She thinks we’ll see it most with the rise of brain-enhancing technologies, like smart drugs and implants that can help us improve our memory, attention span, creativity, and even empathy.”

human: For decades, Jada Pinkett Smith has been plagued by misconceptions: about the dynamics of her marriage to Will Smith, about her bond with Tupac Shakur and, most recently, about the Slap at last year’s Oscars. But in her revelation-heavy 400-page memoir, “Worthy,” these discordant threads, and others, will be pinned to the ground in no uncertain terms.
llm: For decades, Jada Pinkett Smith has been a fixture in the entertainment industry as an actress and singer. She's also been an outspoken advocate for women of color, LGBTQ people, and other marginalized groups. But she's never talked about her struggles with mental health until now—and she wants you to know that you're not alone.

human: Piper Laurie, who escaped the 1950s Hollywood starlet-making machinery to become a respected actress with three Oscar nominations and an Emmy Award, died on Saturday at a nursing facility in Los Angeles. She was 91.
llm: Piper Laurie, who was nominated for an Academy Award for her role as the manipulative mother in “Carrie,” a movie that made a star of Sissy Spacek, and then went on to play the psychopathic head of a religious cult in “Children of God” (also known as “Flowers in the Attic”), died on Wednesday. She was 85.

human: The Palestinian Red Crescent said yesterday that Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City was “no longer operational,” as power outages and shortages of fuel continued to wreak havoc on Gaza’s health facilities. The Gazan aid group said that more than 14,000 displaced people had been sheltering there.
llm: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) said on Sunday that the health conditions of the wounded in hospitals are deteriorating, especially in Gaza. In a statement, PRCS said that the Israeli army has prevented the transfer of 100 patients out of the Strip for treatment abroad since June 28. The statement added that at least 45 cases were denied exit permits due to security reasons, and some 60 other patients were refused entry into Israel.

human: For months, Argentina has been consumed by a single question.
llm: For months, Argentina has been bracing for the presidential election on Sunday. The country’s economy is struggling. Inflation is soaring and the currency has lost 50 percent of its value against the dollar this year alone. Unemployment remains high. And Argentines are increasingly worried about their security amid a wave of crime. To make matters worse, incumbent President Mauricio Macri is running neck-and-neck with his main challenger Alberto Fernández, a former president whose administration was marred by corruption scandals and economic collapse. Mr. Fernández’s running mate, Cristina Kirchner, who ruled from 2007 to 2015, is also implicated in several corruption cases,

human: For decades, South Korea’s economy has been dominated by a handful of family-run conglomerates that hold outsize wealth and influence and factor into nearly every aspect of life in the country.
llm: For decades, South Korea has been dominated by family-run business groups known as chaebols. These conglomerates have their roots in a tumultuous period following World War II and the Korean War that saw the country rebuild its economy from the ground up. The companies that make up the chaebols now account for about half of South Korea’s GDP.

human: When a Swiss museum announced in September that it would be putting three paintings by Paul Cézanne, the Impressionist master, up for sale at auction, there was immediate protest by some who suggested the sale violated ethical guidelines on when institutions should sell off their works.
llm: When a Swiss museum decided to sell three paintings by Paul Cezanne, it was criticized for cashing in on the French artist’s legacy. But the institution says it had no choice. The paintings are “the only works we have of any real value,” said the director, Dagmar Trefzer. The Kunstmuseum Basel has been struggling financially since 2010, when its budget was cut amid government belt-tightening. Now, with new management and a revised strategy, the museum is taking steps to reinvent itself. In addition to the sale, which Ms. Trefzer hopes will raise about $8 million, the museum plans to refocus its collection on artists from Switzerland, Germany and Austria.

human: In August, a black bear bit a man who was camping in Colorado, officials released a statement about “bear activity” in Tennessee after one tried to find food in a car, and a grizzly attacked a man in Wyoming.
llm: In August, a mother bear and her cub were spotted swimming in the Hudson River, not far from New York City. They were later seen again on Long Island. (Photo: National Park Service)

human: The Senate will vote early next week on a bipartisan resolution condemning Hamas’s strikes on Israel and pledging to support the Jewish state’s war effort, said Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, who is spending the weekend meeting with Israeli officials to discuss the contours of a future assistance package.
llm: The Senate will vote on a resolution to support Israel's right to defend itself upon Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) returns from the Jewish state, according to reports.

human: Millions of people play Wordle every day, and share, discuss and debate how they tried to win.
llm: Millions of people use Wordle to create word clouds from their blogs and other text. In the past, I've used it to create word clouds from my blog posts. But now I'm looking at word clouds in a different way. Thanks to the folks over at the Internet Archive (and their Wayback Machine), I have access to all of the publicly available web pages that were published between January 1996 and March 2010. And thanks to Google Docs and Sheets, I can do some rudimentary analysis on those pages to see what words are most frequently found in them.

human: As it has done every year for the past seven straight decades, the Winter Show, the venerable arts and antiquities fair, which benefits the East Side House Settlement in the Bronx, has brought together an incredible range of objects, most of those years under the capacious roof of the Park Avenue Armory. A concert piano with a curved keyboard, designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly and built by Chris Maene. (Bernard Goldberg Fine Arts, LLC, C1). A couple of Bonnards for the foyer (Jill Newhouse Gallery, A7). A contemporary painter responding to Italian old masters (Robert Simon Fine Art, C10). A red, white and blue Centennial-year bird cage in the shape of the U.S. Capitol (Focus: Americana, curated by Alexandra Kirtley of the Philadelphia Museum of Art). What about a butter dish shaped like a bundle of asparagus (Michele Beiny, D1)? Or first editions of Edmund Spenser’s “The Faerie Queene” and “Leaves of Grass” (Peter Harrington, C12)?
llm: As it has for decades, New York's annual winter antiques show is bringing the world to America's doorstep, from exquisite miniature furniture to elaborate European decorative pieces to jewelry and other objets d'art. The 58th edition of the show runs through Sunday at the Park Avenue Armory, with more than 70 exhibitors offering works of art spanning several centuries and cultures.

human: Three Tacoma police officers who were acquitted in the death of Manuel Ellis, a Black man who died in police custody in 2020 after pleading that he could not breathe, will each receive $500,000 for resigning from the Tacoma Police Department, according to documents released by the city on Tuesday.
llm: Three Tacoma police officers involved in a fatal shooting of a black man in January will receive $500,000 each from the city to resign as part of an agreement reached this week with their attorneys.

human: As diplomats try to keep the fighting in the Israel-Hamas war from escalating, some business leaders are continuing to push back against institutions over where they stand on Israel.
llm: As diplomats try to work out a deal for peace between Israel and the Palestinians, Israel’s corporate defenders are growing louder. They are lobbying in Washington against efforts by some members of Congress who want to impose sanctions on Israel if it does not stop building settlements on land claimed by the Palestinians.

human: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest. One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination. Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity. Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.
llm: The complex dance of living

human: Three years after Bayer agreed to pay $10 billion to settle claims that its weedkiller, Roundup, caused cancer, juries continue to award plaintiffs in additional cases billions of dollars in damages, even as the German drug and chemicals giant insists it will continue its fight in court.
llm: Three years after buying Monsanto for $63 billion, Germany’s Bayer AG is still reeling from the deal. The company has taken a hit of more than 50 percent in its share price this year amid investor concern that it overpaid for the seed giant. And now comes another headache: billions of dollars in legal liabilities related to claims that Monsanto’s Roundup weedkiller causes cancer.

human: Security footage broadcast by state media showed the girl being carried unconscious off a subway train, but footage from inside the train has not been released.
llm: Security footage broadcast on state television showed the girl being pushed off the train by a woman wearing black and shouting, "Why are you going out without hijab?"

human: The United States carried out a new military strike against Houthi ballistic missiles in Yemen on Tuesday, the U.S. military said, but the latest salvo against the Iran-backed group left the White House grappling with how to stop a battle-hardened foe from disrupting shipping lanes critical for global trade.
llm: The United States military launched an air strike against al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) targets in Yemen for a third time this year, officials said on Friday. human: Jump into book discovery with this Title Search puzzle that hides the names of more than a dozen books about road trips and exploring new places.

human: An aqua blue light appeared on my outstretched palm, showing a menu. Slowly, I circled my wrist to scroll, pressing an index finger and thumb together in a pinching motion to select an item. I wanted to send a text message. The device on my sweater, a two-inch square magnetic pin from a start-up called Humane, let out a soft “clink.”
llm: An aqua blue, wavy-lined rectangle is all that’s left of the original picture — a ghostly imprint from the laser’s destruction. This isn’t an art project; it’s a way to test a new algorithm that can predict how a photo will look after being shredded by a laser pointer. The researchers behind this image have created a neural network that can predict what a photo would look like if it had been blasted with a laser. It was trained on 150 photos, each of which had been subjected to different patterns of light. Now, they want to know whether their algorithm could be used to improve cameras on smartphones or other devices.

human: Gabe Amo, a former White House staff member who worked in the Biden and Obama administrations, on Tuesday became the first Black person to represent Rhode Island in the U.S. Congress, according to The Associated Press.
llm: Gabe Amo, a 32-year-old black activist and community leader in Providence, R.I., has won the Democratic primary for the state’s first congressional district, making him the frontrunner to become Rhode Island’s first African American representative.

human: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in selected areas of northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, a White House spokesman said.
llm: Israel has agreed to extend the lulls in Gaza for another 24 hours.

human: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet. “The genre is rooted in my land,” she said, in a video call from her place just outside Madrid. “It’s in our roots.”
llm: When the Spanish-born singer María José Llergo sings in her native tongue, it sounds as if she is about to cry. Her voice quivers and shakes, and the sound of her singing fills up your whole body. She does this while accompanying herself on guitar with dexterity, but without flashiness or showiness.

human: The elected school board in Sarasota, Fla., took the rare step on Tuesday of calling for the resignation of one of its own members, the latest development in an ongoing scandal involving a power couple in state Republican politics.
llm: The elected school board in Broward County, Fla., has asked one of its members to resign after he was arrested for allegedly soliciting sex from an undercover police officer.

llm: A North Dakota woman is accused of fatally poisoning her boyfriend with antifreeze to collect on his life insurance policy. She has been charged with murder, conspiracy to commit murder and a host of other charges. The boyfriend's mother also faces charges in the case. Prosecutors allege that the woman killed her boyfriend by giving him drinks containing antifreeze over several days. The alleged crime was discovered when the boyfriend's mother found an empty bottle of antifreeze at his house. The mother then contacted authorities. human: Former President Donald Trump won the New Hampshire primary, but Nikki Haley said the race is far from over.
llm: Former President Donald J. Trump has been impeached by the U.S. House of Representatives and will face trial in the Senate, a historic vote that could end his presidency or backfire on Democrats. human: The next few weeks of the war in Gaza may be especially important because the Biden administration is pressuring Israel to shift to a less intensive approach by late January. In today’s newsletter, I’ll explain what both Israel and Hamas hope to accomplish between now and then.
llm: The next few days were a blur. I was in and out of the hospital, and they kept me on morphine to keep my pain down. At one point I woke up from surgery to see an Israeli soldier with his rifle pointed at my face. He seemed very young, about seventeen or eighteen years old, and he had a frightened look in his eyes. I wondered if he knew how much pain I was in. He didn't speak English, but I could tell that he was trying to communicate something important by pointing his weapon at me and making strange sounds in Hebrew.

human: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise. In between, there are lonely nights, fleeting joys, ordinary degradations, laborious work, karaoke reveries, many cigarettes and more drinks. A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs. Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.
llm: Modestly scaled and quietly observant, “Fallen Leaves” is an ode to a certain kind of life — not necessarily lived well but with unwavering commitment. That applies equally to its characters, whose romantic entanglements are as tangled as their pasts, and to the film itself, which was shot over six years on the fly by the prolific French director Michel Gondry, best known for his music videos and feature films like “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.”

human: The Supreme Court declined today to decide whether Donald Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. Instead, the case will move forward in an appeals court and will most likely return to the Supreme Court in the coming months.
llm: The Supreme Court won’t be fast-tracking the appeal of a lower court decision that found President Donald Trump can’t block his critics from seeing his Twitter feed. The justices said Friday they won’t hear an emergency appeal by the president to put the case on a faster track to a final ruling. That means the case is unlikely to be decided before the midterm elections in November.

human: Democrats in New Jersey retained a comfortable majority in the General Assembly and the State Senate in Tuesday’s legislative races.
llm: Democrats in New Jersey are celebrating a major victory in the state’s legislature, where they retained their 24-16 advantage over Republicans after several hard fought races this election cycle.

human: As one urban gardener after another beseeched Cherelle Parker to prevent the green spaces that they had spent years nurturing from being gobbled up by developers, she furiously took notes in her trademark spiral notebook and barely said a word.
llm: As one urban school reformer says, “The question is not whether to expand charters. It is how to do so in a way that makes sense for the system as a whole.” This article from The Atlantic highlights some of the issues cities are facing as they look to increase their charter school seats and includes comments from CREDO's research director Margaret Raymond.

human: On July 18, 2021, the day Patrick Alan Pennel was supposed to meet Margaret Ann Kretzmer for a first date, he canceled to spend time with someone else he was getting to know. When Ms. Kretzmer offered to meet him the following day instead, he said OK but brought the other girl along.
llm: On July 18, 2017, The New York Times published an article that focused on how the American Kennel Club (AKC) is helping singles find love by hosting their "Meet and Compete" events. These events allow singles to meet one another while watching their dogs compete in various AKC-sanctioned dog sports. According to the article, these events have proven successful for singles who want to date someone with similar interests.

human: In the next few months, as the weather warms in Washington, something remarkable could happen in the city’s federal courthouse: Donald J. Trump could become the first former president in U.S. history to sit through a trial as a criminal defendant.
llm: In the next few months, we can expect more investigations of Trump's financial dealings. In addition to the Mueller investigation, there is a federal criminal probe into whether Michael Cohen committed bank fraud, wire fraud or campaign finance violations by making hush-money payments to Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal.

human: OpenAI is in talks to complete a deal that would value the company at $80 billion or more, nearly triple its valuation less than six months ago, according to a person with knowledge of the discussions.
llm: OpenAI is in talks with a consortium of investors that could lead to the artificial intelligence startup being valued at more than $80 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

human: Two prisoners in upstate New York say they were brutally beaten by guards and taken to a different facility to be waterboarded — a method of torture once used by C.I.A. interrogators on terrorism suspects, according to newly filed lawsuits.
llm: Two prisoners in the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City were subjected to beatings by guards that left them with serious injuries, according to a pair of lawsuits filed Thursday. One prisoner alleges that he was waterboarded by officers as punishment for his failure to cooperate with their requests during an interrogation. The two men allege that they were denied medical treatment after being beaten up by guards. They also say they were not afforded due process before they were placed in solitary confinement. “The violence is rampant,” said Jonathan Cohen, a lawyer representing one of the plaintiffs. “It’s a culture of impunity.” Read more

human: With grand estates and rolling meadows, this Somerset County borough has long attracted the wealthy. But now it’s courting less affluent buyers.
llm: With grand estates and a historic downtown district, this New Jersey borough is just 30 miles west of Manhattan. The town has long been known for its fine restaurants and shops, but the area also offers cultural attractions such as the Morris Museum, the Giralda Farms Arts Center and the Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey. Residents enjoy access to local farmer's markets, parks and open spaces, and recreational activities including hiking, bicycling, swimming and golfing.

human: Odds are that this winter’s going to be a wet one.
llm: Odds are that the upcoming winter will be warmer than average, with below-average precipitation in much of southern and eastern California. That’s because El Niño is expected to continue through at least winter 2015-16. In fact, according to the latest forecast from NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center, there is a 90 percent chance that El Niño conditions will persist into next year.

human: It was a cold evening in December 2018, and Nadine Arslanian, the soon-to-be wife of Senator Robert Menendez, was zipping through the darkened streets of suburban New Jersey in a black Mercedes-Benz sedan. She would later tell the police she did not see the man stepping out in front of her to cross a busy thoroughfare.
llm: It was a fatal crash. The driver of one vehicle died. Another man fled the scene, according to court documents.

human: Members of the United Automobile Workers union have given their backing to new contracts with the three big U.S. automakers, agreements that deliver hefty wage increases and other gains that had eluded the union for more than 20 years.
llm: Members of the United Auto Workers union voted this week to approve new contracts with Ford, General Motors and Fiat Chrysler. This is good news for those who hope that Detroit's auto industry will continue to be a powerhouse in American manufacturing. The deals are all expected to be ratified by the companies’ boards of directors within weeks. They include wage increases, bonuses, promises to hire more workers and commitments to invest billions of dollars in their factories. (CNN)

human: For a decade, it was easy to get help repairing an iPhone. Cracked screens could be replaced in minutes, and broken cameras could be exchanged without a hitch.
llm: For a decade, Apple has built its business around the idea that it can sell users access to its software and services. But with iOS 7, the company is taking that model a step further by tightening its control over what you do on your phone.

human: The origin of this seasonal slasher is in an ersatz trailer the horror filmmaker Eli Roth made for the portmanteau movie “Grindhouse” in 2007. The two lurid features directed by Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino were separated by a series of teasers for imaginary movies concocted by like-minded pals of the filmmakers, also including Rob Zombie and Edgar Wright. Believe it or not, Roth’s feature-length version of “Thanksgiving” is the third such trailer to get its Pinocchio-esque real-movie wish.
llm: The origin of the turkey as a Thanksgiving staple is unknown. However, it has been suggested that Pilgrims brought domesticated turkeys to America from England.

human: Details of a sexual assault allegation against the chairman of the Florida Republican Party in an affidavit from state authorities are fueling turmoil within the party.
llm: Details of a sexual assault allegation against the chairman of the Republican Party in Florida are emerging, and could further roil an already tumultuous state party. The woman who made the accusation, Katherine Prudhomme-O’Brien, said that she was at a fundraiser for Mr. Trump when she met Mr. Lewandowski, who was then running his presidential campaign. Ms. Prudhomme-O’Brien said that Mr. Lewandowski asked her for her phone number and that he called her later that night and invited her to meet him at a bar near her home in Tallahassee.

human: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 5,000-square-foot home built in 1952, with a two-story foyer, hardwood floors, a bright open floor plan for dining and living with a wood-burning fireplace, an eat-in kitchen with custom cabinetry and Caesarstone quartz countertops, a family room with beamed ceilings that is open to a screened-in porch and an outdoor patio with a pergola, a first-floor en suite primary bedroom with a fireplace and radiant-heat bathroom floors, a laundry room, a mudroom, an office, a bonus room and an oversized three-car garage, on 1.83 acres. llm: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 10-acre estate in East Hampton, listed by Prudential Douglas Elliman at $29 million.

human: In September, I went to see Counting Crows, a band whose music formed the soundtrack of my adolescence. The people alongside me at the Greek Theater at the University of California, Berkeley, were mainly in their 40s and 50s; people who might have had a babysitter waiting at home, or a slightly achy back. llm: In September, I had the pleasure of interviewing a very talented singer/songwriter by the name of Sara Watkins. Sara is one-third of the folk rock band Nickel Creek and has released two solo albums: 2009's "Sun Midnight Sun" and 2012's "Sun Midnight Sun". She recently wrapped up her tour with The Decemberists and has announced her next tour which will start in January 2015. We spoke about music festivals, the importance of music education for young children, her experience on The Voice and much more!

human: It is a truth universally acknowledged that meat tastes better when seasoned ahead. Even a brief 20-minute rest with a sprinkle of salt will help bring out the best in most cuts. human: On a barren swath of land in the Sahara, U.S. Air Base 201 stands far from public sight, on the outskirts of a remote city in one of the world’s poorest countries, its role more elusive than ever since its completion nearly six years ago.
llm: On a barren patch of desert in Niger’s southwestern corner sits one of the most important military bases for American operations across West Africa and the Sahel: Agadez. The base is home to about 100 troops from the 3rd Special Forces Group who advise local forces fighting Boko Haram militants. It also hosts an airfield that has become increasingly vital for the United States as it steps up drone strikes against Islamic State affiliates in Libya and carries out surveillance flights over Mali, where French forces are battling jihadists.

human: Samantha Harvey features two famous artworks in her poetic fifth novel, “Orbital.” One is Diego Velázquez’s enduring 1656 masterpiece, “Las Meninas.” The second is a 1969 photograph taken by the astronaut Michael Collins of the lunar module Eagle, carrying Buzz Aldrin and Neil Armstrong back from the moon, with Earth in the background. Collins is literally the only person in the world not in the image.
llm: Samantha Harvey features on The New York Times, June 14, 2018. Samantha's book The Western Wind was published by Pantheon Books in April 2018. Read more about The Western Wind here.

human: President Biden pulled a red United Automobile Workers T-shirt over his button-down on Thursday and celebrated a landmark labor deal that kept a Stellantis manufacturing plant in business, using an appearance in Illinois to shore up crucial union support.
llm: President Biden pulled out all the stops to shore up support from organized labor at a big rally Friday night in Chicago. He spoke with a fire and passion that I have not heard since he was elected Vice President. And as he has done many times before, he showed how effective he is when he speaks without a script.

human: Margot Polivy, a high school physical education teacher turned lawyer who tirelessly lobbied the federal government to legally guarantee that college athletic departments offer women equal opportunities to participate in sports, died on Oct. 7 at her home in Washington. She was 85.
llm: Margot Polivy, a pioneer for women in college athletics who coached the University of Maryland field hockey team to its first national championship in 1976 and later served as an administrator with the NCAA and the American Volleyball Coaches Association, died Dec. 20 at her home in Columbia, Md. She was 85.

human: Last week a self-described Jewish conservative named Charles Weber took to X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, to address the “cowards hiding behind the anonymity of the internet and posting ‘Hitler was right.’” Weber dared those trolls to “say it to our faces.” One X user took him up on it.
llm: Last week a number of prominent Jewish leaders including Rabbi Shmuley Boteach and Mort Klein (president of the Zionist Organization of America) came out in support of Tesla founder Elon Musk. The reason? Because Musk has spoken out against artificial intelligence and has said that he is afraid it could destroy humanity.

human: “The Color Purple,” a new musical take on Alice Walker’s landmark novel, seemed to arrive as an instant hit.
llm: “The Color Purple,” which received an overwhelmingly positive reception from critics, opened in third place behind the holdovers “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story” and “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them.” The film earned a mediocre $8.7 million on 2,150 screens for a per-screen average of just under $4,000 — a very disappointing number for a movie with Oscar buzz, even when you consider it opened against two big blockbusters.

human: Adan Canto, the Mexican actor known for his roles on television series including “The Cleaning Lady” and “Designated Survivor,” as well as for playing the superhero Sunspot in the film “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” died on Monday. He was 42.
llm: Adan Canto, the actor best known for his roles in Fox's X-Men franchise and Netflix's The Punisher, has died. He was 42.

human: For soup enthusiasts across America, the post-Thanksgiving turkey broth can be as sacred as the holiday meal itself. Leftover turkey soup is a cozy way to keep Thanksgiving’s bountiful spirit going for several more meals.
