human: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, John Carpenter’s groundbreaking shocker comes out on top. But Carpenter was prophetic with narrative choices that horror now takes for granted: a masked killing-machine villain, a strong-willed final girl next door, creatively depicted deaths, touches of dark comedy. (And a score that sounds like a chase.) Together they make “Halloween” my top Halloween treat.
llm: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, I never know how to answer. Because there are so many great ones that it's really hard for me to pick just one. But if you're looking for a classic that will give you a good scare and maybe make you jump out of your seat once or twice, here are 25 suggestions of the best horror movies to stream on Netflix right now:

human: Poetry makes nothing happen, W.H. Auden said in 1939, when words must have seemed especially impotent; but cinema is another matter. For several decades after the end of the Second World War, what’s come to be seen as its central catastrophe — the near-total destruction of the European Jews — was consigned to the status of a footnote. The neglect was rooted in guilt: Many nations eagerly collaborated in the killing, while others did nothing to prevent it. Consumed by their own suffering, most people simply didn’t want to know, and a conspiracy of silence was established.
llm: Poetry makes nothing happen. — Auden

human: It was clear from the start that House Republicans would struggle to govern this year given their deep ideological divisions, narrow majority and myriad personal feuds and grudges. They've had three choices fall through already and it looks like this one won't work either. It would seem that the only way out of this mess for them is to take a deep breath, regroup and find someone who can actually win an election.

human: Last year was the warmest in recorded history. The graphic artists of the environmental movement tried to warn us. Whatever their approach — bright, witty, somber, blunt, even sexy — they sought an image, a phrase, that could change enough minds to literally save the world.

human: For my entire professional life, I have started nearly every weekday morning with an extremely important productivity ritual: I make a coffee, I sit down at my computer, and I mess around on the internet for an hour or so. And, for most of my career as a writer, this has been an effortless task. I’ve had accounts on dozens of social networks, message boards and online communities thronging with similarly bored and truant peers, vibrant with creativity and delight. Or, at least, with tolerably decent jokes.
llm: For my entire life, I have known no other way to live than with the Internet. It has been a part of me since birth and for that reason it is hard for me to understand what it must be like to grow up without it. The Internet has shaped the lives of millennials more than anything else in our generation; therefore it is interesting to see how many people are beginning to view this new digital age as less than perfect. We’re getting older and we know that there is so much more out there for us than just our phones, but is anyone willing to let go? human: For over a year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz. llm: For over a decade, I've been teaching jazz piano to college students at the University of New Orleans. One of my favorite activities is to take one of my favorite musicians and have students transcribe their solos, in order to get deeper into the music and better understand the techniques that make them great. The first time I did this with Thelonious Monk, it took about 10 minutes for me to fall head-over-heels in love with his playing. It was one of those "Wow!" moments where you realize that something you thought was good turns out to be great.

human: Before she died in 2013, Dolours Price, a Provisional Irish Republican Army guerrilla, started granting interviews. She described planting I.R.A. bombs and driving people to their executions, smuggling explosives and going on hunger strike in a British prison.
llm: Before she died, I told my mother that if she was going to leave me anything in her will, it would have to be something of value. Otherwise, I wasn’t interested. When I got the call from my brother telling me she had left me a house (along with her other four children), I was shocked and dismayed. I could think of nothing worse than moving into someone else’s home. What if they didn’t like my decorating? Or my pets? Or my children? It was not an ideal situation, but I decided to take advantage of a good deal when I saw one and moved myself and my family into this new place.

human: Bella Cummins has run Bella’s Hacienda Ranch, her Nevada brothel, for nearly four decades — and for four decades, she’s been shunned by much of the banking industry.

human: When it comes to movies, we live in a high-concept world. Whether you’re a Marvel movie or a microbudget indie, you’ve got to sell moviegoers on a premise that can cut through the content and get them into a theater.

So far, this year's Sundance has been an interesting mix of highs and lows for me personally. In other words, there have been plenty of buoys, but not so many satellites.

human: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors. Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets. A forest becomes manicured bushes. A lake becomes a pool.
llm: Hollywood horror often relies on jump scares and gore to get a rise out of the audience. In some cases, this is effective, but in others it can come off as tired or overdone. Night Swim is not afraid to take its time and really explore what it means to be frightened. The film takes place in an abandoned swimming pool where two sisters are trying to get their lives back on track after losing their parents in a car accident. Their plan for recovery? Going skinny dipping every night at midnight. This plan soon goes awry when they realize that something sinister has been watching them from below the surface.

llm: Zvi Zamir, who served as the head of Israel’s Mossad intelligence agency during some of its most crucial missions, including the capture and killing of a top Nazi war criminal, died on Wednesday. He was 98.

The odor in the summer is terrible. We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone. The kittens are cute, their cries not so much. What can we do?

human: I write these lines from Jerusalem, after spending time with the families of some of the 240 people kidnapped by Hamas terrorists on Oct. 7. The hostages now held in Gaza include Jewish Israelis, Muslim Israelis and foreign citizens of different ethnicities.
llm: I write these lines as the war in Gaza continues, with no end in sight. We are aware that there are those who do not understand how Israel can be expected to accept a reality in which thousands of rockets are being shot at us, aimed at our homes and cities. We do not see ourselves as occupiers, but rather as a people whose history has been one long struggle against persecution, exile and attempts to destroy us. human: Amid growing despair and rage, Arab countries including Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt are intensifying their appeals to the U.S. to pressure Israel for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza. Failure to do so, they say, risks sabotaging the security of the entire Middle East.

human: The moon stands alone. It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found. And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships. But that is about to change.
llm: The moon stands alone in our solar system as a world that has been thoroughly mapped and studied. But in spite of all we've learned, it still holds many mysteries. What are those strange craters on its surface? How did they get there? The moon's origins remain controversial, but one thing is certain: Its future is in our hands. In this sweeping narrative history—encompassing art, literature, religion, folklore, mythology, film, space exploration, and scientific theory—Karen Rugh takes us from the dawn of humanity through the present day, examining how humans have viewed and understood the moon throughout time. From the first cave drawings of the heavens to modern astronomy and astrophysics, she explores what

human: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.
llm: Eight years ago, the Obama administration made its first public case for a drone strike on an American citizen. It was then-Attorney General Eric Holder who delivered the news: Anwar al-Awlaki had been killed in Yemen by an unmanned aircraft. The killing of the cleric and propagandist, who had become a leading recruiter for Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, was not only legal but “fully consistent with our values as Americans,” Holder declared. He added that “the Constitution does not protect those who fight against this country.”

We call on the Government of Iran to release Ms. Sotoudeh immediately and unconditionally.

human: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation — good that will extend far beyond the realm of criminal justice. With a 2020 law finally taking full effect, people who are incarcerated can for the first time in decades get Pell Grants, the federal tuition aid for low-income students. The grants are small, but they are critical to rebuilding one of the most important tools we have to reduce crime and mitigate the harms of mass incarceration: college education.
llm: A change taking place on the inside is just as important to a prisoner's rehabilitation and reentry into society as any work that happens outside of prison walls. While it can be easy for those who have not spent time behind bars to discount or ignore the importance of spirituality, religious institutions are playing an integral role in changing the lives of prisoners across the nation. This was certainly true for me. I am certain my life would look very different today had I not been given the opportunity to find Christ while incarcerated.

human: The agony came in waves as the wounded Ukrainian soldier in the back of the ambulance slipped in and out of consciousness. The driver, hurtling past cratered fields on roads thick with mud, was racing to escape Russian artillery fire north of the city of Avdiivka, while hoping he was not spotted by drones.
llm: The agony came in a few seconds. The Ukrainian soldier had been standing guard near the front line in eastern Ukraine when he was struck by a shell blast that ripped through his torso and blew out his back. He lay there for 20 minutes, screaming in pain. Then another soldier heard him and dragged him away from the battlefield, where he could be treated. By then it was too late. When the medics opened up his chest, they found that his heart had stopped pumping blood some time before. He died instantly.

human: As dinner tables and snack menus feature far more chicken and cheese, farms are expanding where water is scarce.
llm: As dinner tables around the country are laden with turkey, stuffing and pumpkin pie this weekend, consider that the meat, grains and other food on those plates will ultimately end up in your drinking water. That may not sound appetizing, but it’s a reality of the American diet: Meat production produces large amounts of manure; corn is used to feed animals and humans alike; and most people eat some form of grain every day. All of these things take a toll on our groundwater supplies. It’s an issue that has been growing for decades, but it is only recently gaining attention from farmers, scientists and policymakers. llm: In a subterranean passageway beneath the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah, Israeli soldiers uncovered what they said on Friday was evidence of Hamas cells and hostages being held in tunnels.

human: Their pink bodies began to wash ashore last month, startling locals and scientists in the remote Amazon town of Tefé, Brazil, who had never seen anything like it. A crippling drought had sucked parts of tributaries flowing into the Amazon River nearly dry, causing some water routes to become impassible and turning other shallow areas into a hot bath.
llm: Their pink bodies floating in the water, hundreds of freshwater dolphins washed up on India's coastline, dying from poisoning. The culprit: cyanide-laced mining waste that polluted the waters they swim through, turning them into what locals described as a hot "soup" and killing hundreds of fish.

human: The Senate on Tuesday took the first step in advancing a stopgap spending bill to avoid a partial government shutdown at the end of the week, buying time to enact a broader bipartisan funding agreement for the remainder of the year.
llm: The Senate on Wednesday advanced a stopgap bill that would prevent the government from shutting down at midnight, with Republicans and Democrats coming together in a rare show of unity to keep the lights on for another two weeks. The 78-22 vote came after a deal between Democratic leaders and Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.), who had threatened to filibuster the short-term spending measure unless it contained more money for the military. Mr. Paul’s demands were met through the use of an obscure parliamentary maneuver called “vote-a-rama,” which allows senators to offer amendments by voice vote.

human: Guy Stern, who fled rising antisemitism in Nazi Germany at 15 for a new life in the United States but returned to Europe during World War II as a member of a military intelligence program that trained him to interrogate prisoners of war, died on Dec. 7 in West Bloomfield, Mich. He was 101.
llm: Guy Stern, who fled Germany in 1938 as a Jew to escape the Nazi persecution that killed his father and sister, and then became an American citizen to interrogate some of the most notorious Nazi war criminals after World War II, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 101.

human: The grandfather always feared this day would come.
llm: The grandfather always said that Afghanistan was a land of extremes. In the north, he told me, there were mountains so high they would make your head spin, and in the south there were deserts so hot you could fry eggs on them. It was a country where people who had never met before would suddenly become best friends. The women were beautiful and kind, but if their husbands even looked at another woman, they'd be shot dead by her brothers.

human: I was irritated as I drove west from Nashville. At least I’m not heading east, I kept reminding myself, stuck behind one big rig trying to pass another on a steep mountain incline. On the flat lands of West Tennessee, even eighteen-wheelers can pass going 90 miles an hour.
llm: I was irritated when I read this in the NYT: "This is a very small, very personal essay that has to do with my own family and our lives. It’s not about immigration or politics." But then, it's also not an "essay," strictly speaking. If you're going to publish something like this, at least call it what it is. (And the first sentence of the piece should be rephrased.)

human: Are you a fan of comic books and superhero movies? Have you seen every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe? Do you eagerly mark your calendar when the latest release date is announced? Or are you growing a little tired of the genre?
llm: Are you a fan of superhero movies? I'm not. And here's why: The genre has been saturated for so long that it's become impossible to tell the stories apart. Each one is just an iteration on the last, and they all feel like remakes or sequels. There are too many characters running around, each with their own movie franchise, and the storylines have become tired. The Marvel Universe is full of heroes who aren't particularly likable, and yet we're supposed to care about them because they're fighting the bad guys. But what if the bad guys were the good guys? Wouldn't it be more interesting if the Avengers fought to protect us from them instead of the other way around? What if the

human: I started making this short documentary as a response to my mom developing dementia in her early 60s and forgetting how to read a knitting pattern. After years of having her knit for me, I taught myself how to knit by watching YouTube tutorials. As I learned more, and my mom’s health declined, I began to understand the solace that knitting brings.
llm: I started making my own yarn a few months ago. I’m currently knitting an afghan with the yarn that I have spun and plied. It is amazing! I am loving it so much more than when I was just using commercially made yarns. My hands are soft and strong and I feel very close to nature as I spin the fibers from their raw state into something usable. There’s just no comparison between the feeling of my homemade yarn and the stuff you can buy at a store. I’ll be posting about this experience on my blog soon, but for now…I’d love to connect with anyone who shares in this experience.

human: When Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said this week that he was not likely to call a general election in Britain before the second half of the year, he was trying to douse fevered speculation that he might go to the voters as early as May. But in doing so, he set up another tantalizing prospect: that Britain and the United States could hold elections within days or weeks of each other this fall.
llm: When Prime Minister Tony Blair said he would step down as Britain's leader by September 2007, it was widely assumed that his successor would be in place at least a year before the next U.S. presidential election. But now, with Mr. Blair's departure potentially coming within weeks of the November vote, his party is scrambling to put together an electoral plan that will allow a new prime minister to take office and make his or her mark on British politics.

human: Global oil prices jumped yesterday after the energy giant BP said it had stopped sending tankers through the Red Sea. The route has become increasingly dangerous since the Houthi armed group began attacking ships with drones and missiles.

human: It’s good to be back! llm: It’s good to be back, and I can’t wait for you to hear the new songs! They’re all available on iTunes now.

human: Daphne Caruana Galizia was both famous and infamous in Malta, an in-your-face journalist who wrote that “the greatest enemy of freedom of expression” is fear, for it leads to “the dangerous situation where individuals are gagged.” Being gagged was the last thing Caruana Galizia could tolerate. Ultimately, fearlessness got her killed.
llm: Daphne Caruana Galizia, a Maltese journalist who had been investigating money laundering and corruption on the island nation, was killed in an automobile bombing on Monday. The 53-year-old reporter had written about her fears of being murdered before she died. In this article from October 2017, Lizzie O’Leary wrote about how Daphne Caruana Galizia spoke truth to power — until she was killed for it.

human: The holiday season is around the corner, and there are so many beloved rituals and traditions to look forward to.
llm: The holiday season is supposed to be filled with warmth, joy and love. But for many people, it can also bring stress, conflict and drama. This week on The New American Farmers Podcast, we’ll talk about how to manage family dynamics during the holidays. Our guest is Dr. Jennifer Powell-Lunder, an associate professor of psychology at Penn State University and author of several books on communication. She offers tips on how to handle tough conversations with your relatives over Thanksgiving dinner, plus advice on managing other difficult situations like when your in-laws drop by unannounced or you discover your dad’s girlfriend is not what you expected. Listen now: https://anchor.fm/thenewamericanfarmers

human: Priorities USA, one of the biggest liberal super PACs, will not run a single television advertisement in the 2024 election cycle.

llm: A near-total communications blackout has descended over the Gaza Strip, with telephone lines down and only one of three cellular companies still providing service. In addition to the humanitarian crisis that is mounting, Gazans are also being denied access to information. The Israeli military began blocking phone calls in the first few days of its offensive, and cut most of the power supply on Dec. 29. Calls from Gaza to Israel were blocked by Dec. 30, leaving only about half of Gaza's population with landlines able to call out. Cell phones have been more resilient, but all of them are dependent upon Israel's Bezeq International Ltd., which provides the connection to the outside world through cables running underneath the Mediterrane

human: For the members of Brooklyn’s Aleppan Jewish community, the tinier the meat- or cheese-filled pastry, the better the cook.
llm: For the members of my extended family, it was a staple.

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance. Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen. What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers. “Everyone is a cook,” he said. “They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.” There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations. They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade. The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is). The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison. Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area. The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style. The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement. Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel. On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations. (Opens Wednesday)
llm: Some new restaurants are worth the wait. For two years, chef and co-founder of Noma, Claus Meyer, has been building up to his first New York venture, Agern, located in Grand Central Terminal’s dining concourse. The Danish restaurant offers an upscale interpretation of Scandinavian cuisine and features sustainable ingredients from around the world.

human: Over the course of a few days this week, we got two pretty remarkable data points for the 2024 election.
llm: Over the course of his 40-year career in politics, Joe Biden has never been one for calm. He’s known for being emotional and impassioned. In fact, many people who have worked with him say that he is more likely to get angry than sad. When you combine this tendency with the fact that he has been running a campaign that often seems to be struggling against itself, it doesn’t come as much of a surprise that he would lash out at what he perceived as an unfair attack on his son Beau. What does come as a bit of a surprise, however, is how Biden’s response is now causing his campaign trouble. Read More >>

human: When readers receive their annual copy of Puzzle Mania in the Sunday edition of The New York Times, very often their first thought is, How am I going to get this done? We offered some helpful ways to approach this humongous labor of love in this article, but we asked that no one post any spoilers in the comments.
llm: When readers receive a new book in the mail, they're excited to read it. As soon as they crack open the cover and begin reading, they are instantly disappointed if there is not an epic story waiting for them. If the story isn't good enough to keep them interested, they will put the book down and never pick it up again. However, when the story is so captivating that the reader can't put it down, they will spend hours reading into the wee hours of the morning. That is why it is important to have great writing skills. This skill allows writers to create interesting stories that will capture their audience's attention. The Super Mega Support Group by Drew Tewksbury does just that.

human: With plagiarism in the news, here are five novels that show it's an engrossing plot device, too.
llm: With plagiarism in the news again, here are some novels that have dealt with the subject.

human: It’s a numinous blue that suggests the sky, the sea, the infinite. It’s a field — poetic and abstract — that sets off the eloquence of dancing bodies. The cerulean backdrop associated with the ballets of George Balanchine and New York City Ballet has come to seem so natural a setting for plotless ballet that we barely notice it.
llm: It’s a numinous, dreamlike space that makes you think of the first time you saw a ballet—that moment when you realized how much there was to see in this strange new world. And that’s why I love it.

human: The top Republican Senate campaign group filed a brief on Wednesday with the United States Supreme Court in support of Donald J. Trump’s appeal of a Colorado ruling blocking him from the state’s presidential ballot. It is the latest sign of the rallying effect that the former president’s legal woes are having on his party.
llm: The top Republican on the U.S. Senate Rules Committee filed a brief on Thursday supporting President-elect Donald J. Trump's challenge to a recount in Michigan that was ordered by the state's highest court.

human: The first several minutes of Adrian Murray’s cringe comedy take place in a single, uninterrupted shot. Framed from behind, Molly (Molly Reisman), a 20-something woman in Toronto, and her new housemate, wait in a car by the side of the road as a cop issues Molly a ticket for reckless driving. Even as the film eventually moves on to multiple other locations, including Molly’s apartment, her office and her ex-boyfriend’s home, we never truly leave those initial minutes in the car. The incident takes over Molly’s entire life as she becomes increasingly obsessed with fighting the ticket — re-enacting the scenario repeatedly, doing the rounds of traffic court and talking her friends’ and co-workers’ ears off about the wrongs of the system.
llm: The first several minutes of the film are in French, but once the action moves to a small town on the border between France and Spain, all is subtitled. In this 2017 Cannes entry, a young boy (Adan Alonso) sees his mother die at the hands of her husband and his father (played by Jean-Louis Trintignant) vows revenge. It's an exciting thriller that has been compared to the films of Michael Haneke, with its slow burn tension and twist ending.

human: When around a dozen reporters and editors on The New York Times’s Well desk sat around a long table in a conference room in July to brainstorm ideas for a challenge readers could complete to jump-start their 2024, a variety of suggestions were thrown out: How to live a more joyful life. A week’s worth of decluttering exercises. A relationship challenge.
llm: When around a third of the U.S. population is considered overweight or obese, and two-thirds are not getting enough exercise, health and fitness clubs are growing rapidly in popularity. In fact, the global market for such facilities is expected to reach $150 billion by 2017, according to research from IBISWorld. But with so many options available, how do you choose which one is right for you? Here's what to look for when shopping around:

human: When she was in her early teens, Rokhaya Diagne would retreat to her brother’s room, where she played online computer games for hours, day after day, until her mother finally got fed up.
llm: When she was in high school, Jessica Silver wanted nothing more than to play video games and hang out with her friends at the mall. But when she started college at Columbia University, she discovered a new passion: fighting malaria.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump filed an emergency request to a federal appeals court on Thursday seeking to lift the gag order imposed on him in the criminal case in which he stands accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election.
llm: Lawyers for former Democratic National Committee staffer Imran Awan, who is accused of stealing equipment from the House of Representatives, said that their client had been unfairly singled out by Republicans as part of an effort to smear Hillary Clinton. The lawyers filed a motion on Wednesday to lift a gag order imposed on Awan after his arrest last month.

human: Cari Beauchamp, a political adviser turned historian who documented the overlooked story of women in early Hollywood, when the film industry’s chaotic beginnings allowed them to assert a surprising amount of power, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 74.
llm: Cari Beauchamp, a historian who wrote about the early years of Hollywood and the roles of women in film, died on June 19. She was 74. Her death was confirmed by her brother, Paul Beauchamp. Ms. Beauchamp, whose given name was Carolyn Beauchamp, was born on Aug. 28, 1945, in New York City, where she attended the High School of Music and Art and later Barnard College. After graduation, she moved to Los Angeles and worked as a waitress while pursuing an acting career. She appeared in episodes of the television series “The Mod Squad” and “Hec Ramsey.” In addition, she had parts in movies like “Beyond the Valley of the Doll

human: When Maira Khan’s boyfriend left her last year, she was desperate to win him back. “I knew he was seeing someone else, but I didn’t know how serious it was,” said Ms. Khan, an influencer in Toronto. “I kind of just wanted her gone.”
llm: When Maira Khan’s husband lost his job in 2016, she started selling witchcraft-themed merchandise online. Now her shop is thriving, thanks to the rise of Instagram and TikTok.

human: Former President Donald J. Trump declared in the first rally of his 2024 presidential campaign: “I am your retribution.” He later vowed to use the Justice Department to go after his political adversaries, starting with President Biden and his family.
llm: Former President Donald Trump, left, sits with his sons Eric Trump, center, and Donald Trump Jr., right, during the final day of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)

human: An urgent bid by the Biden administration to send a fresh infusion of money to Ukraine for its war against Russia has stalled on Capitol Hill as congressional Republicans demand sweeping changes to the immigration system.
llm: An urgent bid to save the North American Free Trade Agreement is underway, with key lawmakers from both parties saying they expect Congress to approve President Trump's revised deal. The agreement would require approval by Congress before it can take effect.

human: The sounds of battle echo on both sides of Israel’s northern border with Lebanon. Sirens blare in Israeli towns, warning of incoming rockets fired by Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group. Lebanese civilians have fled their villages, fearing Israeli shelling and the possibility of a new war.
llm: The sounds of warfare are getting louder.

human: Nearly $900,000 is guaranteed to be awarded to the top finishers in this year’s New York City Marathon, and additional prize money could be distributed if athletes break course records.
llm: Nearly $900,000 is on offer in the 12-day tournament. The first-place team gets about $485,000, while the runners up pocket roughly $176,000.

human: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
llm: Welcome to a new series, in which I try to guess what the New York Times will be writing about teens in the future. Let's see how well I do!

human: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention. But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions. High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.
llm: The lament is not about the evils of fracking or climate change. The author, Michael Mann, a professor at Penn State University, says his goal is to help people understand how the forces of misinformation and propaganda are working against efforts to slow global warming. He says it's time for those who care about climate change to fight back by getting informed themselves and then educating others.

human: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon. She was 45.
llm: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese singer whose music mixed pop and traditional sounds from Cape Verde and beyond, died on Saturday in Lisbon. She was 45.

human: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx. These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
llm: Most prescriptions in the United States are paid for by health insurance, but there's no shortage of horror stories about patients who have been charged more than their plan allows. Here's what we want you to do: Tell us your story and let us know if you filed a complaint with your state or federal agencies, and if so, how that went. If you don't know the name of the drug, just describe it as best you can.

human: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made. “The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain. The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
llm: “Beyond Utopia,” a group show at the Center for Architecture, explores how architects envision new communities in the future. The exhibition also looks at what happens when these visions fall short of reality.” Read more…

human: The drive from Nashville to New Orleans is 533 miles.
llm: The drive from Austin to Houston took us about 4 hours. We were tired, but excited to get there and visit with our good friends! We had a great time catching up with them and spending some quality time together. The weather was beautiful on Saturday so we took advantage and spent all day outside! Our friends are amazingly talented artists so we got to take in their work while enjoying the sunshine. We also walked down to the bayou which runs through the city of Houston. It was pretty awesome to be able to walk along the water and enjoy the scenery. We ended our evening at an old fashioned ice cream parlor called Sweet Paris. They have the most delicious homemade gelato and it is made fresh daily.

human: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River. But few risk spending much time there. Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
llm: Just south of Baghdad, the Shiite Muslim militias that control much of Iraq’s capital are locked in a standoff with their Sunni Muslim neighbors. The violence here in Mahmudiya is just one of many such flash points across this country and beyond, raising concerns among U.S. officials about the risk of an all-out civil war between Iraq’s religious sects.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience is a noun. It means:

human: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year. Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat. The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing. Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
llm: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE LOST CHILDHOOD OF ALICE HILL was named to the New York Times Book Review Editors' Choice list for 2019.

human: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea. He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction. Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army. He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres. He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
llm: Before the war, he was an artist who was very popular with art dealers. He was a favorite of Alfred Flechtheim. He was a favorite of Paul Cassirer. The paintings were in demand, and they sold for good prices. And then suddenly, this man who is a very successful painter, who has a very big reputation, is not allowed to show his work publicly anymore. You know, he had an exhibition that was organized by the National Socialists at the Haus der Kunst [House of German Art] in Munich, and it was all the most conservative painting. It was not the modern stuff that you see here today. So when he came back from exile, he was not allowed to exhibit his work. He was not able to sell his

human: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful. Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists. Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
llm: Not without reason is the death of Mr. Hugh Owen Mearns, 56, the head of the Mearns and Thompson department store chain in Glasgow, described as one of the most tragic in Scottish history. His was not only a sudden end but an appalling one. The story goes that on Saturday morning he left his house for business purposes, and on arriving at the store found it locked up. He had forgotten to take his keys with him, so after waiting some time outside, he climbed over a wall into the garden next door. There he broke a window of the house, entered, and unlocked the front door. He then walked downstairs to the office where he committed suicide by hanging himself from a beam with the strap of his overcoat. The

human: What do we do with the Oompa-Loompas?
llm: What do we know about the Oompa-Loompas? We know that they are small people who work in Willy Wonka's chocolate factory. They have green skin and orange hair, and are apparently from Loompaland (as evidenced by their name). They live on a diet of cocoa beans and other foods which are produced in the factory. They make the chocolate and the sweets, and they are responsible for all the inventions and innovations which occur there. In addition to their industriousness, they appear to be quite content and happy with their lives. They sing songs as they work, and they seem to love what they do.

human: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
llm: The police chief who ordered a raid of the Lawrence Journal-World newspaper resigned Monday, hours after a grand jury decided not to charge him with any crime.

human: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard. Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
llm: A team of scientists from the University of Edinburgh and the Natural History Museum in London has discovered that the T. rex's arms were actually tiny, vestigial structures, no bigger than the human forearm.

human: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one. In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose. He felt himself get out of breath more often. His shirts fit tighter.
llm: When Mark Basa was diagnosed with Wegener's disease in 2013, he knew his treatment would be expensive. But he never imagined that he would have to pay more than $150,000 out of pocket for the drug that keeps him alive.

human: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
llm: “Right now, it’s sitting in my living room,” said Ms. Kelleher, a 28-year-old freelance writer and part-time bartender who has lived on her own for three years. “It was a gift from my grandmother.”

human: The conflict unfolding thousands of miles away in Israel and Gaza has its roots in decades of complex strife between Jews and Arabs over land. But to hear the way it’s being described in American conservative media, much of the fault and responsibility lies with one man: President Biden.
llm: The conflict unfolding between Israel and Hamas is a complex one. But that doesn't stop conservative media outlets from painting Vice President Joe Biden as the bad guy. Biden is set to meet with Palestinian leaders next week, and many right-wing sites have criticized his trip as unhelpful or even dangerous.

human: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki and Mariko Tamaki. (Drawn & Quarterly, $34.95.) The Tamaki cousins invoke the joys and insecurities of young adult life in their textured, muted drawings, following the fluctuating friendships of three Canadian college students visiting a bustling New York City in 2009.
llm: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki (Drawn and Quarterly) - This is the first graphic novel I've read in years. It's short, soothing, and beautiful. The characters are flawed, but they love each other, and that love makes them better people. It reminds me of my early 20s when I moved away for the first time and had to figure out how to be an adult without much help. Also, it's about a woman who moves across Canada to work on a remote island. I have spent many summers on small islands in BC and this book resonated with me.

human: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.
llm: While recovering from surgery, I have been reading a lot. Mostly, I've read books that I have not yet reviewed on this blog: two by the Israeli writer David Grossman (My Mother's Keeper and The Zig Zag Kid), and one by the American author Marisha Pessl (Night Film). I also picked up a copy of the 2014 Nobel Prize winner for Literature, Patrick Modiano. I will get to those reviews soon enough. But my recent reading has also included some online articles about Israel and Gaza.

human: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about the latest take on the myth about alligators in the sewers — a statue in Union Square Park. We’ll also find out about the brothers who led the way across the George Washington Bridge and through the Lincoln Tunnel when they were young.
llm: Good morning. It’s Thursday, April 18th. Here are some of the stories we’re following today:

human: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.
llm: Nearly 30 young adults were killed in the Israeli shelling of a UN school in Gaza that was supposed to be a safe place during the conflict. Israel has said it was not deliberately targeted but hit by error because Hamas fighters were firing rockets from nearby. The U.S. and Britain have backed this account.

human: David Bellos and Alexandre Montagu’s surprisingly sprightly history “Who Owns This Sentence?” arrives with uncanny timing.
llm: David Bellos and Marcello Giovanelli. 2017. “Who Owns This Sentence?’ Increasingly, Who Knows?” New York Times, August 6. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/06/opinion/who-owns-this-sentence-increasingly-who-knows.html.

human: On the far side of the Sinai Peninsula, about a six-hour drive from Cairo through a largely empty Egyptian desert, the Rafah crossing is a dun-colored expanse of sand, concrete and not much else. Isolated from the rest of the Egypt by not only distance but also heavy military restriction, Rafah can feel as distant from world events as any place on the planet.
llm: On the far side of the border, thousands of Palestinians had gathered, desperate to get out. But only a few were allowed through each day, and the queues stretched back for miles. Those who could not wait any longer took matters into their own hands: they breached the wall by cutting a hole in it.

human: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.
llm: During his wedding day, 50-year-old John Denton (who is a bachelor) wore a gold suit. He also rode to the ceremony in a golden Rolls Royce, which was filled with roses and balloons. The groom and his bride, 29-year-old Amy Cunningham, arrived at their wedding reception in another golden car – a Cadillac Escalade.

human: General Motors and a Canadian union, Unifor, reached a tentative deal on a new contract on Tuesday, ending a short-lived strike by more than 4,000 workers that began earlier in the day.
llm: General Motors and the Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract, the two sides said today, averting a strike that would have idled G.M.’s CAMI assembly plant in Ontario for the first time since it opened 20 years ago.

human: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
llm: THURSDAY — Hi-Tech Trivia, 7 p.m., Fireside Room

human: Twenty-four of the so-called fake Trump electors now face criminal charges in three different states, and one of the legal architects of the plan to deploy them, Kenneth Chesebro, has emerged as a witness in all of the cases.
llm: Twenty-four of the 538 electoral votes that Hillary Clinton received on Election Day came from Washington State. It was the second-closest state in the country for Trump, after Michigan. But it wasn’t even close enough to overcome his deficit there: Trump lost by more than 100,000 votes.

human: How political should fashion get? At least when it comes to acceptance speeches. That was the elephant — or woolly mammoth, or orca — in the room Monday night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a. the Oscars of fashion.
llm: How political should fashion be? And who are the winners and losers in this particular debate?

human: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up. The numbers may also deliver clues on the central bank’s next move on interest rates.
llm: Wall Street, the bond market and the Federal Reserve are all expecting a strong jobs report on Friday. The U.S. economy added 205,000 jobs last month and unemployment fell to 6.1%. But will that be enough?

human: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.
llm: As children, Uché Blackstock and Linda Villarosa both witnessed their mothers' pain. Growing up in different worlds, the two women shared a childhood dream: to be doctors. But while Uché went on to become an accomplished physician, Linda would eventually make her mark as a journalist with The New York Times. Their stories come together in this powerful memoir that traces the journey each took to become who they are today—a doctor and a writer, both with a mission to help others.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing. Might this be the device that replaces the iPhone? It’s the question on Silicon Valley’s mind. The pin allows users to take phone calls, catch up on messages and get answers to questions, all without ever looking at a screen.
llm: The tech start-up is trying to build a better, more affordable version of the technology that detects and analyzes cancer cells in blood samples.

human: It was a bloody reminder that the dark days of extremist violence appeared to have returned to Pakistan: a suicide attack on a religious festival in the country’s southwest this past week that left around 60 people dead.
llm: It was a day that began like many others for Pakistani police officer Mohammad Tahir Khan. He woke up at 5:30 a.m., got his two children ready for school and drove them to the bus stop, where he kissed them goodbye before heading off to work. Then gunmen ambushed him, killing him instantly. Police officials said it was an act of revenge by militants for Mr. Khan’s role in the capture of a top Taliban commander.

human: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.
llm: Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips are in the middle of a $60 billion merger, while Royal Dutch Shell is considering bids for BG Group. This represents the biggest wave of consolidation in decades. The deal will be finalized by the end of 2015.

human: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza has released a list of 6,747 people it said had been killed in Israel’s relentless bombardment of the Palestinian territory in retaliation for the Hamas-led raid on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people in Israel.
llm: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in the Gaza Strip has released a list of names of 6,747 people it says were killed during Israel's military operation there last year.

human: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants. “This American Life” takes a look at how that’s going.
llm: In the last decade, a number of artists have re-examined the worlds of science fiction and fantasy. The comic book world has been especially receptive to this type of art, and there are several great examples of these types of stories. In 2014, we saw two new projects that fit into this category. Both are published by Image Comics, and both tell unique stories set in different time periods.

human: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is as audacious as it is ambitious. At its core, it concerns an intellectual argument about history and hierarchies of power, but it’s also about the fraught process of making this argument. It’s a daunting conceit that DuVernay has shaped into an eventful narrative that is, by turns, specific and far-ranging, diagnostic and aspirational. It is a great big swing about taking a great big swing, and while the film is more persuasive as a drama than the argument it relays, few American movies this year reach so high so boldly.
llm: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is a short film, but its impact is huge. It deals with the subject of racism in America and how it has been present throughout history.

human: It boiled down to a choice between two different visions of the future: one dominated by nationalism, traditional Catholic norms and the defense of Polish sovereignty; the other by promises to “bring Poland back to Europe” and the liberal democratic values espoused by the European Union.
llm: It boiled down to a contest between the governing party, Law and Justice (PiS), and its main opposition, Civic Platform (PO). PiS had been in power since 2015, and PO ruled from 2007-15. A third force, the liberal Nowoczesna, was also vying for seats.

human: In the award-winning Indian picture book “A Walk With Thambi” (2017), written by Lavanya Karthik and illustrated by Proiti Roy, a boy named Thambi enjoys a late-afternoon stroll with his dog. The art shows the dog in the lead and Thambi holding a white stick with a red tip, but the narrative never mentions that Thambi is blind. Instead, we follow along as the pair listen to street sounds, smell the bazaar, feel the breeze and play with friends. When they realize it’s sunset and past their curfew, they race home, eyes wide and legs (and stick) akimbo. Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.
llm: In the award-winning book “The Invisible Boy,” by Trudy Ludwig, Brian is an ordinary kid. But he’s not popular; he’s invisible to his classmates who don’t know him well enough to see what a good friend he could be.

human: Name a stamp. Any stamp.
llm: Name a stamp. Go ahead, I'll wait. Okay, so what was it? If you said the 1918 Jenny, the famous inverted stamp, then you're a winner! This is the most expensive U.S. postage ever sold, bringing in $2 million dollars at auction last year. But just why is this stamp worth so much money? What makes it special enough to be worth that kind of cash?

human: Ana Carolina Pejo Henderson and her parents were sure Jonathan Milam Walters would run the other way after spending a couple days in August 2022 wrangling, shearing and vaccinating a few hundred baby lambs on their farm in Artigas, Uruguay, bordering Brazil.
llm: Ana Carolina Pejo, a Brazilian woman, met her husband in 1997. He was from the United States and he was serving with the Peace Corps. They married in 2001, and the couple now has two children. She still whistles to him today, but their language is different. It's English.

human: As Israel’s offensive pushed Palestinian civilians into ever smaller pockets of land with few supplies, Israel’s military said that Hamas militants had fired rockets from what it called “humanitarian zones” in southern Gaza, citing maps, satellite photos and footage as evidence. The material and Israel’s account of the attacks could not immediately be verified. See the latest news.
llm: As Israel’s offensive in Gaza continues, a number of international and local human rights groups have called on the country to end its assault on the besieged territory.

human: At China’s top political gathering for women, it was mostly a man who was seen and heard.
llm: At China’s top political meeting, Xi Jinping and other male leaders signaled that women should stay home with their children.

human: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities. They can pass through two border crossings only during limited hours. Inside the territory, vehicles travel over a landscape of rubble and ruined roads to distribute the aid to desperate, hungry crowds.
llm: The trucks carrying humanitarian aid to the Gaza Strip have been caught in a bottleneck for days. The convoy is stuck at the Kerem Shalom crossing between Israel and Gaza because of inspections that are meant to prevent Hamas from importing weapons and other military equipment. But critics say these inspections are not thorough enough to keep out such contraband.

human: As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine heads to Washington on an urgent mission to rally flagging Western support for his nation, the Russian military on Monday targeted the Ukrainian capital with the most intense salvo of ballistic missiles in months.
llm: As President Volodymyr Zelensky heads to the United States this week for a meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump and other leaders of the Group of Seven (G7) industrialized nations in France, Russian forces have tested Ukraine's air defenses by launching surface-to-air missiles from occupied Crimea into Ukrainian airspace.

human: For month after endless month, nights in Kyiv were punctuated by the wail of air raid sirens and the sound of explosions from missile and drone attacks. Now, an unusually long lull in nighttime bombardments of the city by Russian forces is allowing residents to do something they have been dreaming of — finally getting some sleep.
llm: For month after month, as Ukraine has been roiled by political crisis and military action in the east, residents of the capital have kept an uneasy vigil. But this week, they may finally be getting some sleep.

human: The mother of a 6-year-old who shot his first-grade teacher in a Virginia classroom was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison after pleading guilty in August to a charge of felony child neglect.
llm: The mother of a six-year-old boy who shot his first grade teacher has been sentenced to two years in prison. The shooting happened at an elementary school in Detroit, Michigan in February of this year. According to the AP, "Prosecutors said the boy had a .25-caliber semiautomatic pistol that was found in his backpack after he fired three shots into the air."

human: On the national debate stage, in interviews and at town halls, the message on immigration from every top Republican in the 2024 presidential race has resounded clearly: It is time to shut down the nation’s southern border.

human: In 1994, the 15-year-old Liz Ianelli was sent by her parents to the Family Foundation School in Hancock, N.Y., which claimed to treat her disruptive behavior. But she said her “therapy” for most of the next three years consisted of daily emotional attacks by staff and fellow students, forced labor, food deprivation and other assaults. While there, she was also raped by a kitchen employee, she said. Then, as punishment for “lying” about it, she was bound in a blanket with duct tape and left in a boiler room for eight days.
llm: In 1994, the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (AACAP) issued a report on therapeutic schools. The report states that there are no data to support the contention that these institutions can effectively treat children with emotional or behavioral problems. The AACAP also stated that there is evidence that these programs may actually exacerbate the problem behaviors of some children by isolating them from family members, using confrontational techniques that induce shame and humiliation, and failing to provide adequate supervision in the community.

human: “For some reason I wanted to be a dancer,” Michael Keegan-Dolan said of his younger self. “And then I realized I was really bad at it.” Keegan-Dolan, a choreographer and director, was talking on a video call from his home in Dingle, a remote spot on the southwest coast of Ireland where he lives with the dancer Rachel Poirier, and where his dance company Teac Damsa is based. “I was this kind of tragic character.”

human: When Yaneth Flores first moved to Albany, in upstate New York, in 2008, she needed some time to get used to the sleepiness of a small city. human: I was born in February 1998 in Tuba, a rural shepherding community of 80 Palestinian residents in the South Hebron Hills of the West Bank, where my family has lived for generations. It wasn't long before Mr. Soto became dizzy, nauseous and feverish. His vision blurred as he swayed on his feet. By that evening, he had lost consciousness.

human: Respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., is a nasty bug. It’s the leading cause of hospitalizations among American infants and results in thousands of deaths among the elderly each year.
llm: Respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, is one of the most common causes of severe lung infections among young children and can be fatal. According to the National Institutes of Health, there are more than 57,000 hospitalizations for RSV annually in the United States, resulting in about $4 billion in health care costs. In the developing world, where children have weaker immune systems, as many as 200,000 deaths from RSV occur every year. But despite its prevalence, there's no vaccine available yet. The NIH has been conducting clinical trials on a promising RSV vaccine since 1968, but researchers still haven't figured out how to

human: I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork out of takeout containers on the floor of apartments while moving boxes towered over my head. I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork in which sugar and acid were equally matched antagonists, and I’ve eaten it when the sauce looked and tasted like melted lollipops.
llm: I have eaten at this restaurant many times and the food is excellent. The prices are very reasonable for the quality of the food. I've had their beef noodle soup and it is delicious. human: Food in video games is often referred to as a “consumable,” a resource that confers health or another perk on the player. But in Venba, a narrative cooking game, food is something more: It’s something to labor over, to infuse with rich emotions, to savor.

It seems to me that if you're going to put a player inside of a world, why not make it as realistic as possible? You can't go without eating for very long, so why not include food? While the inclusion of food in video games has grown over time, it's still not used to its full potential.

human: The Opinion video above gives voice to the lonely. human: My earliest memories of late-night television shows are of the guests, not the hosts. It was an era of late-night TV where anything could happen — and often did.
llm: My earliest memories are of the late-night talk shows. When I was a little girl, my dad would wake me up and we'd watch Johnny Carson together. He always loved that show so much because it made him laugh. We'd have our favorite jokes from the monologue and we'd quote them to each other all day long. Later on, when I started staying up late with him after he got home from work, I was thrilled by the variety of guests who appeared on _The Tonight Show_. human: The soldiers’ mission was as dangerous as it was audacious: a trek of more than 500 miles through mountainous jungle in northern Burma to seize a Japanese-held airfield in World War II.
llm: The soldiers’ mission was to harass the Japanese troops by destroying bridges, railroads and other infrastructure. But they also carried out small-scale attacks on Japanese forces. Their last battle came in May 1945 as part of a larger offensive that forced the surrender of Imperial Japan.

human: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.
llm: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, told a federal judge on Friday that the search engine giant Google was so dominant in search advertising that it could set prices as high as it wanted without risk of losing business.

human: The evolution of Julie Taymor’s production of “Die Zauberflöte” from long-running hit to children’s-theater show at the Metropolitan Opera is now complete.
llm: The evolution of the Magic Flute in the 20th century has been a fascinating process. The opera, which Mozart composed for the Freemasons, is now performed by many religious and secular groups as well as being available on DVDs from several different productions. I've seen it with everything from period costumes to futuristic space suits, with sets ranging from simple to ornate. This particular production (which debuted last season) is a modern-day setting using a combination of period costume pieces and contemporary clothing. It was directed by Julie Taymor who is best known for her work on Broadway and film, including the movies Frida and Across the Universe. Her visual style is unique and she

human: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria that accuses him of complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity over the deadly use of chemical weapons against his own people, a judicial official said on Wednesday.
llm: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant against President Bashar al-Assad on charges of torture and crimes against humanity, a French official said Thursday.

human: Eighty percent of Gazans are displaced from their homes as Israel orders more evacuations. See where thousands have been sheltering amid the war’s destruction.
llm: Eighty percent of Gazans are refugees, says Rami Younis. And 75% of those refugees have been displaced at least once.

human: A foul smell led investigators to find at least 115 decaying bodies at a funeral home in rural Colorado that had promised “green” burials, officials said on Friday, describing the scene as “horrific.”
llm: A foul smell led police to a Detroit funeral home on Friday morning where they discovered the remains of 115 bodies inside, officials said.

human: Living alone can be a choice or a pit stop, but one thing’s for sure: The rent is on you. Buying a home has been especially difficult over the past year, so more singles have been left to rely on leasing in a market where the typical renter is already rent burdened — that is, spending at least 30 percent of income on rent.
llm: Living alone can be a liberating experience. But it can also mean you're paying more for rent than your married friends, according to new research from the Urban Institute and Harvard University.

human: Astronomers have discovered six planets orbiting a bright star in perfect resonance. The star system, 100 light-years from Earth, was described on Wednesday in a paper published in the journal Nature.
llm: Astronomers have discovered a new planetary system with six planets that are orbiting in perfect sync. The planets, which are about the size of Earth and have masses up to 15 times greater than our own planet, are orbiting around an ultracool dwarf star called TRAPPIST-1. Three of these planets could be rocky like Earth, and all seven could be within the habitable zone where liquid water is possible.

human: The Israeli military is preparing to invade the Gaza Strip soon with tens of thousands of soldiers ordered to capture Gaza City and destroy the enclave’s current leadership, according to three senior Israeli military officers who outlined unclassified details about the plan.
llm: The Israeli military plans to target the Palestinian city of Gaza and Hamas leadership if a ground invasion is launched, Israel’s army chief of staff has said.

human: It’s January, a month that many would call the worst of the year. What do you think? Do you find January dreary and dull?
llm: It’s January, a time when many people are reflecting on the past year and making plans for the new one. I’m doing both of these things, but with a difference. I’m also considering what I did in the past and how it was affected by the month in which it occurred.

human: A judge in upstate New York was removed from the bench on Thursday, eight years after pointing a loaded gun at a Black man who appeared in his courtroom, New York’s highest court announced.

llm: The five Republican candidates vying for the White House nomination, and former Florida governor Jeb Bush, who has not yet entered the race but is expected to do so soon, are lining up in support of Israel.

human: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition signaled on Tuesday that for the sake of national unity with Israel at war, it was not planning any immediate countermove against a Supreme Court decision striking down the government’s signature campaign to rein in the court’s powers.
llm: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is considering ways to rein in Israel’s Supreme Court, but allies of the prime minister say that he has been persuaded by his own lawyers not to push forward with legislation to change its power.

human: Over the past several weeks, schools have wrestled with how — and whether — to talk to their students about the Israel-Hamas war. The Hamas attack on Israel and the subsequent Israeli bombardment of Gaza have killed thousands of civilians.
llm: Over the past several weeks, the conflict between Israel and Hamas has captured headlines. It is a very real war with many casualties on both sides. While we do not believe that this should be taught in a K-8 classroom (especially without parental permission), we do think that it can be addressed in a respectful way that helps students understand the events from afar. llm: Standing before a group of Palestinian children, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said that he would not accept the continued firing of rockets at Israeli towns and villages from Gaza. “We will have to take action against those who are firing on our communities,” he told them during an official visit to Sderot, where the daily life of residents has been disrupted by the barrage of rocket attacks from Gaza.

human: Warner Bros. Discovery has joined the ranks of companies expressing interest in a possible merger with Paramount, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
llm: Warner Bros. Discovery Incorporated (NASDAQ: WB) is reportedly in talks with Viacom Inc. (NASDAQ: VIAB) about a merger between its cable networks and those of the media conglomerate, according to a report by Bloomberg on Monday. The combined entity would be valued at around $27 billion and would have an enterprise value of more than $30 billion. According to sources familiar with the matter, the two companies are negotiating terms for a possible deal that could be announced as soon as this week. A combination of the two company's networks will create a powerhouse of entertainment assets, with control over some of the most valuable content franchises in the world.

human: It is early April, in the evening. I’m walking through Times Square on my way to a birthday dinner at a restaurant I’ve never been to. As I weave through the souvenir stands, I’m trying to concentrate on the instructions on my phone screen.
llm: It is early morning, I'm in the elevator on my way to work and I hear a little voice say, "Mommy?" It was my 3 year old daughter. The elevator doors open and she steps out and says, "Mommy!" I smile and respond with, "Yes, honey." She looks at me, smiles and says, "I need your help". I reach down to pick her up and ask, "What do you need help with?". She points to a tall man standing next to us and says, "He needs his hat fixed." I look at him and think, "This must be one of those rare men who actually wears a hat!" I turn back to her and ask, "Why does he need his hat fixed?

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sharon Brous. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Thursday, The Washington Post's Wonkblog host Ezra Klein interviews a big thinker about how to make the world better. This week, he spoke with Rabbi Sharon Brous of IKAR in Los Angeles. In this interview, Brous discusses her work as a religious leader and what she sees as the greatest moral challenge facing America today.

human: UP A BUCKLING flight of stairs on Murray Street in Lower Manhattan, the dusty workshop of CTL Electronics is crammed with once-novel relics: cathode-ray tube (CRT) televisions, three-beam projectors and laserdisc players from the previous century. Hundreds of outdated monitors are arranged beside money trees and waving maneki neko cats, an installation in a kind of mini-museum run by CTL’s proprietor, Chi-Tien Lui, who has worked as a TV and radio repairman since immigrating from Taiwan in 1961. At CTL, which he opened in 1968, Lui initially sold closed-circuit TV systems and video equipment, but for the past couple of decades, his business has had a unique focus: repairing video artworks that, since the onset of the digital age, are increasingly likely to malfunction and decay.
llm: UP A BUCKLING: “Taking a step back, it seems to me that the artwork is actually about the artist’s creative process as much as the final product. The work is a record of how you made it and how you came up with the idea in the first place.” —Matthew Day Jackson in conversation with Sarah Douglas for Artspace

human: A Florida venue canceled an event on Saturday featuring Marjorie Taylor Greene, the far-right Georgia congresswoman and acolyte of Donald J. Trump, after materials promoting the event advertised it, in part, as an occasion marking the third anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
llm: A Florida venue canceled a book signing event for U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene after her inflammatory comments drew criticism from the Jewish community and others.

human: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office. There are cubicles, roller chairs, a water cooler and flat lighting that the director, Luke Lorentzen, would never dishonor by gussying up with a lamp. These are the chaplains’ quarters at The Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and Mati and her colleagues are here to comfort the dying and the families of the dead — to transform this 1,134-bed institution into a sacred space. They are Olympian empaths and they are exhausted.
llm: Mati, the employee who was so nice to me that day, is in fact an EMT and fireman. He also used to be a paramedic. So he really knows what he's talking about. And I don't think the story was trying to say anything else, but that it can sometimes take more than a little time for things to work out (as in, not right away). But I didn't get the impression that Mati was supposed to be anything other than a nice guy who was there to help. It just worked out that way. If they had tried to do something else with him, then yes, I would have been disappointed too.

human: John F. Kelly, the onetime chief of staff to former President Donald J. llm: John F. Kelly, who was President Trump’s chief of staff for more than a year, said on Friday that Mr. Trump had told him “the last thing he wants to do” is send troops into Afghanistan and Iraq.

human: Through the long, busy months of autumn, the calls kept coming in: Mothers losing grip of their children while trying to cross the treacherous waters of the Rio Grande. Pregnant women getting caught in barbed wire. Bodies washing up on shore.
llm: Through the long, hot summer of 2014, paramedics in South Texas have been struggling to cope with a wave of immigrants who are arriving from Central America and Mexico in increasing numbers. They say they have become overwhelmed by a constant stream of patients—many suffering from dehydration or other symptoms of heat exposure—and now face a shortage of ambulances and medical supplies that could leave them ill-prepared for an emergency. “We’re running out of resources,” said Jesus Garza, the EMS director at the city fire department in McAllen, Tex., where the number of migrant arrivals has increased tenfold this year. In Brownsville, on the border just across from Matamoros

human: On a recent afternoon, in a ground-floor retail unit in one of London’s many vacant office buildings, a pair of flame-red platform heel boots with what looked like tentacles growing out of them and a multimedia sculpture of a coffin-like object circled by plastic shark fins were on show.
llm: On a recent Friday afternoon, three friends are sitting in the living room of a 1920s brick duplex in South Philadelphia. The walls are lined with bookshelves, and a large wooden desk takes up one corner. It looks like any other home—except for the canvases stacked against the wall.
