human: At an emotional evening news conference immediately after he was removed as speaker of the House, Representative Kevin McCarthy gave an inconclusive answer about whether he would remain in Congress.
llm: At an emotional farewell party for his staff, Rep. Joseph R. McCarthy (R-NY) says that he is “ready” to leave Congress and has no regrets about his decade-long career as House majority leader. He and his wife Norma have long said they would leave Congress together, but she lost a recent primary race and therefore will not be leaving with her husband; they must now sell their Washington, DC home and move back to their native Buffalo. McCarthy gave up his position as speaker after Republicans lost control of the House in 2006. He has been elected to two more terms since, but has sat on the sidelines as Democrats under Nancy Pelosi have controlled the House. He was rated as one of the most

human: There were times, a year ago, in Iceland, on a glacier, in the dark, in temperatures well below freezing, when Issa López thought to herself: “Who wrote this? What is wrong with this person?” López, the showrunner and director of Season 4 of the HBO anthology series “True Detective,” had only herself to blame.
llm: There were times, I'm sure, when Nic Pizzolatto wasn't even sure he was going to come back for a second season of his HBO series True Detective. But now the show is back and ready for action. Season 1 was an intense, sometimes harrowing experience with its story of two detectives (played by Woody Harrelson and Matthew McConaughey) who had been brought in decades later to investigate a brutal murder that took place years before. The new season introduces three new characters played by Colin Farrell, Rachel McAdams and Taylor Kitsch. And while it doesn't have the same intensity as season one, this new season is still compelling and intriguing, thanks largely to some ter

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.” The line appeared in a critical review of Daniel Jonah Goldhagen’s best-selling and furor-starting book, “Hitler’s Willing Executioners,” which was itself an example of Neuhaus’s point in action. In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
llm: In 1996, in a speech to the Palestine National Council, Hamas leader Ahmad Yassin declared that “the Jews are Nazis” who had perpetrated a holocaust against the Arabs. “They even slaughtered children on their mothers’ backs,” he said, citing as his source for this charge the anti-Semitic forgery, The Protocols of the Elders of Zion.

human: Days of intense negotiations enabled the Biden administration to avoid casting a veto at the United Nations Security Council in defense of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza.
llm: Days of intense fighting between Israel and Hamas in Gaza have prompted world leaders to make statements urging both sides to cease hostilities and return to a lasting peace deal. But one country's government has remained silent: the United States.

human: The Washington Ballet announced on Tuesday that Edwaard Liang would be its next artistic director, starting immediately.

human: The Los Angeles Times said on Tuesday that it would lay off about 115 journalists, slashing its newsroom by more than 20 percent after a tumultuous few weeks that saw top editors depart and workers walk off the job.

human: Golf is a sport where certain years stand out above others, and 2023 may prove to be one of those years. It’s a heady list.
llm: Golf is a unique sport in that it is played on courses designed and owned by private clubs. This has made golf an attractive business for investors looking to acquire facilities that have been built with capital invested from memberships, but are now more valuable as real estate than as places to play golf.

human: The next United Nations climate change summit appears set to take place in Azerbaijan, a spokesman for the country said Saturday, resolving a bitter, monthslong political standoff over which nation should host the talks in 2024.
llm: The next United Nations climate summit is expected to be held in Azerbaijan in 2024, according to a statement released by the country's President Ilham Aliyev on March 19.

human: Play a simplified version of the bonus round, then read on for strategy advice, whether you’re a future contestant or just watching at home.
llm: Play a simplified version of Wheel of Fortune at home. You can use household items as game pieces. For example, you could use a plastic bag for the wheel, a bottle cap for the puzzle board, and a paper clip to mark your guesses. Make sure the person with the highest score wins. Have fun!

human: Few challenges are as complex in Madrid as finding a cat. Not the animal, but a gato — someone who was born in Madrid, whose parents and grandparents were born in Madrid. Nobody in Madrid was born here: You’ll seldom be asked where you are from, because the assumption is that you’re from somewhere else, although suspicion — and prejudice — can come up when you have a certain accent or skin color.
llm: Few challenges are as daunting and exciting as a new job. A little extra help from friends can go a long way toward easing the transition, and there’s no better source of support than your fellow expats! With InterNations, you never stand alone: Our events calendar is always packed with great ways to meet up and mingle with fellow American expats in Madrid. From dinner parties to cocktail hours, book groups to dining out — we have something for everybody, no matter what your interests or lifestyle. Looking for other American expats in Madrid? Look no further! Among our 5,400 members in Madrid we also welcome Americans living in Spain.

human: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected in 2016, I spoke to a friend in Istanbul about my boundless horror, and while I can’t remember the exact words she said in response, they amounted to “Welcome to my world.” I told her about all the protests breaking out, and she gently warned me not to get my hopes up. She’d also demonstrated against Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she said, but eventually those protests had died out, and ours would too.
llm: Shortly after Donald J. Trump was sworn in as president, millions of Americans marched through the streets of their cities and towns to say no to his agenda. And they have continued to do so, with more than 1 million people protesting in Washington alone over the past year.

human: More than 100,000 demonstrators in Paris and cities across France took to the streets on Sunday to show their solidarity with the country’s Jews and to deplore antisemitic acts that have multiplied across the nation since Hamas’s attack on Israel on Oct. 7.
llm: More than 100,000 people marched through Paris on Sunday to protest against a surge in anti-Semitic attacks.

human: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam. In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market.
llm: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, which has produced bullets for the U.S. military since World War II, was the source of ammunition used in some of America’s most notorious mass shootings, a USA TODAY investigation found. The plant has been plagued by safety and quality control problems that led to millions of faulty rounds being shipped to troops in Afghanistan in 2014, according to government records. In one case, an inspection found workers at the Lake City plant had failed to properly inspect bullets for cracks and other flaws before packaging them.

human: When Mary Lou Retton, the decorated Olympic gymnast, accrued medical debt from a lengthy hospital stay, her family did what countless Americans have done before them: turned to crowdfunding to cover the bills.
llm: When Mary Lou Retton was just 16 years old she won the gold medal in gymnastics at the Los Angeles Olympics. Now, more than three decades later, she has a new goal: to pay off her medical debt.

human: An article on Friday about Iran’s links to regional conflicts referred incorrectly to Iran’s nuclear program. Iran has raised the prospect that it could develop nuclear weapons, maintaining that its nuclear program has only peaceful purposes, but it has not developed them.
llm: An article on Thursday about the reopening of a major thoroughfare in Midtown Manhattan misstated the time of day when cars are allowed to use the street. It is from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m., not from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. The article also misstated the amount that the city’s Department of Transportation will spend on improving the plazas surrounding the street. It is $13 million over five years, not $5 million over five years. And it was unclear which of two public-private partnerships would pay for the work; the department says both will. (The article also referred incorrectly to the new name of the street, as it has been named since 1999

human: Joseph J. Esposito, who served longer than anyone else as the highest-ranking uniformed officer of the New York Police Department, and who oversaw the city’s response to emergencies, including the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and the devastation of Hurricane Sandy, died on Jan. 8 in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 73.
llm: Joseph J. Esposito, who was appointed to the New York City Police Department by Mayor John V. Lindsay in 1964 and rose through its ranks to become the department’s chief of detectives before retiring as commissioner in 1986, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 73.

human: The key to cutting emissions from cars and light trucks that are heating the planet could lie with the nation’s super drivers, the small percentage of American motorists who drive, on average, about 110 miles per day.
llm: The key to successful EV deployment is to ensure that the right infrastructure is in place. Without a reliable, cost-effective charging network, EVs are not going to take off.

human: Thousands of faculty members at the nation’s largest four-year public university system are canceling classes and mounting rolling strikes this week as they demand higher pay and better benefits.
llm: Thousands of faculty at 23 California State University campuses are striking this week. The strike is part of a labor dispute that has been going on for months, and it could drag on into next year if not resolved soon.

human: A Virginia fisherman who died in 2017 was responsible for the killings of three people in two separate cases in the southeastern part of the state that sat unsolved for more than 30 years, the police announced this week.
