human: The British Library on Monday began restoring its online catalog, which holds details of books, journals and music scores, the first step in its recovery from a brazen cyberattack in October, the library said.
llm: The British Library, one of the largest research libraries in the world, has been struggling to restore online access after a cyberattack. It said Wednesday that it was making progress and hoped to have most of its services back up by the end of the month.

human: The mechanics of how chess players might cheat increasingly occupies the minds of professional chess players, academics who build models to catch cheating and top chess platforms.
llm: The mechanics of the game of chess are notoriously simple, but the strategies for winning are endlessly complex. The same is true with cheating in the game: It's easy to fool a computer and make it think you're doing better than you really are. But detecting the cheater takes some serious sleuthing.

human: In Seattle, the debate consumed much of two City Council meetings. In San Francisco, the line to speak stretched long all night under the City Hall dome. The Oakland City Council spent four hours just on public comment.
llm: In Seattle, the city council has passed a resolution that condemns Israel for its actions in Gaza. It calls on Congress and President Obama to stop military aid to Israel until it stops the attacks against Palestinians. The city council is now looking at divesting from companies that do business with Israel. We speak to Councilmember Bruce Harrell, who introduced the resolution, and to Councilmember Nick Licata, one of three members who voted against it. [includes rush transcript]

human: Less than a week after presenting his third collection as Ferragamo’s creative director in Milan this past September, Maximilian Davis was at ease. The clothes — a luxurious combination of asymmetrical dresses and Italian tailoring — had been well received. As he spoke, quietly but with confidence, he gestured gently with his hands, like a conductor keeping an unhurried tempo. Born in Manchester, England, to Trinidadian and Jamaican parents, Davis, 28, the youngest of three children, spent his summers in Trinidad until the age of 13. A passion for clothing ran in the family: His maternal grandmother taught him to sew when he was 6, his mother was a working model and his father studied fashion design.
llm: Less than a week after the New York Times published an article on his new home collection, the designer talked to us about why he loves San Francisco, and what's next for him.

human: Al-Shifa Hospital, the Gaza Strip’s largest medical complex, has been overwhelmed with wounded patients since Israel launched airstrikes in Gaza in retaliation to Hamas’s attack.
llm: Al-Shifa Hospital, the largest in Gaza, is overwhelmed by patients.

human: As 2023 comes to an end, there is a growing sense of panic in Europe. Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the European Union has been preoccupied with integrating the country — widely seen as a geopolitical necessity — and with the internal reform required to make that possible. But over the course of this year, as the much-hyped Ukrainian counteroffensive stalled, tensions among member states have increased.
llm: As 2023 comes into view, it is easy to imagine Europe moving backward on a range of issues. The EU has long been in the grip of a slow-motion crisis that is about to become full-blown, and the global financial system is just as vulnerable today as it was before the crash of 2008. For all the talk of “recovery,” there are plenty of indications that we have yet to emerge from the Great Recession—or even to begin the next recession. The eurozone’s third largest economy, Italy, is once again flirting with default and bankruptcy. France’s new president, Emmanuel Macron, has made some welcome moves toward reducing regulations and cutting taxes, but his proposed labor market

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain rejected claims on Friday that he had lowered his country’s net-zero ambitions and pledged to meet targets in a more pragmatic way.
llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is the new UK Chancellor of the Exchequer. He is replacing Sajid Javid, who resigned on Thursday after PM Boris Johnson fired his top advisers and several other ministers. Sunak was born in Stanford-le-Hope in Essex, but he studied at Oxford University and went on to work for Goldman Sachs. In 2015, he became MP for Richmond (Yorkshire), where he has been serving ever since.

human: Colorado’s top court ruled on Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump is disqualified from holding office again because he engaged in insurrection with his actions leading up to the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol, an explosive ruling that is likely to put the basic contours of the 2024 election in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court.
llm: Colorado’s top court on Thursday ruled that President Donald Trump is not eligible to appear on the state’s 2020 ballot because of a constitutional provision barring anyone “adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction” to be mentally incompetent from holding office. The decision, which came from the Colorado Supreme Court, stems from a lawsuit filed last year by a Democratic activist who argued that Trump was unfit for office and should be removed from the presidential primary ballot. The case was dismissed, but the plaintiff appealed, leading to Thursday’s ruling. The judges found that the “mentally incompetent” clause in the Colorado Constitution applies to candidates as well as elected

human: On a recent afternoon in SoHo, Seth Weisser and Gerard Maione were checking in on their shop, What Goes Around Comes Around, a luxury vintage boutique on West Broadway that has long been a downtown destination for stylists and celebrities.
llm: On a recent afternoon, the 40-year-old owner of Hollywood’s venerable Decades, Cameron Silver, was chatting with a customer who had just spent $2,500 on an Hermès scarf. “I love that,” said the customer. “It’s very old school.”

human: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, held two days of hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa accusing Israel of committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
llm: The International Court of Justice, known as the World Court, is the United Nations’ judicial branch. The court was established in 1945 by the U.N.’s Charter and began its work in 1946. It is the successor to the Permanent Court of International Justice (PCIJ), which was created under the League of Nations after World War I but never had a permanent home. The ICJ is based in The Hague in the Netherlands, where it has been located since 1986. Its seat is called the Peace Palace because it was built for the PCIJ and dedicated with those words from John Haynes Holmes in 1913.

human: These days, real estate imagery is often defined by staged hotel-lobby-style furniture and generic artwork, dramatic drone shots on unsettlingly perfect sunny days and a lack of human presence — almost never do you see any people or evidence that these homes have been lived in.
llm: These days, real estate photography is a very popular job. There are many reasons for this trend but one of the most important ones is that a good photo of your property can help you sell it faster. The reason why we say “good” is because there are bad photos as well and they will definitely harm your chances to find a buyer. So if you want to take control of your selling process by taking your own pictures, make sure you’re not making these common mistakes.

human: Accusations of plagiarism appear to be the newest weapon in the raging battle over the leadership and direction of elite universities.
llm: Accusations of plagiarism against a prominent investment executive who pushed for the ouster of Harvard University president Drew Faust have surfaced, as The New York Times reported.

human: A law making it illegal to discredit Russia’s army has ensnared thousands of Russians for even mild acts or statements against the war.
llm: A law making it a crime to criticize government policy in wartime has been on the books for more than 10 years, but only recently have prosecutions begun under this broad and vague legislation.

human: Outrage over a blast that killed hundreds of people at a Gaza City hospital set off protests across the Middle East and elsewhere. President Biden backed Israel’s assertion that it had nothing to do with the explosion.
llm: Outrage over a deadly blast that killed at least 20 people in the southern Gaza Strip on Wednesday has led to protests across the Palestinian territories. The explosion occurred in a hospital in the town of Rafah where wounded Palestinians were being treated after an Israeli air strike, according to medical workers. Israel has denied any involvement in the bombing.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.” Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.” And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own. When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing. Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the youngest daughter, McKenna Grace (“Gifted”) is a wide-eyed innocent who sees ghosts where no one else does. She’s also a budding psychic, which may be why she has a soft spot for Hugh Crain’s grandson, Hugh “Young Hugh” Crain, played by Oliver Jackson-Cohen (“Dracula”).

human: Playing Prince Harry in the final season of Netflix’s “The Crown,” Luther Ford said he felt like royalty.
llm: Playing Prince Harry in “The Crown” required a lot of prep. Josh O’Connor read books about him and his family, watched videos and studied photographs. He also had to grow his hair out.

human: American and Israeli officials said their intelligence showed that the deadly blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday was caused by an armed Palestinian group, rebutting Palestinian claims that an Israeli strike caused the explosion.
llm: American and Israeli intelligence agencies have concluded that a Palestinian faction was responsible for the explosion that rocked Gaza City's al-Shifa hospital, according to an American official who has seen initial reports from both countries' investigators. The findings are likely to be used by Israel as it tries to bolster its case that Hamas is not a legitimate partner in the peace process.

human: “2024 is the final battle,” Donald Trump has said.
llm: “2024 is the earliest that he would be eligible to run for president. And it’s probably safe to say that at 73, he wouldn’t be a candidate. But his son, Donald Jr., could be. He’ll be 38 in 2016.”

human: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.
llm: For years, a group of Montaukett Indians has been fighting to regain their federal recognition as an American Indian tribe. Last month, the New York State Senate passed a resolution to recognize them as a tribe and to allow them to use their land for gaming purposes. But Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed the measure on Nov. 30, saying it would open the door to “unlimited casino-style gambling.”

human: The U.S. military program that provides leadership and civic values training for students in thousands of high schools across the country will have more oversight thanks to new legislation approved by Congress this week. The changes came after complaints of sexual abuse by instructors and instances of schools requiring students to enroll in the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps, also known as J.R.O.T.C.
llm: The U.S. military has been a key component of my life since I was 17 years old. In fact, I have spent more time in the service than out of it and I am proud to say that I still serve today as an Army Reservist. So, when I saw this article from The New York Times on Sunday about the new protections being afforded to JROTC cadets by Congress, I knew I had to read it. It is a good thing too because the article, "Congress Approves Sweeping New Protections for J.R.O.T.C. Cadets", is well worth reading. Here are some highlights:

human: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England. Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.
llm: In the ancient world, an individual with these skills was called a magus (magician). It is not surprising that the ancient Greeks and Romans were fascinated by these men. Magi could use their powers to foretell the future, change their shape into animals, predict the weather and even raise the dead.

human: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an open-air prison.
llm: Ever since Israel began its military operation in the Gaza Strip, the focus has been on the tunnels used by Hamas to smuggle weapons and attack Israeli forces. In this video, Aaron David Miller explains why these tunnels are a key strategic asset for Hamas and what it means for any future peace agreement between Palestine and Israel.

human: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
llm: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Panic in a Suitcase,” is about two sisters who take off on the road.CreditCreditEmon Hassan for The New York Times

human: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer. David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos. Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.
llm: The guys in the band were stunned to learn that their music had been lifted and used for years without permission or credit, but they're even more frustrated that the company responsible is nowhere to be found.

human: The United States-led airstrikes on Thursday and Friday against sites in Yemen controlled by the Houthi militia damaged or destroyed about 90 percent of the targets struck, but the group retained about three-quarters of its ability to fire missiles and drones at ships transiting the Red Sea, two U.S. officials said on Saturday.
llm: The United States-led air campaign in Yemen has dealt a severe blow to the Houthi rebels and their allies, but their ability to conduct offensive operations remains intact, according to a new analysis by IHS Jane's.

human: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass. He was 99.
llm: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose work won acclaim late in life, when he was more than 80 years old, died on Tuesday in Providence, R.I. He was 99.

human: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.” And once you get there, starting Saturday for dinner and Monday for breakfast, lunch and coffee, you can have something to eat. On Monday, the new Weill Café, occupying the stately, cream-colored room, recently renovated with gold and burgundy accents, that has long been serving snacks and drinks during intermissions, will be open to the public from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Mondays through Fridays. Breakfast items, coffee and tea, soups, salads, quiches, sandwiches and pastries will be available, and there is a bar. It will have a street entrance, so a concert ticket is not required. That’s not the case when it comes to preconcert dining however. Those with tickets to select performances in the Stern Auditorium can book tables starting at 6 p.m. for a three-course dinner, $139 including unlimited beverages, tax and service. An initial menu by the executive chef, Derek Prough, working for Constellation Culinary Group, which is running the cafe, includes burrata with vegetables, citrus and beet carpaccio with shrimp, seared branzino, glazed short rib, roasted acorn squash tower, and dessert bites like chocolate lava cakes and apple-spice Bundt cakes. The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions. (Opens Jan. 20, 22)
llm: Yes, we know, there are plenty of other places to grab a drink in the neighborhood. But none is quite as iconic as the Weill Café at Carnegie Hall (154 W 57th St). And while the café has long been a favorite destination of concertgoers and tourists alike, it's recently become a prime spot for those who don't have tickets to the show—a place where you can watch the action onstage through the glass windows, nibble on cheese plates and salads and sip on cocktails. The space itself is bright and spacious with high ceilings, large mirrors, and a handful of tables scattered about. But what really sets this café apart from others is its view

human: As Democrats amplify their concerns about President Biden’s status with Black voters, South Carolina has emerged as a proving ground for his campaign: one where he can test his message to a predominantly Black electorate and use it as a largely ceremonial launchpad for his re-election.
llm: As Democrats amplify their focus on black voters ahead of the 2020 presidential election, two leading candidates are turning to a key constituency in South Carolina that could prove critical to their chances.

human: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to a symbolically important exchange rate of 100 to the dollar on Tuesday for the first time since mid-August, when worries about wartime shocks to the economy led the central bank to call an emergency meeting at which it sharply raised interest rates to 12 percent.
llm: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to 100 against the dollar on Tuesday, its lowest level since 2009, as oil prices continued to slide. The currency has been hit by a sharp drop in global crude prices, which account for around half of Russia's exports. The Central Bank has said it is ready to intervene if needed.

human: Democrats won decisive victories in major races across the country on Tuesday evening, overcoming the downward pull of an unpopular president, lingering inflation and growing global unrest by relying on abortion, the issue that has emerged as their fail-safe since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year.
llm: Democrats won decisive victories in Virginia and New Jersey on Tuesday night after campaigning on a range of issues that included abortion rights. And while President Trump was quick to tweet about the wins — or rather losses — his party suffered, he made no mention of the fact that the Democrats’ gains in the state legislatures were driven by the election of women who ran on a platform of expanding reproductive health access in their states.

human: Voters in New Hampshire received robocall messages over the weekend in a voice that was most likely artificially generated to impersonate President Biden’s, urging them not to vote in Tuesday’s primary election, according to the state attorney general’s office.
llm: Voters in New Hampshire are complaining about robocalls that appear to be coming from former Vice President Joe Biden's campaign. The state attorney general is now investigating the calls, which claim to be from a nonprofit group called the Committee for American Democracy and Progress (CADP). The number listed on the call isn't registered to the CADP but to an online marketing company called VOX Media Group. On Twitter, Biden said his team had nothing to do with the calls, calling them "dishonest." But he also used the incident to talk about the importance of campaign finance reform.

human: Polls in states with major elections will close on Tuesday across a three-hour period nationwide, beginning at 6 p.m. Eastern time in Kentucky and ending at 9 p.m. Eastern time in Colorado, New York and parts of Texas.
llm: Polls in states that allow early voting are open on Tuesday, November 8.

human: Visits to the International Space Station are valuable, and would-be astronauts and their countries can wait a long time for the opportunity. In addition to wealthy adventurers, Axiom Space is making it possible for people to make the trip from countries that have seldom or never had astronauts aboard the orbital outpost. The three on the Ax-3 flight are: Alper Gezeravcı, who will be the first Turkish astronaut; Marcus Wandt, a European Space Agency astronaut from Sweden; and Walter Villadei, an Italian Air Force pilot who previously flew to the edge of space on a Virgin Galactic rocket plane. A launch on Wednesday was postponed to Thursday.
llm: Visits to the ISS will be a regular occurrence in the future

human: You don’t need Halloween to justify reading scary books, any more than you need sand to justify reading a beach novel. But the holiday does give editors here a handy excuse to talk about some of their favorite spooky reads. On this week’s episode, the host Gilbert Cruz talks with his colleagues Tina Jordan and Sadie Stein about the enduring appeal of ghost stories, Gothic novels and the horror genre as a whole.
llm: You don’t need a book club to enjoy these books. They are just perfect for a rainy afternoon, or anytime really!

human: Do you have pets, or have you ever had one? Would you like to have one?
llm: Do you have a pet? If so, do you want him to live longer than normal? Would you try new treatments or procedures if they could prolong his life and improve his quality of life? A recent article in the New York Times discusses this issue.

human: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt. Those ingredients make up Vaughn Vreeland’s new chocolate chess pie (above), a veritable litany of all the baking stuffs we want when the weather turns cold and the yule log turns warm. Made with a store-bought pie crust (or a half-recipe of this foolproof pie dough), it’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
llm: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs and flour. It's easy to make a good pie crust, but you can't mess around with the filling.

human: Leesburg Animal Park in Northern Virginia has seen strong business at its Pumpkin Village festival this autumn. Even with rainy weekends and a jump in admission prices, families have been coming out to visit the petting zoo, ride on giant slides and zigzag through a hay-bale maze.
llm: Leesburg Animal Park is home to more than 1,000 animals. But this weekend, it will be home to the nation's highest-rated economics blogger.

human: As Israel called for Gazans to leave the north of the besieged enclave, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients and that there were not enough hospitals to treat them in the south.
llm: As Israel called for the evacuation of Gaza hospitals, doctors say they are facing impossible choices: leave patients behind or abandon their jobs and risk prosecution.

human: The president paid tribute to the 18 people killed in shootings at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.
llm: The president paid tribute to the victims of the shooting at an El Paso Walmart, calling it a “wicked act of mass murder” and promising to unify a grieving nation.

human: In Cairo and at the U.N., talks about a possible truce between Israel and Hamas over the war in the Gaza Strip are making slow progress, as negotiators struggled to come up with plans for pausing the fighting, freeing hostages and speeding up help for Gazans.
llm: In Cairo and Alexandria, Egyptian security forces have reportedly killed at least 62 people in a single day. The violence came on the second anniversary of the January 25 revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak. On Wednesday, thousands of demonstrators had rallied to mark the occasion. Thousands more had taken to the streets this week. The protesters are demanding President Mohamed Morsi resign. They say he has failed to carry out his promises from last year’s election campaign.

human: After drifting steadily away from its source of inspiration — Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1996 neo-noir thriller about the bloody unraveling of a criminal scheme in Minnesota and North Dakota — “Fargo” appears to be creeping back.
llm: After drifting steadily downhill for a few seasons, Fargo has found its footing again. The fifth season is back in Minnesota and the Coen brothers are back at the helm as executive producers (they wrote the pilot). And, after an uneven start, the show is finally delivering on what it promised all along.

human: Inflation in the eurozone fell to a new two-year low in November, dropping much faster than expected as a result of high interest rates and efforts by European countries to ease prices for energy and food, setting the stage for the European Central Bank to hold interest rates steady at its next meeting.
llm: Inflation in the euro area fell faster than expected last month, data from Eurostat showed Friday.

human: “If my regiment could see five minutes of what I saw today, there would be a revolution.”
llm: “If my regiment were to fight with yours,” said he, “I should not fear the result; but if you are so wise as I am, and know what it is right to do, why do you not give up these bad habits?” (from Gulliver’s Travels)

human: A young Palestinian man from East Jerusalem, Soheib Muhammad Abu Amar, is missing and believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas and ferried into Gaza, his family said.
llm: A young Palestinian boy holds a photo of his cousin, who was killed by Israeli soldiers during a protest against the construction of Israel's separation barrier on 15 March 2004. The boy says: "I want my cousin back!" (Photo: IRIN)

human: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of the Showtime series "The Curse."
llm: A selection of events from the weekly calendar.

human: The year-end holiday travel season is here, and if you’re skipping the airport and hitting the highway for your family gatherings, both Google Maps and Apple’s Maps have apps that can help save you time and money. Sure, online map navigation has been around for years, but if you haven’t used the apps for the long haul lately, both companies have recently improved their tools for modern road-trip concerns — like finding electric-vehicle charging stations or not getting lost in low-signal country. Here’s an overview.
llm: The year-end holiday season is a time when we tend to travel more than usual. In fact, 95 million Americans will be on the road during this busy period and many of them will use their smartphones as an indispensable resource. According to research by Google, half of all searches are performed with the intent of finding something locally. To better understand how consumers use local search in the real world, we recently conducted a study with Ipsos MediaCT to explore consumer behavior around local search using mobile devices.

human: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Germany went through a period of uncomfortable soul-searching about the close ties that some of its political and business leaders had to Moscow.
llm: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2014, the Kremlin embarked on a public relations blitz to bolster its image and undermine support for sanctions imposed by Europe.

human: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Sunday night that he has chosen Laphonza Butler, the president of Emily’s List and a former labor leader, to fill the vacancy left in the Senate by the death of Dianne Feinstein.
llm: Gov. Gavin Newsom has appointed his chief of staff, Ana Matosantos, to replace Sen. Dianne Feinstein on the board that oversees California's bullet train project.

human: A teenager jailed in Egypt, determined to bear witness to the abuses he suffered during years of detention. A proponent of peace in Colombia, shadowed by death threats. A father in India, fighting his own patriarchal impulses to give his two daughters a better life.
llm: A teenager jailed for killing his mother says he wants to die. His mother, a heroin addict, was killed by her own son with a knife.

human: The Golden Globes averaged 9.4 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen, an increase over the 2023 ceremony ratings but still significantly lower than the audience totals of just a few years ago.
llm: The Golden Globes are the second-most watched awards show of the year, behind only the Oscars. That's not bad for a show that isn't even on broadcast television.

human: Theron Truluck has everything he needs, for now, in his 425-square-foot apartment in the Bronx. The modest dorm-style room, with white walls and red-tiled floors, comes with a mini fridge, a microwave, a sink, a twin-size bed, a desk and an armoire. He also has access to a shared shower and bathroom, a community kitchen, and his building has a computer room when he wants to use the internet.
llm: Theron Truluck has been homeless for three years, but he hopes that a new program will help him get off the streets and into housing.

human: TV in 2023 was like synchronized swimming. Below the surface, there was roiling and churn. The writers’ and actors’ strikes wiped out much of the production year. The hangover from the corporate binge on streaming platforms led to cancellations and cutbacks. A number of hall-of-fame series left the air, with no clear plan of, as it were, succession.
llm: TV in 2023 is a very different place than it was five years ago. Netflix is still the king, but now Hulu and Amazon are nipping at its heels, with newcomers Apple TV+ and Disney+ nipping at theirs. The Peacock has been on the air for just over a year, and while there's plenty of good stuff to watch, it's not yet clear that NBCUniversal can be as successful in the streaming space as CBS All Access or WarnerMedia. (But it's worth noting that none of those companies own HBO.)

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Lydia Polgreen, with Pratap Mehta. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Friday, we'll send you an email to your inbox with scores, news and notes for Washington DC.

human: Israel’s acceptance of the terms of a hostage deal with Hamas late on Tuesday reflected the intense pressure brought by the Biden administration to reach an agreement that would free some of those held by the armed group and produce potential longer-term opportunities to de-escalate the conflict.
llm: Israel’s acceptance of a ceasefire agreement with Hamas that was brokered by Egypt and the United States last week, after 50 days of fighting, has set off a political storm in Jerusalem. While the government agreed to the terms offered by Cairo and Washington, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Moshe Ya’alon are both furious about it. But Netanyahu is even angrier than his minister, because he believes that the American secretary of state, John Kerry, pressured Israel into accepting a deal that was far less favorable than what had been presented earlier. The Israeli cabinet had approved an earlier draft of the document but then decided not to sign it. After the cabinet meeting ended, Netanyahu told senior members of his government that Kerry had threatened him and

human: E. Leo Milonas, a resolute jurist who administered New York courts for a quarter-century and was known to rise to defend his fellow judges in public disputes, in one case sparring with Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Jan. 2 at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 87.
llm: E. Leo Milonas, a lawyer who represented the city in its fight to keep control over the courts, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

human: Sweden moved one step closer to joining NATO on Tuesday, after Turkey’s Parliament backed the move, underscoring how the war in Ukraine continued to reshape the military alliance nearly two years into the fighting.
llm: Sweden moved one step closer to joining NATO on Wednesday after a majority of parliament voted for an agreement with the military alliance. The move comes as tensions between Russia and its neighbors grow over Moscow's intervention in Ukraine.

human: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey had a problem — and, prosecutors say, an opportunity. An old friend and political patron was facing federal prosecution. And as New Jersey’s senior senator, Mr. Menendez was in a position to help, by recommending the next leader of the office overseeing the case.
llm: Senator Robert Menendez, who is facing corruption charges, tried to place his friend as the head of the New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women. The friend was later forced out after a public uproar.

human: In the 17 minutes that Ziwe Fumudoh, known for her witty and acerbic interviewing style, engaged George Santos, the most telling moment was an earnest one.
llm: In the 17 years that I have been in business, I have seen many different people come through our doors. We started out as a family owned business and we still are today. Our mission statement has always been to give everyone who comes into our facility, service they will be proud of.

human: The year of “The Bear” continues. Jeremy Allen White, who last week won his second Golden Globe for his performance as the driven chef Carmy, added his first Emmy to his trophy case on Monday night, for best actor in a comedy. (Because this year’s ceremony was delayed by the writers’ and actors’ strikes, White was recognized for his performance in Season 1 of the show; his Golden Globe was for Season 2.)
llm: The year of Jeremy. He really deserves all the awards he is getting and I am so happy for him!

human: Throughout my life, I’ve wondered: Why is the universe the way it is?
llm: Throughout my life, I have been in the right place at the right time to capture some spectacular images. On September 12, 2014, I was in the right place for another such event!

human: For six months, the disappearance of $17.2 million in gold bars and cash from a warehouse at Toronto Pearson International Airport has remained a mystery. Now a lawsuit has given the public a glimpse into the victim’s view of the heist.
llm: For six months, a man named Alexander Nguyen had been working as an undercover agent for the Canada Border Services Agency, pretending to be a gold smuggler looking to get $15 million worth of bullion out of the country undetected. He was on his way to making his final deal when he went through customs at Pearson International Airport in Toronto. The customs officer asked him what he was bringing into the country. “Gold,” Mr. Nguyen said. The officer asked how much. “$17.2 million.” The officer asked where it came from. “Congo,” Mr. Nguyen replied. The officer then asked if there were any weapons or drugs in the suitcase. There weren’t. The officer let him pass.

human: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign. Just as historians work to document the facts of the last 10 years, so, too, do novelists try to reveal their meaning. Tim O’Brien’s diagnosis of what ails America in 2023 is “mythomania,” which he defines as an epidemic of lying that swept our nation during the Trump presidency, infecting man and, he writes, bird alike.
llm: When scientists take a close look at the world around us, they often find that it is more fantastic than we ever imagined. For example, if you looked closely enough at your own skin, you would see that each square centimeter of it contains 10 million bacteria. That means that an average-sized person has about 2 kilograms (4 pounds) of bacteria on their skin—about as much as a medium-size dog! This book is full of facts like these. And the reason why this book includes so many crazy and wonderful things about our world is that it is written by a scientist who loves sharing his excitement with young people. You may have heard of Dr. David Eagleman before. He is a neuroscientist who was named

human: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?
llm: Why is Donald Trump so popular with people who are struggling economically?

human: In 2014 Jony Ive, then the chief design officer of Apple, came to Paris Fashion Week with his Big New Product, the Apple Watch, to convince the fashion crowd that wearables were the future of fashion. That turned out to be not exactly true (at least style-wise), but it hasn’t stopped two former Apple designers, Imran Chaudhri and Bethany Bongiorno, from returning nine years later to try again.
llm: In 2014 Jony Ive and Marc Newson's (RED) Auction at Sotheby’s raised $5 million for the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

human: Dave Chappelle was about 24 minutes into his set on Wednesday night in Raleigh, N.C., when he briefly touched on remarks he had made about the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week that had led to cheers, some walkouts and headlines.
llm: Dave Chappelle was not making a political statement. He was making fun of the hypocrisy of people who are quick to criticize others but don't take an honest look at themselves. The same thing that happens in America, where people can't see their own racism because they think all racists are white supremacist rednecks, is what happens in Israel.

human: Welcome to pumpkin spice season, that blessedly fleeting moment when leaves are turning, mornings are chilly and we at the Book Review look back at the year in literature while keeping one eye firmly on the books still to come before the end of December.
llm: Welcome to pumpkin spice season, where the leaves are changing color and the bookshelves are filling up. There are some exciting books coming out this fall — from novels to biographies, cookbooks to art books — that we can't wait to get our hands on. Here are 10 titles we're looking forward to reading this fall:

human: An evil pizzeria mascot, Freddy Fazbear, became a surprise box office sensation over the weekend, reinforcing a message that moviegoers have been sending to Hollywood all year: Give us something new.
llm: An evil pizzeria owner, his mutated employees and the town of Burtville are in for a rough night as a group of camp counselors try to save their friends from becoming the latest meal.

human: During a news conference, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced that interest rates will remain unchanged with a hope that it will lead to price stability and bring down inflation in the future.
llm: During a news conference following its monetary policy meeting today, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) said it would maintain interest rates at their current levels.

human: In college, Lily Gladstone studied the history of Native American actors in Hollywood. Now, she’s making it.
llm: In college, Lily Gladstone (Cree) was always the last one picked for a team. “I was terrible at sports,” she says. “But I had this sense that I could do anything if I just put my mind to it.” After graduating from Whitman College in 2003 with degrees in rhetoric and political science, Gladstone went to work as a horse wrangler on an Idaho ranch and then became a janitor at a public elementary school. “It was really hard,” she says of her early years. “I didn’t have any money. I lived on a friend’s couch and worked all these odd jobs. I had to learn how to be alone.” She also learned to love reading and writing—and eventually

human: Good morning. This is it, for those celebrating Christmas tomorrow: the final push. Maybe there’s a turkey dry-brining in the fridge, or a ham waiting for its holiday glaze. Some will prepare prime rib, or a mushroom Wellington, or crack open oysters by an open fire.
llm: Good morning. This is your wake up call. Please turn off your alarm and get out of bed so you can make these cinnamon rolls. I promise they won't be hard at all!

human: This week, the director of the F.B.I. warned Congress that the Israel-Hamas war had escalated threats against Jews and Muslims in the United States, and that antisemitic threats had reached “historic levels.”
llm: This week, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights released a new report on antisemitism. The report is titled “Antisemitic Hate Crime and Discrimination in the EU: Experiences and perceptions of Jews.” In it, the agency found that 35% of European Jewish respondents felt discriminated against in their everyday lives.

human: When Tracy Bennett sits down to play Wordle, she does so with a word of six — not five — letters in mind: Whimsy. She wants to approach the game with a bit of levity. So, she opens The New York Times Games app and taps into her intuition, five empty squares — each a chance for success — staring back at her.
llm: When Tracy Bennett, Wordle's art director, isn't busy coming up with witty and clever ways of using words in her designs, she can be found playing video games or spending time with her dog. Read on for our interview with this talented artist.

human: “You can’t learn how to be funny,” James Burrows said. “That has to be instinctual in you.”
llm: “You can’t learn to do this,” he says, “you have to be born with it.” He smiles. “I think I was.”

human: In August 1944, in a city near Paris, Robert Capa took a photograph of a woman cradling a baby in the middle of a jeering crowd, her head shaved and her forehead marked with a swastika.
llm: In August 1944, after the Allies had captured Paris, the German army launched a surprise attack on the city, known as Operation Luttich. This operation was intended to split the French and American armies in two by cutting off their supply lines from Normandy. The attack began with a massive aerial bombardment of Parisian suburbs that lasted for three days before the German troops moved in. During this time, many civilians fled the area. One woman who did not escape was a woman who went by the name Madame D., or sometimes just “Madame.” She lived near the Rue de Sèvres and Boulevard Saint-Michel, which were both bombed out during the German assault. When the Germans entered her neighborhood, she ran into

human: Rishi Sunak, the prime minister of Britain, had one last appointment on Thursday evening after a busy couple of days hosting dozens of government leaders, tech executives and other experts at a summit on the dangers of artificial intelligence: a sit-down with Elon Musk.
llm: Rishi Sunak, the Conservative MP for Richmond in North Yorkshire, is a rising star in Britain’s ruling party and one of the most powerful men in the country: He is Chancellor of the Exchequer—the second-most important position after Prime Minister. On Thursday evening at a dinner hosted by the Economist Group he will speak with Elon Musk about his work as the minister responsible for artificial intelligence (AI) policy in the U.K., which has become a global leader in developing rules around the technology. The interview will take place before an audience of business leaders and policymakers and will be livestreamed on Facebook and Twitter.

human: “Don’t ever say you can’t do anything because you are a woman.”
llm: “Don’t ever say ‘I can’t do it,’ because you’ll find that you can. You just have to try a little bit harder.” – Betty White, who has been on TV for over seven decades and is now 95 years old.

human: The district attorney in Uvalde, Texas, has said for months that she intended to convene a grand jury to consider evidence from the 2022 shooting at Robb Elementary School, with the possibility that state criminal charges could result over the botched police response to the massacre.
llm: The district attorney, Daniel Kindred, said on Tuesday that he would present a bill of indictment to the grand jury by Friday, adding that it was likely to include charges against the school’s superintendent and school board president. He declined to say what those charges might be.

human: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday laid out her vision for the coming legislative session and described objectives that often were more of a reflection of her moderate roots than the state’s recent progressive slant.
llm: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Andrew Cuomo proposed a number of initiatives that would affect higher education in New York. Here are five takeaways from this year's speech.

human: Economists spent much of 2023 warning that a recession could be imminent as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to the highest level in more than two decades. But for companies like Soergel Orchards in western Pennsylvania, a slowdown is nowhere in sight.
llm: Economists spent much of the summer warning that the U.S. economy was heading into a recession, but now they're saying consumers aren't heeding those warnings and instead are spending at a robust pace.

human: Colette Rossant, a native of Paris whose childhood in Cairo before and during World War II gave her a global view of cuisine that eventually helped fuel a prominent career in New York as a cookbook author, food critic and food memoirist, died on Thursday at her home in Normandy, France. She was 91.
llm: Colette Rossant, a food writer and cookbook author who helped popularize the cuisines of France in America and gave new life to the classic Julia Child cookbook “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” died on April 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

human: Salman Rushdie, the acclaimed novelist and free speech advocate who was viciously attacked at a public event last year, will write a memoir about the experience, his publisher, Penguin Random House, announced Wednesday.
llm: Salman Rushdie, the author of Midnight’s Children who survived a fatwa on his life in 1989, is writing a memoir about the knife attack he suffered outside his home in London last year.

human: Videos filmed by residents in Sderot captured a grisly and indiscriminate shooting rampage by Palestinian gunmen in the town on Saturday.
llm: Videos filmed by the attackers show that they were inside a mosque, where they fired at IDF forces. The terrorists also took hostages, and later killed them.

human: An article on Friday about the low use of Paxlovid among eligible patients misspelled the name of the pharmaceutical company that makes the medication ensitrelvir. It is Shionogi, not Shinogi.
llm: An article on Saturday about the U.S. Postal Service’s plan to end Saturday mail delivery misstated the amount of revenue that the agency says it loses on Saturday deliveries each year. It is $1.5 billion, not $1.5 million. (The correct figure was given in a chart with the article.)

human: The Times’ Jonathan Weisman analyzed a New York Times/Siena College poll which found that voters broadly disapprove of the way President Biden is handling the bloody strife between Israelis and Palestinians.
llm: The Times’ Jonathan Weisman and the Siena poll’s Steven Greenberg write that “more than half of Americans disapprove of the way Mr. Obama has handled the crisis in the Middle East, according to a New York Times/CBS News/Quinnipiac University poll.”

human: The Pierre hotel on the Upper East Side sparkled on Saturday night as a group of business and entertainment leaders of South Asian descent, joined by friends, kicked off the Diwali season in New York in feathered lehengas, bedazzled saris and gold-stitched sherwanis at the All That Glitters Diwali Ball.
llm: The Pierre hotel is a stunning backdrop for the glamorous evening.

human: In 2021, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. earned more than $500,000 as the chairman and top lawyer at Children’s Health Defense, the nonprofit organization that he has helped build into a leading spreader of anti-vaccine falsehoods and a platform for launching his independent bid for the White House.
llm: In 2021, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will be 65 years old, the age his father was when he was assassinated in 1968. If he continues at his current pace, it seems likely that by then Bobby Kennedy Jr. could be worth $200 million or more—a fortune that would rival his father's net worth at the time of his death. And while his public crusades may have cost him millions of dollars and brought him little fame, those efforts have also helped him generate millions more in private income through real estate investments, stock market trading, and a network of lucrative business relationships with politicians and corporate executives.

human: The United States has embarked on the biggest industrial policy push in generations, dangling tax breaks, grants and other financial incentives to attract new factories making solar panels, semiconductors and electric vehicles.
llm: The United States is investing $4 billion in clean energy research over the next 10 years, part of a larger government strategy that seeks to spark innovation and spur competition with China and other nations.

human: If Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio was the most prominent public face of the congressional effort to fight the results of the 2020 election, his mentee, the newly elected Speaker Mike Johnson of Louisiana, was a silent but pivotal partner.
llm: If Representative Jim Jordan is correct, the Obama administration engaged in an unprecedented and blatant abuse of power. This was not simply a matter of investigating a political opponent. It was not simply a matter of spying on a rival campaign or using government resources to influence an election. It was a brazen attempt by the government itself to overthrow an election.

human: If Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for president in 2024, it’s now clear he will likely still have criminal indictments hanging over his head on Election Day. It’s possible that his criminal liability for the events leading up to the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol will remain unresolved.
llm: If Donald Trump is innocent, he can take some comfort from the fact that the trial of his former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen is not scheduled to begin until April 10 — more than three months after the president’s inauguration day impeachment hearings are set to end. The scheduling of the Cohen trial, which was revealed by Politico, has led some observers to speculate that U.S. District Judge William Pauley III will be inclined to move it along quickly given the potential for it to disrupt the president’s first year in office.

human: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1918, had survived both the Spanish flu and Covid pandemics, as well as her first skydiving attempt at age 100.
llm: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1913, has become the oldest woman to skydive.

human: For over a year, we’ve been rooting through jazz history five minutes at a time. We’ve covered favorites by Ornette Coleman, Mary Lou Williams, New Orleans’s jazz greats and many others. Now let’s turn our attention to a vocalist who epitomized — but couldn’t be contained by — jazz: Sarah Vaughan, “The Divine One,” owner of perhaps the most impressive vocal instrument in recorded history.
llm: For over a decade, pianist and composer Michael Weiss has been performing with the legendary jazz singer, Dee Dee Bridgewater. In this video from Jazz at Lincoln Center's archives, you can watch the two of them perform "You Go To My Head," one of many songs they have performed together over the years. The song appears on their 2009 album, Red Earth: A Malian Journey.

human: Certain kinds of surprises are de rigueur in television. The shock of when a character unexpectedly dies, for instance. It’s jolting, sure, but it’s nothing too out of the ordinary. Television writers do it all the time.
llm: Certain kinds of witchcraft are more common in certain regions. I have seen a lot of information about the history and traditions of Wicca and it seems that the majority of people practicing this religion live in New England, California or the Pacific Northwest. So, it is not surprising to see so many characters from these regions being portrayed as witches on this show. The fact that the youngest witch is from Louisiana (where voodoo is very popular) and the oldest witch is from Texas (which was once a part of Mexico), is interesting. It could be that the writers are hinting at some kind of connection between these two types of magic. In any case, I love this show! I am looking forward to seeing what happens next season.

human: How do you sift through Mexico City’s roughly 57,000 places to eat — more than twice as many as there are in New York City — and choose the most essential dishes? “In a city like Mexico City, how do you narrow it down? It’s insane. The exercise is absurd to begin with,” says Gabriela Cámara, the chef and owner of Contramar and three other restaurants in the Mexican capital, at the outset of the video conversation I’d arranged to do just that: identify the specific meals or bites (or drinks) that best represent the metropolis’s formidable food scene right now. Nonetheless, Cámara was up for the challenge, as were the four other panelists I’d convened, all of whom live in Mexico City either year-round or part time: Ana Dolores, the chef and owner of Esquina Común restaurant in the Condesa neighborhood; Anais Martinez, who founded the Curious Mexican, a street-food tour company, and recently opened Manada, an all-Mexican cocktail and natural wine bar in Narvarte; the food writer Alonso Ruvalcaba, the author of the guide “24 Horas de Comida en la Ciudad de México” (2018); and Carla Valdivia Nakatani, T Magazine’s art director, who splits her time between Manhattan and Mexico City, where she co-owns a boutique in Roma. Before we met as a group, I’d asked each participant to nominate around 10 dishes, including a sweet and a drink, from 10 different spots, ranging from fine-dining restaurants to street carts and market stalls. Then we spent two hours and several subsequent emails and phone calls debating our choices, trying to whittle down the 50-plus nominations to 25 in order to produce a list like those in the ongoing T 25 series devoted to food in Paris and in New York.
llm: How do you like your sushi? We've got the answer for every type of sushi lover

human: The cicadas are coming — and if you’re in the Midwest or the Southeast, they will be more plentiful than ever. Or at least since the Louisiana Purchase.
llm: The cicadas are back! The Brood X variety of the harmless, but noisy bugs will emerge en masse in the next few weeks. Here's what you need to know about them.

human: See results for key races in the Nov. 7 general election.
llm: See results for all 435 House races, plus the Senate and governor's races.

human: A movie centered on domestic abuse isn’t an obvious crowd-pleaser, even when directed by and starring one of Italy’s most popular performers.
llm: A movie centered around the Italian comedy world and its treatment of women is proving to be a hit with audiences. The film, "Loro", was released last month by famed director Paolo Sorrentino. It features Toni Servillo as Silvio Berlusconi, who Sorrentino says has been an inspiration for him since he was young. While many have criticized the film's sympathetic portrayal of the controversial politician, it has proved popular among cinema-goers, with 150,000 viewers attending cinemas across Italy within two weeks of its release. Sorrentino says that one reason for the success of his latest work could be because of the country's current political climate.

human: Since her star-making turn in “Phantom Thread,” the Luxembourgish actress Vicky Krieps has found fertile work, particularly in European productions, playing women responding to tragedy, sometimes with recklessness or self-harm.
llm: Since her star-making 1984 album, “Mistaken Identity,” Chaka Khan has been a paradoxical pop figure. Her voice is among the most distinctive in contemporary music — richly textured and powerfully expressive, a blend of soulfulness and sass that earned her the nickname “the Queen of Funk.” And yet she’s never quite fit into any particular category; at various points in her career, Ms. Khan has recorded everything from disco to rap to gospel.

human: At least 40 percent of crop workers in the United States do not have legal immigration status. Americans typically aren’t willing to do backbreaking work in the fields, farmers say.
llm: At least 40 percent of farm workers in the United States are immigrants, and many are undocumented. But they don't qualify for most safety-net programs — meaning that when they get sick or injured on the job, there's little to no help available.

human: In the 1970s, soft-shell clams started mysteriously dying off in Maine and the Chesapeake Bay. Years later, scientists identified the culprit: a bizarre form of cancer that spread like an epidemic.
llm: In the 1970s, a mysterious cancer began to spread among oysters and clams in estuaries along the U.S. East Coast. The disease caused tumors on the shellfish's gills, which grew so large they sometimes blocked their ability to filter food from the water.

human: A few years after the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests started a Christmas tree farm, Nigel Manley, who oversaw the operations, began noticing some interesting developments among the rows of fragrant balsam and Fraser firs lining the land.
llm: A few years ago I was able to visit a working Christmas tree farm in the Fraser Valley. It was a cold, wet day and we were all soaked through after just 10 minutes on the tour. But it was a great experience! We got to see how the trees are grown, harvested, shaped, graded and bundled for sale. Then we got to pick out our own tree and carry it back to the car.

human: The terms of the private loan were as generous as they were clear: With no money down, Justice Clarence Thomas could borrow more than a quarter of a million dollars from a wealthy friend to buy a 40-foot luxury motor coach, making annual interest-only payments for five years. Only then would the principal come due.
llm: The terms of the loan were never disclosed to the Senate Judiciary Committee during Justice Thomas's confirmation hearing, and Mr. Thomas said he had not discussed it with his wife or anyone else. His failure to disclose the loan was a violation of federal law.

human: The rapid rise of Oliver Anthony’s “Rich Men North of Richmond,” plus the playful pop of the TikTok star Rae. [Originally published Aug. 23, 2023]
llm: The rapid rise of a teen pop star.

human: “The Sweet East,” a shape-shifting satire about modern American subcultures, is a curious — occasionally delightful — object. Its doe-eyed leading lady, Lillian (Talia Ryder), is like the reincarnation of her ostensible namesake, the silent film star Lillian Gish. Both are blank canvasses filled out by different kinds of American dreams. Not the gooey, aspirational sort, but the delusional kind that makes you question humanity’s worth even though you can’t look away.
llm: “The Sweet East,” a documentary about the life of an Asian-American woman in New York, is an attempt at being something it’s not. It’s a film about a young woman named Lily, who grew up in China and moved to America after high school, where she fell in love with the culture and became an American citizen. She was also adopted by a white family as a teenager, which adds another layer of complexity to her story. In “The Sweet East,” we see Lily in all her forms — Chinese, American and adopted — but none of them feel fully formed.

human: A lot happened in the early 1990s: In about four years, the world saw the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Gulf War, a bombing of the World Trade Center, the beating of Rodney King and the riots that roiled Los Angeles, a peak in the AIDS crisis, a market crash, and the withdrawal of funding of controversial artists by the National Endowment of the Arts as part of a larger culture war.
llm: A lot happened in 1993, a year that feels both distant and recent. The same can be said for 2023, the setting for two new plays at New York Theater Workshop. In "Pipeline," Dominique Morisseau's follow-up to her 2016 play "Skeleton Crew," we meet Nya (Jessica Frances Dukes), a dedicated but overworked public school teacher who is trying to steer her son away from the path she knows too well: one of petty crime and prison. Read more here.

human: A leading presidential candidate. The head of the country’s customs agency. At least three borough mayors in the capital. It’s a list that includes powerful members of Mexico’s government.
llm: A leading presidential candidate is being spied on by the Mexican government. The country's intelligence agency has obtained a surveillance order that reads like a political power list. It names journalists, lawyers and activists among those to be monitored.

human: When was the last time you listened to Donald Trump for longer than 30 seconds? Longer than a clip sailing by in a tweet or a TikTok or packaged on the evening news? Lovers and haters alike seem filled to the brim with information about this man, unable to take in any more or alter their view of him.
llm: When was the last time you saw a headline like that?

human: The Israeli military warned on Friday that it was stepping up operations in the southern Gaza Strip, where hundreds of thousands of people had fled to safety, while hospital officials said Israel bombed an area in the south where it had ordered civilians to seek shelter.
llm: The Israeli military's use of Palestinians as human shields violates international law, the UN says.

human: You need to put politics aside to shrink government budget deficits — or that’s the conventional wisdom, anyway. Heidi Heitkamp disagrees. Heitkamp, who served one term in the U.S. Senate as a Democrat from the red state North Dakota, argues that it’s impossible to cut deficits and restrain the growth of the national debt without politics.
llm: You need to read the whole thing, but I'll just point out one of my favorite paragraphs:

human: When Indiana officials created a new industrial park to lure huge microchip firms to the state, they picked a nearly 10,000-acre site close to a booming metropolis, a major airport and a university research center.
llm: When Indiana officials began to plan a $270 million pipeline to bring groundwater from Lake Michigan 135 miles inland, the state’s main concern was ensuring that there would be enough water for its growing microchip industry.

human: Margaret Newcomb, 69, a retired French teacher, is desperately trying to protect her retirement savings by caring for her 82-year-old husband, who has severe dementia, at home in Seattle. She used to fear his disease-induced paranoia, but now he’s so frail and confused that he wanders away with no idea of how to find his way home. He gets lost so often that she attaches a tag to his shoelace with her phone number.
llm: Margaret Newcomb, 69, a retired public-school administrator in Rockport, Mass., said she is struggling to pay the bills. She was forced to move her mother, who has dementia, into an assisted living facility last year after realizing that she could no longer care for her at home.

human: A volcano in southwestern Iceland, the country’s most populated region, began erupting Monday with lava fountains reaching high in the air and the glow lighting up the sky miles away in the center of the capital, Reykjavik.
llm: A volcano in southwestern Iceland erupted for the first time in 230 years on Wednesday, sending plumes of steam and ash shooting into the air and forcing hundreds of people to evacuate. The Grimsvotn volcano, one of Iceland's most active, began rumbling last week after a swarm of earthquakes signaled an imminent eruption. A cloud of ash rose more than 15 miles (25 kilometers) above sea level.

human: The original 2004 movie “Mean Girls” contained something unusual, both then and now: a main character who was home-schooled. But not that kind of home-schooled.
llm: The original 2004 film, “Mean Girls,” was a comedy about the trials and tribulations of high school. It was not only hilarious but also made us think about how cruel teenage girls can be to one another. The new musical is no different.

human: On Dec. 11, NASA engineers anxiously gathered at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., to view a cat video, wondering if it would be in the pristine high definition for which they had hoped.
llm: On Dec. 11, 2014, NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft came within 7,800 miles of comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko — the first time a space mission had ever achieved this close an approach to a comet.

human: And just like that, Ron DeSantis’s quest for the presidency is kaput. In a short video on Sunday, the Florida governor looked natty in a blue suit and red tie, every hair perfectly in place as he papered over his deeply imperfect campaign. He touted his leadership and, perhaps with an eye toward running again in 2028, endorsed the Republican kingmaker, Donald Trump. It wasn’t a terrible performance, especially under the circumstances. But watching Mr. DeSantis’s now-famous awkward smile and listening to his unnatural cadence, it was hard not to think: Yeah. I can see why this guy’s candidacy is deader than disco.
llm: And just like that, the Florida Governor's race is back on. It had been almost over before it started but now, we are back to the status quo ante: a close race with Rick Scott having an edge in the polls and Adam Putnam having an edge among party insiders. Ron DeSantis has thrown his hat into the ring and he will make things interesting for both of them.

human: “So, well, there’s that.” You said it, Axe. The penultimate episode of “Billions” has now come and gone, and with it one of the show’s final opportunities to really blow us away with a patented five-steps-ahead scheme that ends in a sudden twist turning everything on its ear. That is … not what we got.
llm: “So, well, there’s two things I’d like to say. One is that you really, uh, kinda have my sympathy because if this were me, and I was in your position, I think I would be extremely nervous. And the other thing I wanted to tell you is just how much we appreciate what you’re doing.” – Bobby Axelrod (Damian Lewis)

human: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday defended six Nevada Republicans who were recently indicted in connection with a scheme to overturn his 2020 election loss, claiming without evidence that they were victims of political persecution by the Biden administration.
llm: Former President Donald Trump on Monday defended six Republican congressmen charged with conspiring to overturn his 2020 loss by rigging the election in favor of Trump and against former Vice President Joe Biden.

human: Ask Minnesotans about the state’s official flag, and prepare for a crush of critiques.
llm: Ask Minnesotans about their state flag and you'll get two answers: First, that it is one of the most boring in the nation; second, that it has been a target of derision since its introduction 57 years ago.

human: Could President Biden and Donald J. Trump really be locked in a close race among young voters — a group Democrats typically carry by double digits — as the recent Times/Siena polls suggest?
llm: Could President Biden's age and health be a factor in his campaign? A new poll shows the former vice president's support among young voters is lacking.

human: Clallam County in Washington State is far from Washington, D.C. — almost as far as you can go without leaving the continental United States.
llm: Clallam County in Washington State has voted for the Republican presidential candidate in every election since 1980, with the exception of 1996 when the GOP nominee was Bob Dole. This year's Republican is Donald Trump and his support is strong. The latest Kitsap Sun poll (September 28) shows him leading Hillary Clinton by 5 points, which is right within the margin of error. In other words, this race is too close to call.

human: Brothers and Sisters for Israel formed initially to protest judiciary reform. After Oct. 7, they shifted their mission to helping victims of the attacks, and together with volunteers from Israel’s leading tech companies, created a sophisticated data operation to help find out more about those missing, taken hostage or killed.
llm: Brothers and Sisters in Christ, the time has come for us to stand up against the evil that is being perpetrated on our brothers and sisters in Israel by those who hate them because of their faith! The time has come for us to pray that God will grant them wisdom, courage and strength to defeat their enemies in battle and destroy their weapons of warfare. We must also pray that they will be able to rebuild their lives after having been so brutally attacked. But we must also pray that God will open the eyes of the world to what is happening to His chosen people. For as long as the nations of this earth turn a blind eye to this situation, then the persecution of God's chosen people will continue. And it will eventually come to America. So

human: After weeks of anticipation, a volcanic eruption in Iceland’s most populated area sent lava spewing into the night sky late Monday and pushed the authorities into action mode Tuesday. The eruption, which was larger than volcanologists had predicted, happened not far from an evacuated town and a power plant.
llm: After weeks of rumblings, Iceland's Bárðarbunga volcano has erupted. Here's what you need to know about the latest activity and its possible impact on travelers.

human: “When I was maybe 3 years old or so, I was given a gold bracelet with dragons on it from my grandmother,” Diane Neuville said on a video call from Versailles, France, where she lives and works. “My mother is Vietnamese, and in Vietnam jewelry in gold with gemstones is given to children and handed down from mother to daughter. It’s symbolic, like a message of love from the family.”
llm: “When I was a kid, my favorite part of the jewelry store experience was playing with all those cool necklaces and bracelets. The ones that were shaped like flowers or fruits or had charms on them. But, they always seemed so grown up. That's why I designed this collection.”

human: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer. “Never retire” was No. 20. “If you work forever, you can live forever,’’ he explained. “I know there is an abundance of biological evidence against this theory, but I’m going with it anyway.”
llm: At age 80, he was one of the most successful financial analysts on Wall Street. He was also a respected poet and author. And he was an expert in Chinese art. But Byron R. Wien’s friends knew him best for another skill: predicting the future. For more than three decades Mr. Wien, who died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan, worked as chief investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. At first glance, it might seem strange that someone with such a strong interest in poetry, art history and the Chinese language would end up working on Wall Street. But over the course of a career that began when he joined Salomon Brothers in 1967, he became known as a prescient prognosticator, often offering insight into the

human: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease. “Second act trouble” presented in many ways: unmoored songs, desperate cutting, illogical crises, hasty workarounds. Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.
llm: Even in the first episode, I could tell this show was going to be awful. The concept of a reality show where you can't eat is so stupid. They might as well have called it "Hunger Games".

human: Inside the “blueberry muffin” conference room, the walls are, naturally, painted blue. Not just any blue — it’s the calming color you might find a baby’s bedroom, what the paint can refers to as “sea to shining sea.” Anchoring the room is a table, red and oblong, adorned with fake succulents in purple pots.
llm: Inside the “blueberry” offices of Glossier, a cosmetics startup that is one of New York’s hottest employers. The office was designed by the firm Snarkitecture and features pink-painted walls and neon signage.CreditCreditKrista Schlueter for The New York Times

human: Robert Card displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices. He told people that he was planning violence. And his behavior had markedly changed in the months leading up to the mass shooting he carried out last week.
llm: Robert Card displayed an interest in guns, violence and school shootings for years before he went on a shooting rampage at his former high school in 2018. But no one stepped up to stop him.

human: America’s Democratic governors brag about booming local economies, preside over ribbon-cuttings of projects paid for with new federal legislation and have successfully framed themselves as defenders of abortion rights and democracy.
llm: America’s Democratic governors are in a quandary. They want to talk about abortion rights and health care for women, but the party has made it clear they should not mention President Donald Trump.

human: In a perfect world, you’d always be able to serve your Thanksgiving turkey directly after its sojourn in the oven. It’s the best way to take advantage of the bird’s crisp juiciness and meaty aroma — not to mention a chance to hide in the kitchen from football games.
llm: In a perfect world, you'd have your turkey in the oven at 8 a.m., and would be relaxing by 1 p.m. while your bird roasts. But we all know that cooking a turkey is a lot more involved than that. And if you're hosting this year, there are plenty of other things to do besides standing over a hot stove. So why not get ahead? Here are four ways to prep your turkey before everyone arrives so that you can spend less time cooking and more time enjoying your guests.

human: It started with a postcard-perfect snapshot. An image of India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, lounging in a chair on a secluded white-sand beach, provoked heated words from officials in the Maldives, a tiny archipelago nation in the Indian Ocean.
llm: It started with a bang when Prime Minister Narendra Modi landed in the Maldives on Tuesday, but ended with a whimper. human: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
llm: The word ordeal has two very different meanings. It is most often used to describe a very difficult test, trial, or experience. For example, you might say that an athlete had an ordeal in recovering from injury, or that a person went through a terrible ordeal after surviving an accident. The other meaning of ordeal is for a form of criminal punishment, based on the belief that someone who was guilty would be injured by touching hot iron or fire. This use of ordeal is usually found only in historical writing.

human: In “Oppenheimer,” the writer and director Christopher Nolan’s summer blockbuster biopic — three words that generally don’t go together — the character of Kitty Oppenheimer is effaced twice over.
llm: In “Oppenheimer,” the director Pieter-Jan De Pue’s historical drama about the Manhattan Project, Emily Blunt plays a doctor who treats the scientists who worked on the project. She is an idealist, and she believes that her work will help make the world a better place. But as time goes by, she sees how things are not as they should be — for instance, she learns that the United States did not just drop bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki to end World War II; it also used them as a test of their effectiveness.

human: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.

human: Astrid Delgado first wrote her college application essay about a death in her family. Then she reshaped it around a Spanish book she read as a way to connect to her Dominican heritage.
llm: Astrid Delgado first thought about her college essay for the University of Texas at Austin. She began with a description of her parents, who had left Puerto Rico and moved to Brooklyn in search of a better life, only to find themselves living below the poverty line. Her father worked long hours as an auto mechanic, leaving Ms. Delgado and her younger brother to take care of each other.
